reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV is a sci-fi themed survival game with action combat.
It feels kinda like a mix of World of Warcraft and Minecraft with a solid third-person combat thrown in.
The game is build using Unreal Engine and looks absolutely gorgeous.
And there's plenty of procedurally generated content to explore.
On top of that you can build your own base, which will undoubtedly be attacked at some point, so don't forget the defences.
Jetpacks, monocycles and pets are included.
Oh, and dancing around campfire to increase healing rate is there too! :D
Plus, developers are pushing out updates like crazy (just look at those build notes).

On the downside:
- Game in general is not very well optimized at the moment (and there are no options to tweak, only ini files). So, unless your machine meets min reqs (have at least 8GB of RAM, this game loves it), you probably shouldn't get it.
- Net code seems to be unoptimized at all - having any latency and lags to local server is a bit strange (although that might be related to fact that server as well eats tons of RAM and 8GB is just not enough for running both - server and client)
- Current (v7) progression is limited to getting all blueprints from monster and leveling your character does not do much.

Oh, and it's definitely more fun to play with you friends.
If that sounds like your thing - you'll probably enjoy playing GRAV!

Watch overview of the currently available things in the video below:
http://youtu.be/YYvj-3RsJpU

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV is an incredible survival game, the vibrant colors and fun art-style is a perfect mix. The game is mostly online only, I imagine there is probably a way to play by yourself, but that wouldn't make for a very entertaining experience. There aren't a lot of enemies right now, I have been told that this is due to a bug. So far I haven't experienced much PKing (Player Killing), though I have seen it happening according to the chat. The game has a nice friendly/unfriendly system, which makes playing with friends a lot easier. The caves/dungeons can be really hard to find, and leveling up can be very difficult as well, but this game is still extremely pretty and I hope to see this game get even better over the next several updates.

If you are thinking of purchasing this game, I would highly recommend it, there are a lot of friendly players and the game is very well made.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here is a quick first moments video showcasing my first 7 min moments or so in this game on early access launch day:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1rLKJ8KBkT0&feature=youtu.be

33 Minute 1080P HD First Exploration Of GRAV: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ndLhr0uhiyw

55 Minute 1080P HD Exploration of GRAV #2: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dvwU5qoAw88

Okay, this is still not even close to what I plan on being my final review of this early access alpha, but now with over 4 hours of game time, I can at least give you something worth biting on.

This is a huge amazing and beautiful world that is procedurally generated, and perhaps the most amazing procedurally generated world I've ever played in!  This is impressive stuff and is a great addition to the unreal engine library of games.

Combat is frantic, frenzied and furious fun as you move in and out and left click your attacks trying to best time them against the mob or enemy players own attacks.  Quite simply, the combat is very fun and a nice way to keep you invovled as you fight for your life!  While there isn't any kinda of special attacks or rolls to dodge and that kind of stuff at this early point, it is still very fluid, responsive, and engaging!

Exploring the different biomes of this gigantic world full of vibrant colors is perfectly speckled with just enough dungeons and caverns to adventure into.  Inside these tunnels, sounds echo through the natural looking rooms of rock and water drips from the top.  Some great rewards are found inside as well as a much greater risk in the form of more dangerous monsters.  Ore, gems, better loot, and the valuable element X resource are some of the rewards found within these glowing entrances.

This is a very friendly development team who are showing more then a healthy determination to make this the best and most fun game they can, and they prove it with a patch to fix numerous bugs in less then 24 hours after its initial early access launch!  That is very impressive to see!  Add in fun, well thought out game design and you can see these guys care about what they give us!  Just an example of great and fun game mechanics is their idea to have you dance at a campfire to gain health and the team work bonus of mutual faster heals by adding more fellow players dancing at any camp fire.  This idea works brilliantly and makes the game with online strangers much more cohesive fun then other survival games out there.

Crafting requires exploration and killing the bad guys that roam the dark places and nights of it's virtual sandbox.. if you want to craft more then just the bare basic stuff that is.  Resource gathering seems less boring and less grindy because of the dangers present all around you.  Monsters fight each other in unpredictable fashion and will even attack npcs walking through the world!  It's never going to the same experience twice when you log into GRAV and I look forward to seeing where this game goes.  The sky is the limit for this amazing and brilliantly assembled online survival game.  It's very different then anything out there now, while offering enough familiar game mechanics to keep us feeling comfortable with the game controls.

All in all, this new online world cries to us to explore it, to live in it, and to take in its spendor and beauty.  It's bugs and lag is there but minor and a small dent in an otherwise beautiful new online realm.

Until I get more game time, I WANT to play more, so I'm giving it a definite thumbs up at this point.  Please ignore all the negative reviews complaining about this 'early access' game not being complete or having bugs.  That's to be expected in 'early access' period.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is a pleasant expierence!

Made with Unreal3 engine it bring very best of it - fantastic looking worlds: sky, creatures, structures lanscapes, even waterfals - everything moving or static look great. Tons of screenshots to be done.

Pros:
+ Single- and multiplayer mode to get different expierence
+ Variety of worlds (biomes) with terrain, creatures and objects for days
+ Leveling system for tools, mobs and even trees/ores determinates quality and amont of loot.
+ Mobs' loot is a source of crafting matts and ammo
+ Wide crafting system - many structures, weapons, vehicles connected to character level
+ Vehicles - monocycle, buggy, jetpack and more!
+ Tools and weapons aren't subject to degrade or loose with death, crafted once - used infinte
+ Loot you drop on death could be returned in 2 ways and you may easily find your loot using compass. Compass also useful to find other valueable stuff and locations - never get lost
+ Interface, HUD design, inventory at present state is much better than you may see on most youtube videos. Intuitive and userfriendly as it is, even made me forgot to mention this aspect in pros list
+ Updates are meaty with lots of bag fixes, balance adjustments and new content  on regular basis, aprox once a month

Jobs system - to choose role like engeneer, or pilot, or hunter etc and develope it's special skills and level it up. Not clear if it pro or con, just feature.

+Lots of guides in community to help you if you got stuck on your progress way

Cons:
- It has grinding part for resources. Much less than ARK though.
- Expierence available only for killing mobs (as far as I know), not for role related stuff like building structures or piloting vehicles
- Mobs design is questionable, looks like random models bought on market and hardly related to anything in the world aroud them
-  Early access caused lack of optimisation. Even available through interface settings for graphics are mostly useless - you have to edit config files to disable flares etc -  still with light effect on fps you'll get on low-end PCs

Overall: I like it more than ARK, it has variety and it isn't that hardcore to stop you from discovering world(s) around you or force you to grind all day long.
Game won't scare you most likely, as ARK would. It more would inspire you to explore and learn.

And it has nice music. And you can dance to that music, ingame.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- 09/01/2015 - Grav (early days) Alpha Review -
(If you don't want to read the full review, feel free to go to the bottom of this and check out the bulleted
[ Positives + & Negatives - ] Most information is given in that.)

Grav at this moment in time is a game that needs a hell of a lot of work doing to it, especially before it becomes an actual enjoyable, playable experience.

So, why the upvote?

This game has a lot of promise and looks to be a great game as time goes on, and i am going to keep this review as simple as i can for the time being.

[A lot of things will be put into a bullet list at the bottom].

The one thing that sets this game aside from other survival games in my opinion is the Art style and use of vibrant and contrasting colours.

The idea of combining a survival game with that sort of 'MMO' leveling and gear aspect is quite a good concept. Since there is a leveling system in the game, it gives to think that there will be a lot more to do than just surviving against other players and the wilderness. Although at this early in the game, the leveling system could be a slight problem as there is a level 1 starting zone and PvP is usually turned on.

Dungeons and Quests seem to be the main thing that will keep a lot of players busy, as well as building your base or house, especially those running around in groups. Hopefully item drops and loot spawns will be evenly distributed but we will see.

There is currently no Singleplayer at this moment in time, only a Multiplayer. And with it, are a lot of lag issues.

The game as a whole at this moment in time should only really be given a shot by those who want to go out and scout for bugs and breaks in the game. Since it has only been out for around a day and a half, there is really no propper way to pass judgement on how good or bad this game is or will be, we can only wait and see.

+ Positives & - Negatives [In a bulleted list]
+ Art Style & Visuals
+ Leveling System
+ Dungeons & (Raids?)
+ items (weapons, Armor, Building Material)
+ Building system
+ Open World
+ Probably Vehicles & Mounts
+ Soundtrack [ Seems to have a great Psy/Ambient style]
- Extensive Lag issues
- Quest system isn't quite there. [Alot of the givers just get killed.]
- No Singleplayer
- Constant PvP toggle [ Especially in starting zones & Even in groups]
- Quite a few graphical glitches
- Getting stuck in the most unlikely places is likely [E.G While jumping in an open field.]
- Not a lot to do at this stage in the game [Not everything mentioned so far is implemented]
- Combat system is quite fiddley and broken.
- No map or Minimap feature
- GUI is quite broken at this moment in time

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV - A Surprisingly Well Polished Early Access Game
tl;dr ? Goto the Summary

Survival. Sandbox. Procedural.
Sure, its a common trend these days with so many similar titles coming out on a weekly basis. You get resources, you build stuff, you craft stuff, you kill stuff. Repeat.

To me progression in these games is the hardest thing to nail. To what end!?" I always find myself yelling... that is
date: not so much this time.\n\nLets start with the basics  - this is an early access game. This means that at times it simply may not work because as developers patch it
recommended: it can break. It is the nature of these beasts
hoursPlayed: so please do not spam forums because you are too stupid to identify that prior to buying the game. Additionally
voteText: use the forums to search for information
helpfulPercent:
instead of reposting the same questions.

Graphics 3.5/5
In line with other titles
votesHelpful: this game has a slightly cartoonish feel
votesTotal: based (i think) on the Unreal engine
votesFunny:
it has some pretty good features. Currently though customisation of the options is minimal.

Interface 2.5/5
The main menu is minimal however the ingame HUD works fairly well. An upside is the inclusion of item descriptions in the HUD
commentsCount:
making learning the game a bit easier.

Gameplay 4/5
Gameplay is comprised of multiple components:
The Gather
The Grind
The Build
The Reward
The Gather
Resource gathering is primarily done through the use of a 'multitool'. This device allows you to effectively deconstruct resources into nuggets. Currently the primary resouces are: Ore
column16: Wood
column17: Fossil
column19: Element-X.\nThe first 3 spawn in random locations on the map
column20: dependant on the biome. Food is available via a 'Farm' which requires wood for 'fuel'. Element-X however is a little trickier
column21: it requires a harvester to be built and placed on to a deposit. This must then be checked and emptied. All resources are available as drops from mobs/lootboxes
column22:
aswell as materials.

The Grind
Love it or hate it
column23: the Grind is a key component of any levelling game. Thats right
column24: GRAV has levels. Firstly
column25: lets look at the way the world is layed out. There are multiple 'biomes' which are all assigned with a 'state' and a mob level. For example
column26: you may start in a lush forest
column27: where the 'state' is freezing and the level is 1-2. This means that there is tonnes of wood at your disposal
column28: the mobs do freezing damage and are of course level 1-2.\nAs per any levelling scheme
column29: low level creatures only give good experience until you equal their level
column30: then you are best to chase bigger prey.\nWhat I like about the levelling system in GRAV is that the mobs are genuinely brutal. At level 6
column31: if you try and take on a medium bugdog of level 8 - its practically a deathwish. Unless you have decent gear and lots of health packs.\nLootwise
column32: grinding is the only way you will get blueprints - required to further your knowledge
column33: build more stuff and win at life.\nsidenote- I forgot to mention the excellently done combat system. Although simple
column35:
it is smooth and well polished whilst maintaining fast paced combat.

The Build
By grinding and gathering
column36: you are able to get materials and resources. As you would expect from any sandbox game
column37: these are used to build/craft things.\nBuilding is simple
column38: there are a number of predetermined layouts
column39: which allow you to build in a modular fashion. The interface is decent and the skill required is minimal. In terms of craft items and machines
column40: there is a natural progression here which allows you to build bigger and better things. However
column41: the most vital component is blueprints
column42:
which once aquired allow you to build items such as Generators and Automated Turrets.

The Reward
This is where it all ties together and SOMEHOW GRAV has kept a very balanced gameplay. In order to build decent items
column43: you need decent mats which can only be found on decent foes. And thus the circle is born. Although not disimilar to the multitudes of sandbox games available
column44:
GRAV just seems right. There is just enough annoying resource gathering wihtout it becoming a bore.


Summary 10/15
At the end of the day
column45: its an Alpha. There are issues
column46: bugs and bugdogs. There is no single player
column47: besides running your own lonely server. The netcode is laggy and and the system requirements are pretty brutal.\n\nHowever
column51: rich and adventurous. The combat is great
column52: grinding is fun and with a blueprint system
column53:
you need to keep searching for your next leap of knowledge.

My tips to starting with GRAV :
Check your system specs before purchase.
Ensure you have friends to play with
column54:
or at least plan on playing with other people.
If the game bunks out when you run it for the first time - dont panic. goto the discussion boards and search.

Hope you enjoy GRAV!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The trailer was not kidding, currently over half the game is about dancing. Half the customizable controls are litterally dance moves.

That aside This game has a quite a few drawbacks that need to be addressed. First of all: This game has severe motion blurring, when you move/look around it's like you're drunk and cannot see where you're going. Second: The option menu is minimastic, like an Aeria game there are barely any options. No sliders for detail, no sliders for brightness, nothing. Third: placement controls are awkward compared to other survival type games and needs to be refined. Fourth: as opposed to most other survival type games there is no first person mode. Infact the camera distance is permantly set and cannot be changed which can cause problems such as when trying to look out windows. Fifth: The interact and punch button being the same key is a bad idea. New players would get used to the button being the interact key, try using it against something that seems like it should be interactable but isn't, then end up punching/stabbing a traveler in the face.

Hopefully those will be adressed as the games development continues.

Something else that needs to be mentioned is the game's building system is a cookie cutter build of preset rooms. Some may like this design but for me I prefer building the home piece by piece roof, walls, and all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV Review



GRAV is an action adventure sandbox survival game. Players can either cooperate or compete with others over various resources to help them survive the harsh environments found on the planet(s). There are several different elements/materials with which to craft things, and many are very easy to obtain and build. Most things require a blueprint to craft, and blueprints are dropped randomly by enemies. In this way the game encourages exploration and combat to further the experience by offering you a variety of new things to craft and build.

THE GOOD
-----------------
*Extensive crafting options
*Fast-paced combat
*Dungeons to loot and explore
*MMO-like gameplay and mechanics
*Smooth combat
*Responsive, simple controls
*Funny Gameplay / Dancing Character ^.^

THE BAD
----------------
*Laggy online servers
*Confusing user interface

For an Early Access title, GRAV shows you how Early Access should be done. I asked a question on the forums and got a reply from a developer within an hour. That’s something you just don’t see with Early Access nowadays. The development team is very active with the community and always looking for feedback  to improve the game. Give GRAV a shot!

*** I used a stemkey provided by the developer for review purpose ***

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an Early Access Review. Features are subject to change upon full release.
GRAV is something that I was hooked to instantly. I'm not sure if its the beautiful alien landscapes or the dungeon raiding you can choose to do by yourself or with friends, but I really enjoy it. The Early Access so far gives you 2 fairly decent sized Islands to build on, scavenge, explore and dungeon raid. I'm not sure I would call this a survival game though. Although you do have a food meter and you can build a farm, It is very easy to collect food dropped by enemies. In all the time I've spent in the game, I've only ever needed a farm once, and it was because I crafted several Health stims from the food I had. Upon killing enemies they can drop numerous items, but the one item you get a lot of, is food. So I would hardly call this a survival game unless they are talking about the fact that you can die from enemies and other players. It just doesn't have the survival feel. It is a great game though. Aside from the dungeon exploring and vast landscapes you can also craft numerous weapons, armor, and comsumables, as well as build a base with defenses from enemies like turrets, laser fields, and shield nodes(which create a dome around your base not allowing anything in).  There is a leveling system and in order to take on high level enemies you will have to start at the bottom killing low level enemies first and using low level weapons. I found fighting anymore than 2 levels higher than your players level usually turns up bad unless you're attacking a BugDog or a Slime, those things are usually easy to defeat but can take lots of hits and be tedious to kill. Another great feature that seems to grab a lot of people is the ability to dance. Now dancing doesn't just look funny and awesome but it is also a means of healing yourself and others. If you crowd around a campfire and dance, you will instantly start recovering lost health and if you dance with friends you will gain it even faster. There is also some very awesome music to go along with it.
The crafting aspect of the game is pretty vast. There are numerous materials to be collected and some will only be dropped in certain level areas. Craftable items include Buidlings, Weapons, Vehicles, Armor, Stims, Defenses, and work stations. Among the many things available for you to craft in the game you can get a Jetpack eventually which will allow you to visit the other Island that you can see in the distance from a certain side of the island you start on. Everything on the second Island is meant for levels 14+ I believe, although there isn't many low level dungeons or areas to fight in on that second island, it makes you really have to be careful what and what not to aggitate. It kinda makes you feel stuck doing the same thing for a while between just a couple dungeons but once you hit level 20, your horizon starts to broaden and you can visit a lot more of the many dungeons available. That is pretty much it for exploration at the moment but it still offers a lot. I would say each island is about the size of one of the bigger battlefield maps. In future updates there will be something they are calling stargates that will allow the player to visit other planets, galaxies, and hopefully have new enemies to fight. Now I personally haven't played much PvP considering the servers and the game desync and lag are still being worked on. There are rubber banding issues just like there was in DayZ Standalone when it launched, but those issues are being worked on and a lot of progress on those issues have already been made in the short time I've been playing. So playing against other players isn't really fun at the moment cause you never know if that person your fighting is actually where you see them on your screen, but it should be a fun game mode once the lag is sorted out. The developers are very active in the forums as well and seem to want to make sure everyone has a good experience, they even consider ideas that others have posted for the games future.  I'm very interested to see where this game will wind up. I have very high hopes for it and will continue playing it I'm sure, for a while. I highly recommend it if you're into exploration, dungeons, bosses, leveling up and crafting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now don't get me wrong this is not only a great game for an early access alpha, but just a great game in general. I've been playing GRAV for about a week now and I really enjoy playing it. GRAV is a smooth blend of RPG and survival with decent combat, beautiful graphics and an extensive, interesting environment. My only issue up until about 5 minutes ago was the grind to gather resources which in actual fact is a lot less tedious than other similar games. I've spent hours farming the same resource to make only one piece of equipment as the higher level equipment requires A LOT of resources. So I've just come back to a large base I've found to make myself an assault rifle which I have been farming ore for for a very very long time. I've also got about 6000 gems to make some gem armor! Lovely.

Bam.

Ganked from behind by a PKer 8 or 9 levels higher than me. He continued to kill me until he gave up but not before taking off with all of my resources, basically making me start the game from scratch all over again. Until this game has some sort of PK control, I don't particularaly feel like playing. Either that or make it easier to get resources.

TL;DR: Grind is kinda fun and not too tedious until you get PKed and lose everything

Edit 09/04/15: Just to clarify, it isn't the PvP thats a problem (I actually prefer survival games that have PvP), it's the fact that a level 100 player can (and probably will) kill you despite you being 10, 20, 50 levels lower; and there is nothing you can do about it apart from watch helplessly as you lose everything you've grinded for. This is a good game but having to start from scratch again is not something I have the time for.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFirst, realize from the number of hours that I have played that I obviously must like the game. And I do. However, I have come to the realization that there needs to be more to the game. There is no goal, no ultimate mission, no quests, no purpose other than grinding to get resources to get better armor and weapons. Again remember that I do enjoy it. But I truly wish there was an ultimate goal in mind, a true purpose to advance, a reason to achieve the higher levels other than to be able to defeat the bigger mobs. So I plead to the devs to give us a reason to play other than the grind for resources to get better equipment.  And I do recommend this game. In spite of what I just said there is a lot of enjoyment at stake for those who are considering this game. I have seen some complain about the lag, etc. A good way to lessen the lag is to play solo. And believe you me that makes for a greater challenge, but the lag is almost non existent. Here are a couple tips for you if you are going solo. Endeavor to get the automatic rifle. Once you do you will be able to stand back and fight the big guys. They will give you the blueprints you need. Once you get the jetpack blueprint, you will no longer need to make a fortress at ground level. Each planet has some high altitude rocks that you can fly up to with the jetpack and make your fortress there. You will not have to worry about defenses from that elevation. Again I do truly recommend this game and hope others will also tell the devs to give us a goal. Thanks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Cannot recommend at the moment, needs alot of work before its obviously going to be a finished game.  Right now, far too many issues which make the game more of a chore to play than a fun survival game.   Dungeons have monsters that spawn way too fast, sometimes as you kill one enemy another respawns in its place - and sometimes you die because of monsters respawned on top of your character locking you in place because of clipping issues,  graphics wise it varies from area to area, it can look stunning in forests or on moons, to looking kinder low res and somewhat ugly in dungeons.

Another issue distinct lack of the varity of enemies, just 4 or 5 monsters in the game it seems.  So it can get boring fairly fast, especially once you start the grinding.   Base building is also a chore since you have very limited options all across the board, becomes very difficult to build a cool looking base - another issue with bases is that enemies seem to have no problems walking through walls or spawning inside your base either, also what happened to base lights? Or better options at night since its exceptionally dark, pet lights don't really cut it so again, basically Grav needs more of everything.

I think if the developers can really build on this game, improve base building - add a lot more monsters.  Fix spawn rates and generally add more content then Grav could be a serious contender against ARK.

Pros

Multiple Planets/Moons
Many Dungeons to explore

Cons

Lack of options across the board
Too few enemies types
Melee combat is useless
Grindy
Too dark at night, with limited options for lighting
Base building isn't intuitive

I hope the developers keep working hard at making Grav the game it deserves and aspires to be, I think everyone interested should keep an eye on the development, it shows promise once they can get fix the game up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An update a day, doesn't necessarily keep the bugs away.
You gotta' give the developers their due, 2 days after purchase and I'm already on my second half gig update. Not something I am particularly happy with, when at home on (ain't so) Great British, break neck, net speeds of 500,000 bps (<-you like that?). Yesterdays patch caused lag on all servers so I guess today's update addresses that.
Now I know some of you ♥♥♥♥y mofo's (ye' you know who you are) are going to blame our cr4ppy net for lag issues... although this may be true in many circumstances, the lag issue above were prevalent with friends, multiple configs and on many servers.

Base-Building = Check. You place pre-built rooms, stairs, fences etc (lets call them modules) which come together in varying ways depending on the type. It feels like its kind of a mix between sandbox and tower defense. The modules are not cheap and without defense are soon destroyed. I wouldn't really call this sandbox atm. Open world for sure but there are no tools for modifying the world, merely adding.
Survival = Yep. You have to eat. Scary things can come out at night depending on where you are but ftm that's about it.
Adventure = Explore I suppose. Procedurally generated and I'm sure I read infinite, I find that hard to believe as we reached an endless ocean after a 30min run from server spawn (although I suppose that is infinite ;p) No NPC's missions, story-line or any other distractions.
Action = Kill various stuff. Mainly played PVE but we did jump into a PVP when testing lag issues. No deaths but no kills, despite trying (lag was just too bad).

Likes: Pretty yet doesnt feel too taxing on rig, easy learning curve (at least atm). Nice community (so far). Plenty of potential.

Else: Gathering sound, come on, you can do better than that! No building amendment (that could be a biggy). Even with it's potential for growth, it could fall prey to its limited foundation.

I've seen alot of reference to the dreaded grind"
date: to those people I say "perhaps you ain't a gamer"? ;] Anyone else who isn't currently enjoying any other MMO sandbox
recommended: what are you waiting for? A written invitation! Get your a$$ in here!\n\nLinky

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to like it. I really did. For the first hour or two in the game, it felt like it was going to be fun. Until you reach the two hour mark and I realised, that's it. Not a whole lot to do.
The game could argue its a sandbox game, but no sandbox is fun unless theres things to do.

You can wonder around looking at the pretty sights and fight some monsters but thats about it. The loot system doesn't really give the player any sense of acomplishment, they're meaningless. Crafting things and building structures is so awkward and hard that by the time you have farmed a few hours for resources you either die or build 2 or 3 walls before having to go out and farm for another few hours. Its just not fun.

If the game wants to suceed, they really need to give it a sense of direction. At the moment, any generic zombie shooter is funner than this game. The game looks pretty and sadly thats not enough for me to recommend this to other people.

The game is indeed in early access, and I wish BitMonster the very best in bringing out the best the game has to offer. I only hope they will take on the community feedback and enhance their game. At the moment the game has a strong foundation, it just needs content. But for what it is at the moment, I'm going to have to recommend people keep their money in their wallets for now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing this game for a few hours, I can honestly say though it is interesting, it's pretty linear. One thing I dislike about games like this is that they don't really bring anything new to the table. The whole concept to these games is basically as follows

Spawn
Level up
Farm resources
Build a base
Make a clan
Build up your base and clan
Farm more resources
create OP items so you can PvP other players and basically rule the game.

What this game DOES do differently, however, is the very unique vehicles and different DUNGEONS you can raid either solo or with others. Base building currently is actually really extensive, so if that is your thing, I'm sure you will enjoy this one

A few things to note, however, this game doesn't really have very many graphical tweak options (At least I couldn't find them anywhere) so you're pretty much not able to lower the quality by a lot, if you have a lower quality PC.

Also, when you look at this game graphically, and the behaviour of different characters/NPC's and sound effects, you kind of get a Silly" vibe from it. As a whole. Me myself

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Please ignore any review from players with less then 5 hours of play time due to the following reasons.

1) This game will not take you by the hand and spoon feed you its content like most big name games do. Expect to have to ask or go look up things like how to use the friends system or for that matter how to find your buddy who has started off in the game on another home planet to you.

2) The game will at times apear to have crashed due to what looks like an unresponsive load screen or even that at times it looks like its kicked you back to the main menu,  Due to the massive worlds and player buildings/items on those worlds that it has to load it will somtimes look like its crashed when it has not Just give it time to load between planet warp gates even if you see the main menu and it will load you where your warping to in the end.

3) Sure you might find that its a bit of a grind at times, If you do then your doing it wrong! Ask in chat for leveling tips and farming tips or even better gear to be crafted for you. There are easy ways do level and to farm if you know how and players like me and many many others will help you out when you ask for it as long as its not stupid requests like and end game equip when your level 10 lol

4) Despite what some players say the game is been worked on by the devs who unlike other dev teams are fixing bugs before rushing new content that adds new bugs to the game there is bug fix updates monthly.

TL:DR
In short if your looking for polished AAA game thats almost ready for full release and will take you by the hand and spoon feed you like other openworld base building-survival type games do then this is not the game for you yet, keep checking back on it as for now its 65% complete IMHO

BUT... if your looking for a game that you have to put some time and patience into and like to figure some stuff out on your own, then this is a game you will love.

In closing I enjoy Grav as much now as when i started playing it 2 months ago, First I was on the EU PVP server and got to rank 278 (420 is max) but due to a friend from the USA who had crap net and could not play on the EU server I rerolled on the USwest PVE now after 3 weeks I am 294.
****TOP TIP**** If like me you want to move server instead of rerolling like I did there is as I only recently found out a character transfer service provided by the devs follow the link for more info http://steamcommunity.com/app/332500/discussions/8/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those who might be scared off because this is early access, dont be. I know we live in a era, were early access is a often approached thing here on steam, and many of these games are not worth it while some are. I can truly say i didnt know much about this game when i bought it.. but DAMN! This game feels like an adventure!:

Exploring new places, building bases and try to become stronger. Slay beasts and gather blueprints n' resources so you can gear up! Find friends and people you can work together with.. or attack other players (wouldnt advice that since you can get a pretty tight defense system up and running..).

But ofc. this game IS early access, so there are minor bugs and lags. Also the 'ljoin server' loading screen is really long, and takes about 5 min to finish (by my experience), and the game can be very laggy at start. But after a couple of minuttes the game is pretty fluent. The dev's are really hardworking, though! Since the updates and replies from them are pretty quick & often.

This game has so much potential and i am excited to be a part of the progress of the games development!

9.5/10 would Grav again

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nDecent game, a bit grindy for most impatient players who wanna log in and be a digital god in one night with out putting effort into getting gear, etc. Build stuff and some bored player makes it extinct while your offline lol. Whatever server you choose will be your home planet, like it or not....costly Star Gates take you to one Icey Moon or Mid and Exo-planet that on my server looked same as my home world with the same enemies only different color or name. The few types of enemies are the same with generic names for elites and rare spawns, but higher level mobs are the same as lowbie ones, just different color and name, no matter where you go. This all based on playing up to level 29, not the level cap. The servers are as dead with barely anyone online at all hours of the day. Why give the game a thumbs up? Because it's only EA, and for an Alpha staged game it's got a lot of love from the Devs, and has potential to be a fun addictive game later on, but has a long way to go.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game when it first came out in early access, and while it was fun for a few hours, Rust had just received a new update and I got consumed in that for a time.  After the last update I decided to jump back in, and boy oh boy I'm glad I did. This game is truly awesome.  It has a bit of grind, but it rewards you, and finding new blueprints and crafting new items, armor, weapons, etc. is really fun!  Once you learn the basics of survival and find a wing suit, jetpack, and monocycle, it's really a blast.  Then there are the gates which you can build that take you to entirely new levels, and the global world events, which yield a lot of loot.  There's already a lot here - the developers have proven they're invested, and are constantly adding more content.  It reminds me of a prettier Anarchy Online, aesthetically.  And because of the leveled NPC's and dungeons, there's variety to what you're doing.   And it has basebuilding and PVP servers, but PVE is really where this shines.  It's an mmo, with crafting.  Play it with friends.  You'll see a lot of houses around and evidence of human life, but the players are spread out. I really look forward to the upcoming patches and hope this game gets as much praise as it undoubtedly deserves.  Give it a shot, it's addictive!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a Early Access game i am very suprised at how well this game runs and how well its done so far.After 20hrs i havent run in to any bugs, glitches or had a crash yet.I am shocked at this for a EA game.  There is a lot to do in this game. It feels like a Phantasy Star OInline , Monster Hunter, Rust ( with out the sucky parts), and MMORPG all slammed in to one game. I have only played the single player because these types of games its either that or co-op with friends only and the co-op isnt done yet.

After 20hrs i find my self very hooked in to this game. Its very easy to learn. The crafting is deep and yet does not feel all that complicated and was pretty easy to learn how to put it all together. There are a good amount of enemies and differnt planets to explore. Lots of cool stuff like building a base, Jet Packs, Vehicles and tons of other neat things to slap together.The only thing this game really needs to be a complete game is Quests, Boss Fights, Raids, Online privite Co-op, and I'd also like to see more wepon types like explosive wepons, sniper rifles , ect.  Also a ability to upgrade your ammo amount on your charicter.

Otherwise this is the best EA game i have played . Devs seem to be doinga great job with this game so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grav is a crafting survival sandbox with some action elements. You begin your adventure on a planet inhabited mostly by bugs and slimes. After slaughtering some of the local wildlife and extorting the ecosystem for resources, your inventory will begin to fill with the three main components used for crafting; wood, fossils, and ore. There are also gems, but these are used far less in recipes. Once you’ve crafted some armor and some weapons, the next step is to set up a base. It might start as a tiny hovel, but once the sandbox experience takes hold, you’ll find yourself scouring the planet for more components to complete your fortress. Once you’ve got your castle together, what could possibly be left? Another planet of course. There are many alien worlds to be conquered, as long as you’ve killed enough monsters to find a blueprint for a spaceship. Once you find the blueprint you will find yourself grinding for the raw materials. There are tons of crafting blueprints from landmines to automated turrets. Grav has so much potential, but there are some key elements that will require an overhaul before a full release. What are they? Let’s find out, as we take a deeper look at Grav.

The first thing you will likely notice are the striking graphics. Everything in the world is wonderfully rendered and sticks to a pretty cool looking neo-sci-fi aesthetic. This is completed by a soundtrack that displays some fine synthesizer usage, as one would expect to hear anywhere in space. Though, on occasion the sound will drop out completely leaving you listening to plants rustling as you walk. I think having a soundtrack is fine, so is not having one. But a clear-cut choice should be made. If this is only because it’s Early Access, then please disregard. The dancing/waving/pointing in the game is quite silly, and adds to the laid-back nature of the game. Players seem more focused on base building and resource gathering than on murdering each other, which is a nice change of pace for these types of games. The reason for this might be that the world consensus to being nice to strangers on the internet has completely changed, but the more likely reason is that combat in Grav is currently pretty unsatisfying. PVP matches take upwards of 10 minutes, with both players doing nothing but left-clicking. Monsters have a slightly more varied attack pattern, but still telegraph their two or three moves pretty early. You will be killing a lot of monsters to level up. The grind is felt pretty hard due to the linear nature of combat. Hopefully with the full release combat will be improved, and quests/objectives added since they will be essential components in breaking up the grind.

Grouping and descending into a dungeon is also a decent option for breaking up the monotony, though grouping is most often used for chatting and sharing buildings. The grouping system is not fully implemented, and a member can currently only be invited via the console. Luckily, dungeons don’t require a group. If you’ve got the chops, you can brave the dungeon alone and reap the sweet rewards. Boss creatures aren’t just found in dungeons either. They have tons of health, but their attack pattern doesn’t differ from smaller versions of their species. There are a variety of boosts you can craft; health stimpaks, invisibility stimpaks, and even a stimpak to increase your speed. You will use them often as you traverse the landscape, and eventually space in search of resources. There is a nice day/night cycle, to keep you on your toes and let you know when you should head back to base. Night is a very dangerous time, but you can buy droids to assist you. Some provide light, others will provide attack or defense bonuses. They are all bought with a secondary currency called Element X, which can be mined from glowing spots on the ground by building a Harvester. Currently the game is based on Element X. Build a giant base near some extraction points, build some Harvesters and lock them down. Then about 30 or 40 hours later, when your base is massive and your level is maxed… You can head out and destroy the tech-palace of some other maxed level players. That’s the MMO formula and while building a giant castle is enticing enough, I do have a couple bones to pick.

Before I unleash criticism, I’d like to say that once Grav fully develops I believe it will be something amazing to play. Currently, it has some serious flaws that need to be addressed before I’d put 30 hours into a game in order to reap the full reward. Combat simply doesn’t feel that fun or dynamic and needs a ton of work. Weapons don’t really seem to scale as much as levels, while incoming damage certainly does. One would think an assault rifle would be a decent remedy, but ranged damage is pitiful. On top of the low damage, they actually use ammo. Building my first pistol was a major letdown. The Generator runs on Wood, and eats quite a lot… About 2000/day, so if you get a base worth defending most of your social life will consist of cutting trees with a laser. World events are a great idea but poorly implemented. Monsters spawn 2 levels above the highest player in a zone, so a level 30 can hang out in a low-level zone and really cause some havoc. Base building is the only real incentive I’ve found at the moment. Even during the build, you will need to head out for resources which can be hard to find.  While you’re out and about you’ll inevitably find some combat. Enemy AI needs a lot of help. I can’t count the mobs that simply stood there and took their beating. It’s either that or they walk through a tree for a cheap-shot. Overall, I think Grav has all the makings of something great, but we’ll probably need to wait for a few more updates to truly find out.

Summary: Futuristic multi-world sandbox, set around base-building and domination of the landscape.

Final Score: 6/10 for aesthetic, community, and blueprint variety.

Full text/photos: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-grav-early-access/

Video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZfYsJ4ArPj0

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Solo play review)
A game with great potential.
But..
To be honest it's not really worth the 20€ in any other way then supporting development as it is.
Progress is a bit slow but it's there, I truly hope devs will keep at it and make this game all that it can be.
There's a lot of tweeking going on, I'll give em that, but more content is needed to make the game awsome.
There's not really much to do other then grind materials and a few blueprints.
I usually don't have a problem with grindy games, but I must say that this type of grind get's boring after a while.
Might be more fun playing on a server with other ppl, but as it is, it's hard to find a active server with ppl on so I couldn't tell.

Still..it got potential and I won't dismiss it with a thumbsdown, there's greatness lurking about in this game.
And it is a EA so only natural stuff are missing and buggy.

So buy it to support further development, or pick it up on a sale to support your wallet, there's a few fun hours to be had and more to come I'm sure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was extremely excited to start playing this game. Space, exploration, technology, different terrains and random enemy events all garnered my attention it's way. Upon playing it further I wasn't all that impressed. Controls felt stiff, animations were decently good, gathering resources became annoying (as it was a grind every time) and the gameplay simply remained alright. I realize that this game is early access but there are some issues to be address.

GRAV is a sandbox game by it's premise in which players are required to acquire resources to build and improve their technology or build up their base on a world that is segmented with different environments. Controls are basic at the moment and movement is a bit limited (in regards to jump/dodge/rolls). Obviously, the player can move about using WASD and increase their speed with shift (if they have a stim available). Space will make the character jump quite a distance in the air (air-time cannot be adjusted) while G" will initiate a greeting and put the character into an animation (as well as "X" and "Z"). On top of this
date: players are able to fire out a flare using "F" and are able to keep pets (which can be managed by pressing "K"). Additionally
recommended: skill points can be managed by pressing "K" as well. "B" handles the build menu and will most likely be one of the most important buttons you press. There are devices in-game such as the flaregun that help players locate one another. If players are looking for something more in-depth
hoursPlayed: a locator can be built in which coordinates will be displayed on the screen showing locations

helpfulPercent: crafting new tools or building certain stations. The harvesting tool allows the player to harvest wood

They got pretty creative with some the vehicles they created and decided to make it real by using fuel. One of the first modes of transportation is the wing suit. Altitude can't really be gained but holding space will let the character glide (and doesn't require fuel). The monocycle looks like something out of South Park. It's this giant wheel the player can craft that sort of looks like a motorcycle that does require fuel. The jetpack is another mode of transportation that is quite self-explanatory and uses fuel as well. A doom buggy can be created as well as an aerial vehicle known as the hammerhead (which is extremely expensive).  Lastly

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A LOT OF THE REVIEWS ARE PREUPDATE!!!! ITS A NEW GAME ENTIRELY!!
DID YOU LIKE SWORD ART ONLINE?
Are you looking forward to No Mans Sky?
Looking for a game to fill the void?
This game is amazing. I cant stress that enough.
Pros
-Multiple planets for multiple tiers of play
-Crafting weapons and bases beyond my dreams
-Forming your own cities with other players and building your own lore
(ie, my faction has been fighing a different faction for X amount of game years and weve traded lands in the warring)-this leads to recruitement and armys being built
-You can lay claim to lands and tax them like any good kingdom
-DEVELOPERS LISTEN TO IMPUT FROM PLAYERS
-Decent response time from developers
-Nice support
-Decent community with lots of help given
-teaming abilities that make roving armys a real threat
-lots of gun platforms
-mulitple jobs and skills
-NO PAY TO WIN


Cons
-sometimes you can get stuck in walls/cliffs
-the water has no mass and you can die by jumping into it
-some places that make sense to be able to build in are off limits but places you shouldnt be able to you can

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am not a PVP player, so for PVP you need to read the other reviews.

i've played it a few hours and nearly scratched the surface of what is in the game. Its fun and entertaining. It also is a bit of a grind, and sometimes you might ask yourself why you build a base. (it looks pretty if you have made something looking sci fi-ish.
the building interface isn't one of the better ones, it often is difficult to view what goes where, but it works.

animations are funny and mostly correct. No map. So you are wandering aimlessly around until you get the hang of it.
some people say there is no bigger goal. Well it's goal is survival and exploration.  The survival is not too hard, but exploration. ... the world is HUGE. you can run your socks off... and soon you start wishing for a vehicle of some sort.

coop: yes! finally a game where i can build something with my buddy and we can share items i make shoes, he makes gloves. put it in the storage container and you can swap things out. So far i didn't find a trade menu.

The menu are somewhat frustrating as they don't respond. if you open the build menu it slaps the thing you previously build in your face and that can be annoying. (a little)
most things just take some time to get used to.

best part? it's early access AND it is playable AND it is fun. so it probably gets better, more playable and more fun. Unless they make some weird design decisions. (have seen that too often, to make a game 'better' for a small but very loud(mouth) group of .... take your pick.)

As it is now for early access i can recommend it.
did i mention:
- active development
- nice in-game community
- wiki with help

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The tags on this game are lies:

Survival ? You kill wild alien animals and they drop ammo and food rations. Wow. Such survival.

Base-Building ? Pre-made structures that don't allow any creativity. Sure you can technically build a base but there's no fun to have there.

Crafting ? You build stuff with random resources and need blueprints to progress in the game. So basically your progress is based on luck and grinding.

Maybe the PvP is fun but this game doesn't really allow any creativity so it must get boring very fast. I suggest Starmade for a fun sandbox game in space that involves creativity. It's even free as long as it's in Alpha ! Just download it from their website.

Also, this game's community seems awful. According to other reviews, griefing happens regularly. And fanboys are downvoting all negative reviews.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Current Rank At Time of Review ~ 40-50~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
TL;DR
GRAV is an exciting sandbox that incorporates MMO style community, friendly and active developers, along with a promising future product. If you enjoy space exploration, building bases, exploring dungeons, and gun combat, this is a must have for you. I plan to keep playing for a long time to come, and hope that the devs keep up the great work!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Review:This weekend was a free trial of GRAV.
I didn't expect much with the recent status of sandbox survival games, but I decided to give it a download.

When I started, I went into the single player version of the game, and was placed into a beautiful environment with a couple weapons and some resources. Combat is extremely smooth, building is user-friendly and easy to do, and gathering resources is done with a multi-tool, which is a superb feature (no more axes, shovels, etc.).

After a couple hours in the single player, I decided to check the multiplayer scene. I was surprised when I saw that BitMonster hosts plenty official" servers (PvE and PvP) which make the game have a sense of community. I quickly hopped on a PvE server and started harvesting resources
recommended: and having a blast. I had a buddy of mine join me
hoursPlayed: and with a friend
voteText: since it's a sandbox survival
helpfulPercent: the game gets x10 better. After playing about 8 hours or so on the PvE server
votesHelpful: we noticed griefing is an issue (without shield generators running)
votesTotal: and there was no way of removing these players even if they were right in front of you. So we decided to start over on the PvP server
votesFunny: and our game experience has improved since then.\n\nI'll start off by saying the game seems like it was meant to be played in PvP
commentsCount:
and they've done it in a way where dying isn't necessarily the end of the world.

Reasons death isn't terrible:
You don't lose your gear upon death. This means you keep your armor

column17: locator

column20: just most of them. I'm not sure the percentage on the materials you lose
column21: but it's a big amount.\nYou keep your ammunition! This allows you to respawn and keep guns a blazin'.\nYou can set your own respawn locations easily. As long as you do this frequently
column22: you won't have issues getting back to where you were.\nTo prevent death you can store your things in a chest. I would recommend you build a small base and with a shield generator (this is an early blueprint that makes it so your base is immune to damage so long as it is powered with a generator
column23: thus keeping your stuff protected)
column24: and then place your chest in that base.\nOne of the coolest aspects of the game is that fact that there are multiple planets

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nill recomend the game,the game is loaded with content, and worth every penny of the full price,but if you dont like grinding for hrs on end, and then have some high level guys take all your stuff, dont play pvp...its unfair in those terms, noobs have no pertection at all, its just unballanced in the pvp area...so i would recomend doing pve ,then you will have some fun..very addicting game...u cant stop playing it...its amazing, just dont waist your time grinding all day on the open servers, untill u know what your doing.. it does need 8 gigs of ram, and it uses every bit of it, so if your at 4 gigs dont bother..u will be ok with 8 though..the game runs smooth and silky most of the time, i havent run into any game breaking bugs yet....the game looks really good, and the jet packs and winged suits are awesome when your gliding over the planet, the sky is the limit on how high you can go, great animation also..the base building is fun, and is nesessary if your going to put hrs in, just dont put a totam up in your base..a totam is somthing u can use to collect taxes in the area its embeded in, its the only way ppl can break into your base..so do not construct it in ur base..very action packed and exploration orianted, 1 thing i would like to see is travilinng to planets with a ship instead of telliporting, you can build many things including a space craft..not sure of its use yet though..have fun, and kiss the family good by!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game tasked me with killing another player for a reward, which turned out to be a Bronze Skull mask. When I put it on and removed it, I became headless!

10/10 would be decapitated again.

===========================

In all seriousness, this game has good potential, but as you can deduce from the above, it's just marred by bugs right now. And it's lacking some very basic features. There's not even an option to change the game's volume. Yes, you read that right! I couldn't hear my party members talking whenever there was combat going on, due to the battle sounds drowning the voices, and there was no way to change this.

The graphics controls are also very limited; it doesn't even have V-sync. Some in-game actions are missing from the hotkeys menu, so you can't assign them.

Combat is at the moment quite boring and unbalanced. Even if you're the same level as creatures and you're wearing the best armor you can, most creatures take 50-75% of your health with one hit, making meleeing them an inviable option. So I had to resort to shooting them with my pistol, but since they don't take notice of you if you're shooting them from so much as 30 ft / 10 m away, it's very boring. They just take all the bullets and die without realizing anything.

That being said, I did manage to have reasonable fun during the Free Weekend, and again I think it has good potential. I intend to check out this game in a year or so to see if it has left early access and the bugs and balancing issues have been sorted out. I might very well buy it then, if I'm not too busy with No Man's Sky.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have run a local server for my family of this game since it's early access release. I bought it on sale (3 copies) and it has been worth it. The devs are patching every couple of days and slowly creating more robust world.

I would recommended for those that like Phantasy Star Online ish type games (it has a slight touch of it <- maybe it is the graphics) and survival games.  If the combat is somewhat streamlined and varied (multiple types of attacks with the same weapon) and as the content and biomes are increased this game will be very successful.

This has been one of the more dev active projects that I have dealt with on early access, the devs are being very responsive. I commend them on this and hope they can keep up the good work.

You can host your own server in this game (single player is accomplished this way) though it is not  straight forward, yet (I am assuming this will get better).

The graphics are good, again I go back to a open world PSO vibe crossed with the color palette of No Man's Sky. The skies are busy, night day transitions good and the few biomes available are pretty. Enemies are repetitious (again this is early early access - and understandable) and predictable.  The weapons are varied but simple.

I guess the best thing I can say is I got my money worth out of this game already and it looks like it will only get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An extremely clunky execution, Grav takes up way more computer resources than it should, making it run poorly on all but the newest machines.

The game itself is trite. Most of the game is harvesting resources and grinding mobs. There are only like 7-8 different mob models that can be fought. They all behave the same way and are just recolored for different areas.

PVP is not well balanced or implemented, and the game is completely lacking without it.

Developer support is slow coming as their team is very small.
Minor, pointless, bug fixes are constantly pushed out, while major issues are put on the backburner.

All things considered, this game has potential. In the current state, I certainly cannot recommend anyone purchase or play it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Would definitely recommend this game to anyone who loves open-world sandbox survival games.  It's still in Alpha Early Access at the time of my review, but there's still TONS of content available currently.  The combat is what's expected of a TPS, the crafting is relatively easy and intuitive, though it could use some streamlining.  A better tutorial would be fantastic, my first hour of the game was spent figuring out what the hell to do and what could/couldn't kill me.

One thing I like a lot is the leveling system, and zones to fit level brackets.  Makes the game much more progressive, rather than staying in one area and farming your ♥♥♥ off.  Definitely fun to play with friends or people you meet on your planet.

As of right now:  8/10 Would dance in front of flames to heal myself again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am typically more than a little wary of both early access and survival games, but something about GRAV caught my attention, and boy am I glad it did. I picked it up shortly after the EA launch and, despite the fact that it was somewhat laggy and buggy, the beautiful aesthetics and the thrill of finding new stuff to craft kept me going. The devs' devotion to the game is obvious; patches were rolling out regularly and the changes week to week were obvious. I took a break after one of the patches caused some rough times, but, coming back, it's obvious they've been working just as hard. There were major substantive changes to combat, harvesting, crafting, exploring, and basically every other system in the couple of months I was away and I am loving it. Cruising around with a jetpack, exploring endless planets, and shooting everything that moves is already a blast; I'm very excited to see how far this game can go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Incredibly stunning gameplay for an Early Access game. Of course, the UI is not the prettiest, as well as the main menu but those are minor things considering this IS an early access game. Fortunately, the gameplay as well as the visuals will keep you busy.

I'll be listing some pros and cons from my point of view, I haven't played this game for too long so there you go.

PROS:

- Freedom to do what you want to do, exploring areas and planets or slaying alien life forms, as well as building

- Construction in this game is quire fun, there are no waiting times for building, you can build a small outpost or a gigantic fortress if you wish!

- Levelling and job system available

- Weapons and armor, as well as useful devices that makes you glide in the air

- Vehicles!

- Resource gathering and crafting are also here, strengthening that survival" feel in the game

CONS:

- Resource gathering can be tiresome and grindy if you're not really into it

- Early in the game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love the look and feel of GRAV. I've put well over 80 hours into it, and definitely got my money's worth. The gathering isn't horribly grindy, and the survival is fun, but still needs improvement. I'm happy that in the short time I've played, there have been several large updates and overhauls to the game's mechanics. Even if the game were to become abandonware (which it doesn't look like it will, at least anytime soon) I will have enjoyed the time and money I've spent on this game much more compared to various AAA games.

The game is not perfect and has it fair share of issues, so let me share them with you. First, The performance is quite awful. I can barely manage 1080p60 on a Intel Core i5 4570 and GTX 780, and the frames will often drop below 30fps. Luckily, they have been doing optimzations every patch, but I haven't noticed anything major yet. Second, Collision with most of the terrain is completely wrong. Some rocks, spires and other terrain objects you can walk right through to a certain degree, as well as some hitboxes for objects are far away from the object itself ( think invisible walls). It really breaks the immersion of an otherwise beautiful game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWow, i'm surprised...I thought this game would've been boring and bugged as i heard voices about it on day one, instead, even if i'm just at the beginning, i realized by myself that is a colourful and original touch from the usual survivals, the experience seems pleasant and i'm willing to discover more about it., This game will not delude you, i'm usually not keen on 3rd person view games, i'm totally for 1st person view, but this looks so funky that becomes pleasant at the look and the functions in game are not so fast to understand but they are still easy to learn, inventory for example consists in a list of written items, not drawings, divided by category. There's so much to learn during the levelling process of your character that the game will never become boring, because you need to gather a lot and kill lots of mobs, in different places, to get blueprints, but you are rewarded with new recepies and new strategies to add to your gameplay. You start practically unequipped as a LVL 0 and in a few months if you are skilled you might reach LVL 100 with so much equipment and so many resources to loose yourself into developing strategies, this game is so pleasant in colours and graphics either, and it is fun to kill mobs and players around that goes straight to my personal favourites, GOTY!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As I often described the game to my viewers, it was Planet Explorers meets Borderlands. At first, that was actually not a bad mashup, but after awhile the game simply just lost appeal. While I had fun with it for a little while, I don't think I could recommend this to anyone.

Pros    The goofy humor like the campfire dancing, especially if you had a large group going.
Vehicles were pretty fun, and the world was big enough they felt useful.
Planets looked pretty good, and had some good variety.
Combat was simple, albeit grindy when you do it for the 1,000th time.
Cons    The goofy humor does get old eventually.
Despite the variety, after awhile everything felt like it was just a reskin of the last planet.
Game starts to be too grindy and boring after you hit a certain point.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Truly captured by this game.

Visuals are basic yet stylish and pretty, offering amazing lens flare and a colorful palette. the slightly cartoony style fits together well like a jigsaw.

Gameplay is fun and creative - PvE can offer challenges and rewards smart and creative play to gain the edge. enemy's vary with small and large bosses to accompany each race
PvP also does the same, I have found it is much more rewarding to recon and follow somebody then to flat out kill them.

Relationships with others are formed pretty well in the game, I have made a few friends and also rivals on my server one of which being a moderate sized group which my own group is at war with but we all still talk together over public chat making a nice atmosphere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great sandbox game and the second that keeps me playing like Robocraft:)

Huge Universe where you can travel from Homeplanet to different Moons and Exoplants. The graphic looks amazing.

Join and build up a community base. Work, plant and fight togehter or alone. Use bike, jetpaks buggi, spaceship to travel.

Find chests, and big Bosses, level up. And important of all, collect resources and keep them safe.

The performance of the game (with R9 280X and 8GB RAM) is about 25 FPS at 1080p, more frames are available on Moons:-)

You can choose between different jobs, each comes with a own level. The bad thing that a job level has more priority then your overall level, you will get weak again.

Its a good game for a longer play or just for casual gamer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Info for deaf and hard of hearing people:Fully Accessible. I’m not sure if there’s any sound cues that is convenient to have, like a monster rampaging towards you. But missions and such are displayed in text.

I have NOT tried multiplayer.This is a SINGLE PLAYER experience.
Cons: Not a real survival game. Minecraft is more a survival game than this one is.
Mob respawn rate is pretty damn high. You can’t really ‘clear’ an area or cave, they’ll respawn somewhere close by via some magical means.
Building is with modular prefab structures. And the machinery you build might not even fit in those. You also got to find blueprints first before you can start building more interesting components.
Harvesting is very basic. Just trees, ore nodes, and some other sort of nodes, that you can harvest from. The landscape is pretty much untouchable otherwise. Harvesting doesn’t yield terribly much materials either.
There’s no storyline. If there was, I totally missed it. The devs probably missed it too.
Non-interactive buildings in the landscape. There are some interesting looking buildings in the area that you can’t do anything with. Clearly they’re inhabited, since the lights are on brightly at night. How rude.
It’s all about grinding. You’ll need to kill for leveling up, it’s pretty grindtastic. I haven’t even bothered to go to level 10 so I could go to the moon. Game’s not interesting enough for bothering.
You run underwater. Swimming doesn’t seem to be implemented yet. You can even make a campfire underwater and dance!
WeiWei the Weary Wanderer is EVERYWHERE! The humanoid NPCs in the game are all WeiWei, and you can’t do anything with them.
The game doesn’t take itself seriously. Your first crafted set of armour will likely be a wooden one, and it’ll look ridiculous. Dancing in front of a campfire heals you. Might be a pro for some, though.
Pros: Graphically very stunning. Landscapes are gorgeous. My GTX 970 could handle it with ease. It felt smooth.
Conclusion:While the store page plays hints at this being a survival game, it feels more like an action RPG of sorts. You harvest, you can build prefab stuff, you have to kill for loots and XP. Everything’s too underdeveloped to even speak of a true survival. Overall it feels pretty pointless, doubly so because of the lack of real quests and interaction.

If GRAV would develop to be more about survival and building, less about lame fighting and leveling, and more about interesting ways of harvesting and crafting, then it might become interesting. As it is now, I’m not really interested in this. At a higher level there might be more stuff, but it’s simply not interesting enough for me to continue/grind towards that stage.

I find Planet Explorers more engaging than GRAV, offering a bit more, like a storyline, interactable NPCs, and reasons to go explore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first Early Access game, and boy, did I make the right choice!

I'm not very into sandbox survival games either but this made me rethink the whole genre.
You can see that the devs are putting a lot of time and hardwork into this game, and as a
player you get to explore the world that they've envisioned!

They've got a ton of content as it is atm. You get the basic survival stuff : Crafting, Basic combat and what not,

What I didn't expect going into this game was the vast amount of pregenerated dungeons you might
find while strolling the mountain side, gathering resources for your base. Or how about the randomized locations of the hundreds of random bosses that spawn in to kill you? How 'bout the dynamic day/night cycle that'll keep you on your toes? (Day mobs and Night mobs are different so if you need something from a day mob, you'll have to survive the night and vice-versa.)

The.Dungeons.Meng.

The dungeons are pretty random and exciting at the same time. If you play with friends, you can go exploring with them, fighting huge-♥♥♥ bosses and what not to get them crazy loots at the end! You can also get some mad resources if you bump into them inside. Share the resources with your friends, and craft even better gears!

For me, this game provided more of an mmo experience than a survival sandbox. Oh, that's a good thing. So If you're looking for a great game under  $10, this might be a great pick up. Depending on the server you choose, you get to meet great allies, annoying rivals and face great obstacles to survive your way to the Stargate! (A future update that will let you and your squad travel to the moons!)

Well like any game, this game still has it's flaws. It's young, it'll definitely mature over time. As of Update 8, they've made changes to the server/engine to make the game less laggy -- Which is a pain, if anyone has played this game prior to U8. Some kinks and whatnot still need to be addressed but from the looks of it, this game is travelling a path that promises gamers a great adventure. For an early access game, i'd give it a 8/10. None of this 10/10 b*llcrap (It's defnitely not perfect yet.)

So if you're hesitant on picking this game up on EA, i'd suggest you come back at a later date or on official release for a more fleshed out vesion. But as of now, my friends and fellow servermates are having a blast trying to survive Grav's wonderful atmospheric world waiting for future updates and enjoying how the game is evolving throught the Dev's love.

I highly recommend this game if you want a fun adventure with a community that helps each other out a lot! See you guys in GRAV!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI got this game with the humble monthly. I thought that I subscribed for ARK that month, but Grav caught my attention and held it. I played it for 7 hours in one sitting and enjoyed it a great deal. It was a touch glitchy, but it was pretty, easy to get into, and got the adrenaline pumping more than once. Why is this a down vote? The server that I played on went off line on Saturday. It is now Wednesday and still the server with 7 hours of character progression is not listed. The forums have revealed many with the same problem, but no solution. I'm sure the devs have a lot on their plate, but to have mutliple servers down and, from the point of view of the players, ignore the fact is not something that I can forgive. Perhaps it will be better in the future, but as of 3/16/16 a brilliant game is being undermined by its very creators. It's an uninstall for me I fear. Buyer beware.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

On the first day of EARLY ACCESS release, at least we're able to play on the servers.  Not even a year out of development, this game is obviously not without flaws or bugs.  The game itself is *beautiful* and runs smooth.  I've run into and talked to a couple developers on servers, mainly because they appreciate the player feedback and give answers to our questions.  That is if they can answer the question -- it's a 6-man team.  The gameplay is really fun so far and what the devs are saying make me more excited for all the updates they'll be plugging in the future.

It's not a AAA title, so you don't have to worry about a $60 price tag.  In fact, they're running a 30% off sale for the early access launch.  Looking forward to more dance-offs and slapping people in the face. :D

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI absolutely love this game. I have not suffered from the issues other have. I don't have bad lag issues, the game is 100% playable, and my saves work well. The gameplay is fun and rewarding. While crafting right now is limited, there is still enough to build a functional base to survive in. Food is abundant, and resources are fair (a little less than favorable though). The creatures and enemies are well varied with decent AI and the game's graphics and art are gorgeous. There are several things missing though, like the ability to adjust audio/graphics, and the ability to drop items. Dropping items isn't a big deal though as it seems your backpack is unlimited. Would like to see a trade feature amd more content. Discovering blueprints adds new recipes though, so I'm sure there's still stuff I haven't found yet. I would recommend this, but only if you don't mind a slightly broken game. At the moment, I'd give it a 8/10
