reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played for 20hrs on the PVE server during the free weekend trying my luck on the free steam key but to no avail. Nevertheless it gave me a good impression of the game and i really like it. However there can be much improvement in the game overall. 8/10

Pros:
Huge open world (exploration of beautiful world with hills, forest, desert, tundra and sea on home planet)

Environment effect/ other planets (moon - low gravity/no oxygen)

Easy to survive (food abundant, hunger is the only factor in early phase that you need to be aware of except for enemies, no other environment factor until later stage)

Crafting materials easy to find(after getting a hang of the game)/harvest

Vehicles/jet pack/glider (awesome)

Caves(dungeon)

Variety of enemies/monster/bosses

Cons:
World too big with no map system (only a compass system that show important direction, easy to lose sense of direction and get lost in the world)

Early tutorial quest system is great except some lack description (for example i have no idea how to activate pet - right click does not work - until someone points out to activate on key bar.)

Does not have other quest after tutorial (aimlessly wandering around trying to find lvl 25+ monster after finishing tutorial, moon and lvl20 cave)(until the end of the 20hrs manage to find 35+ on tundra but still did not find 25+ and cave)

Hard to survive (getting gang by monster suddenly spawning next to you in an enclosed space/most of the time getting 2 hit ko by any random monster)(after 20hrs still does not understand how the health/damage of monster works)

Drops majority of resources on death and lootable immediately by anyone (Dying to monster all of a sudden in a PVE world and losing most of your resources because someone random was nearby your dead body)

Grindy leveling (damage and experience gain based on level difference btw player and monster)

Lack of early weapons variety/ melee becomes obsolete (After having a rifle, blade and handgun become useless, The same rifle last forever)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Simply put, this is the best survival game I've played, ever, and the best PC game I've played in about 5 years.

That said... don't get me wrong. It has its flaws.
It's buggy.
It's really ♥♥♥♥ing buggy.
Some enemies feel incomplete - sometimes projectiles fired just seem copy pasted from another.
Before Reborn, this was barely even worth your time because there was so little content aside from PVP.
There are permastucks around mountains,
water areas need serious work with collision boxes,
and the arctic planets are so unpolished they feel like a joke.


But it's addictive. I love every possible imaginable thing there is to love about this game, and there is A LOT to love. I started playing this as something to tide me over while I wait for no man's sky... but at this point? I think I'll just keep playing this and watch it grow into a better game every day.

I love the devs of this game. Any other active online MMO dev team could take a page from the way they handle their feedback. I've seen developer leads come straight into the game and investigate bugs, playtesters will talk directly to the community, and they take all requests super seriously. They are the nicest dev team I've ever seen. Period.

And the community, despite some weabos who get off on fooling newbies into giving their FOF codes, is really good. I've met more friends on steam here than I have on any other game, ever. This game is incredible and is a steal for the price.

I;ve put in over a hundred hours (and I work full time), and I plan on putting in many more. I even bought 5 copies just because I wanted to. Amazing work, guys.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I bought the Grav 4pk in the hopes of finding a co-op survival to play with my friends and family. So far I'm not dissappointed. Well worth the $ spent.

For an early access game it's very stable. There are a couple glitches I discovered, but on the whole those aren't game breaking I just simply needed to open and close the inventory again and the problem was solved.

Wei Wei the weary traveler confuses me, but Vendroid has come in handy quite often.

The feel I get from this game is the same as a 3rd person MMO even including a quest based tutorial which actually gives you rewards, diffferent areas, with different level mobs along with varying elemental statuses, resource gathering, elemental influence and gear system.

Thankfully to avoid the game getting bland, you can travel to other planets (and moons).

So Far I've only played Solo on my own world, but I think I might find a decent server as this game has huge potential to just get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, let me try to put a little positive spin on these negative comments:

The game itself is... somewhat fun. It has the makings of a great game, but some of the mechanics need to be polished. As I was explaining it to a friend of mine, it's like a mix between Minecraft/Terraria and Borderlands, with a number of those elements ripped out.

Now, wait one second before you skip over this because of the reference to two other amazing games, allow me to explain.

> This game pulls from Minecraft due to its heavy use of resources to make your character stronger, build new items/buildings/machines/rides/ect. However, what it takes out from the Minecraft formula is the open-ended sandbox elements that Minecraft is known for. Unlike in Minecraft, you can't dig down into the planet to build yourself a base. And, on the topic of bases, they themselves are very limited compared to its blocky counterpart. Though, as seen in the base competion, there is still room for creativity... once you figure out how to do so.

> Now, in reference to Borderlands, I'd like to talk about the weapon system in these two games. In GRAV, you can craft a number of various weapons, from Pistols, SMGs, Assaults and more; and, in similar fashion to Borderlands, it's shoot to win against most of the enemies you'll face within the caves. The controls for shooting, aiming, and the like are a little tricky to get at first, but with all things, practice will make perfect. But, to the element that Borderlands has over GRAV, is simply the vast enemy types. You're going to shoot a LOT of turtles, starting out. And, that, in itself, can be a turn off for a lot of gamers. Myself included. But, it's something that, like all survival games, is something to be overlooked if the enemies are well-designed and function well...

Which leads me to the negative aspects that I've noticed in playing. First and foremost, while you are able to recover lost items upon death, a number of the few deaths I've had could've been prevented if the enemies acted as they should. That meaning, a lot of the time, I would be clearing enemies out, only to have them immediately respawn not long after I passed by their corpes, which left me sandwiched. And once you're stuck, good luck getting out of the mess.

Also, while the game has individual leveling systems for different classes, swapping classes quite litterally means you'll be level 1 in a level 12 area if you're not smart about where you're swapping. Now, while I don't mind grinding, it made me feel like I had to go back to those older areas to build my character up before continuing onward. Now, this in itself wouldn't be a bad thing if the enemies didn't chunk your life so much. Level 1 against a level 5 toad, and I'm out in two good hits. This is with the second class armor, by the way. That, and the hitboxes for the attacks are kind of hit-or-miss with some of the enemies. I would be clear out of the way, and a frog's tongue could still damage me despite missing me by 45 degrees.

Everything considered, the game still has a fair amount of work that needs to be done. But, is it a game that I would pass by? Well, if you've read this all down to here, then honestly, I think you could handle the game. It's still fun, for what it's worth. Especially if you get a few buddies, that's when these games would shine. I mean, I got this game with the Humble Bundle, and I don't regret it. So, if you have some patience, and you're willing to take a few cheap deaths, then I think you'll enjoy what this game has going for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Put simply, this game is amazing. It's an early access gem that no-one seems to have noticed yet, which is a huge shame. The game already has a lot to it, it feels like an RPG/Survival/MMO mix, and has just the right amount of each genre in it. There are tons of things to do and the base building is really great, with a nice snap build system you can build pretty much anything you've ever dreamed of. The graphics are fantastic and really do a good job of creating an amazing atmosphere. There's tons of loot for you to go and find, and the whole system behind finding blueprints is very fun and makes finding blueprints not feel like a boring grind, you get excited when you find something real good. I enjoy the crafting system a ton, and personally my favourite part of the base is doing cave runs and then stashing the loot in my base. Killing bosses is also a great time. You can eventually unlock other planets which you basically 'warp' to, so there's a neverending stream of new environments and biomes to go through. Dancing is a fun little activity with many animations, and my favourite part of this game is honestly the amount of updates the devs push through. We get about 2 a month with huge amounts of content!

I really don't have much to say on the minus side for this game. It can feel a little repetitive after a while, the game really just consists of farming materials, building a base, doing cave runs and.. that's kind of it, really. The game could benefit from a food and water survival system to keep you on edge more and give you more work to do. We also need more world events such as alien hordes which come for your base every x_amount of days. I love the animations of the game although jumping animations need a serious rework, your character looks like a wannabe superhero. Loving the jogging/sprinting animations though. The game could also benefit from a camera system where instead of it being stuck to your back, the character turns and can run toward the character (like GTA/Warframe etc.) The combat system also doesn't feel too great. You right click to enter combat mode, and you're stuck there until you click again. What would work really well is having to hold right click to aim, and left click could keep the camera zoomed out and have you blindfire with no crosshair. Speaking of crosshairs.. the current one doesn't feel fantastic. A dot, or a circle with a dot in it would work much better, in my opinion.

Anyway, that was my personal feedback and suggestions to the devs, but if you're looking for an actual recommendation there here it is: This game is fantastic, the fun almost never ends, and there's reason to keep you playing for hours. There's tons to do and co-op makes it even more fun. It's definitely worth a purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a surprisingly good game, even if it still has some things it needs to tweak.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Update Jan 13: I quit this game a little bit before the merge completed. I've decided to write a bit more in regards to this game, as it may not necessarily be the game for you.

TL;DR: If GRAV is on sale and you're looking for a cheap thrill for a good week or two, you can consider buying GRAV. Otherwise, if you're looking for a genuinely well-developed crafting game, don't buy GRAV. Long version is below.

My True Rating: Neutral. Not a recommend, nor a not-recommend.

First of all, this game is structured to be a RPG-slash-crafting game, where you cap off at Job Level 60, and there are seven jobs in total, for a combined Rank of 420. Each job has their own perks and intended uses, so the goal is to max out each rank in any particular order you desire.

The game gets you hooked by being built as an RPG. About 99% of the time you're not crafting; you're focusing on leveling up, finding blueprints
date:
and making better equipment.... to farm more.

Once you reach past Job Level 50, you start to realize  there's nothing else to do besides build. You hit a mental wall, realizing that after you've put in dozens of hours in the game, you're struggling to find a reason to keep playing.

Don't let the trailers and screenshots fool you. The world exploration" aspect of the game wears out very quickly. Not only that
recommended: but there are only a handful of worlds available for you to explore
hoursPlayed: due to the restrictive nature of how the devs designed the game.\n\nSimply put
voteText: the worlds are grouped into four different tiers
helpfulPercent: and they rotate every three hours in real-time. This means that there is a theoretical max for the number of worlds you could explore
votesHelpful: since 24 hours would mean there's a maximum of eight worlds per tier.\n\nOf course
votesTotal: the devs could add more tiers and/or more content
votesFunny: but with the characters capped at Job Level 60 and all equipment more-or-less already hard-coded
commentsCount: I highly doubt that will happen.\n\nIn regards to the crafting
column16: you can build bases
column17: but with the limited customization options (this isn't Minecraft or some other major crafting game)
column18: you start to feel like the game is lacking on that front.\n\nAnyway
column19: you'll likely clock 50+ hours simply farming until you reach Job Level 60. You'll have significantly more fun if you're playing with some buddies
column20: even if you meet them in-game. But once you max out
column21: you'll lose the will to keep playing
column22: and will feel inclined to quit."
column23: November 15, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all I bought this game on sale, thinking I could get a bargain like others may have as well.... I was not disappointed at all. I would have paid full price for this game had I known beforehand what I was getting into...

Grav isnt your run-of-the-mill survival games. You have a few different things going on in here that make this game unique from others. You have to first learn the basics of the game through the tutorial guide that gives you some information or ask players of the various multiplayer community for help. Afterwhich, you have a sandbox open-word to explore / research / conquer, and through your personal trials in Grav, you may or may not make it to the top.

You have a choice of 6 more Jobs to choose from after you research them after you attain lvl 10 Astronanut (Beginner Job) for which you can then branch off and do your exploratory own thing and see how the game is really going. From crafting gear and weapons, to base building / base raiding, PvP on some servers, rotational planetary systems and mroe to be seen...

A few things to remember when playing Grav. Dont snack in real life while flying with limited wood..... If you hear Grak's Suck!" You will understand sometime soon yourself.

So
date: feel free to come join the fun and I am here. If you have further questions feel free to ask.\n\nHave a great Grav Day!"

Once you reach past Job Level 50, you start to realize  there's nothing else to do besides build. You hit a mental wall, realizing that after you've put in dozens of hours in the game, you're struggling to find a reason to keep playing.

Don't let the trailers and screenshots fool you. The world exploration" aspect of the game wears out very quickly. Not only that
recommended: but there are only a handful of worlds available for you to explore
hoursPlayed: due to the restrictive nature of how the devs designed the game.\n\nSimply put
voteText: the worlds are grouped into four different tiers
helpfulPercent: and they rotate every three hours in real-time. This means that there is a theoretical max for the number of worlds you could explore
votesHelpful: since 24 hours would mean there's a maximum of eight worlds per tier.\n\nOf course
votesTotal: the devs could add more tiers and/or more content
votesFunny: but with the characters capped at Job Level 60 and all equipment more-or-less already hard-coded
commentsCount: I highly doubt that will happen.\n\nIn regards to the crafting
column16: you can build bases
column17: but with the limited customization options (this isn't Minecraft or some other major crafting game)
column18: you start to feel like the game is lacking on that front.\n\nAnyway
column19: you'll likely clock 50+ hours simply farming until you reach Job Level 60. You'll have significantly more fun if you're playing with some buddies
column20: even if you meet them in-game. But once you max out
column21: you'll lose the will to keep playing
column22: and will feel inclined to quit."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello dear steam users,

this is going to be my first review, at least it is on here.

At the first sight I was twisted on this one, I liked the unique style, the mix of several game mechanics...on the other side was the early access stamp, and the MMO aspect.
So obviously I'm very hooked by this game, it offers a unique gameplay and jesus, I didn't enjoy a game like I do this one quite for a long time.
Until now I haven't really experienced the early access aspect of this game, and if I did it wasn't in a bad way.
There's quite a lot to do, I love some of the refined game mechanics.
Grav mixes a lot game mechanics, and makes them even more sweet and clever and by what I can say so far pretty balanced.
Usually I'm not a big fan of MMO's, even though that means nothing more than what the name tells...massively multiplayer online. Still I like the shortened RPG aspects of the game, they aren't too much nor too few, just exactly as I would wish a system to be in a game like this.

The look is unique, unlike games like DayZ, Rust and so on which basically play in the similar genre, Grav doesn't get that stressfull, it's so enjoyable, so blithe, especially with friends. Simply running around and watching the world was fun.
I love the base building, though some things are difficult to remove at the moment when you begin to play. ( it's possible later on when you have the right weapons to destroy it again )

The dungeons are good so far, I really like them, they offer a nice different experience in combination with pvp gameplay.

The farming goes smooth along the rest of the gameplay.
I like the dynamics, mobs attack each other, they change at night, become more aggressive, the newly added events are quite nice, they add pretty well up to the rest and all in all the game has many layers on which you can spent time, none of them is bad so far. Me and my brother we actually didn't know what to do at first, visit another dungeon? farm for our turrets to protect our base? or build a jet pack and check out some of the other places in the world? hunt specific mobs for special drops to craft some cool new weapons ?

All in all it's a great game already now, like I said, I haven't that much fun quite a while!
And that means something as I'm a passionate gamer which is not very confident with the situation of gaming in the moment, thanks for this one BitMonster!

Review should just offer you a little insight, but I play every kind of game ( as long as they offer something I think spending my time on is worth it ) so my judgement on this game isn't influenced by anything.
Also it might change and things add up while Grav develops.

If you think about getting this because you actually like it" but can't decide because you're suspicious due to all the early accesses that disappointed you
date:
do it. It is worth it. If you know you're not into these kind of games and aren't open for something new/different ( the look ) you'd better not do it. If you want to get fed and follow a red line this isn't something for you neither.


To be noted: At the moment I'm on pretty weak hardware
recommended: so I have to play in 1280x920 and pretty much everything where is it possible is turned off/down when it comes to graphic. Still I ♥♥♥♥ing enjoy this game. :-)"

Grav has a LOT of potential. Right now it's $13 for an enjoyable, if basic, survival game. The devs have been very good about addressing early complaints and have released 2 patches that fixed the major issues in 48 hours after release. Impressive.

Art style is awesome, combat and building is fun. No singleplayer yet, but you don't buy a game like this to play alone.

Overall- Right now, 6/10. Fun but buggy. For an early access game 2 days into alpha, not bad at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My friends and I have really enjoyed GRAV. Most games are a bit stressful, so it is nice to to play something that is interesting, fun, and laid back. There are 2 ways to get over your head, it is because you ignored what level area you had entered which are clearly marked, or there was a moster raid and you were caught near it. Do you want to fight and build alone, you can. What to join your friends for a while, again, that is your choice. You are given several characters and if you want all the abilities, you must upgrade them, so if a new friend arrives, change to your lower level characters and go to a lower level area, or stay at a higher level and escort them through higher level area, so they can level up faster. Once they shoot a monster even once, they will share in the experience after said monster is dead.

IT IS FAMILY FRIENDLY.
For those parents out there that love to games but run into objectionable materiel in so many fun games, you should consider GRAV. The only thing one might find offensive, is the ability to leave a dropping on the ground which others can step on. If you create a private server, with a password, then you control who plays. My son and I have enjoyed playing together.

Setting up the server  is supper easy  once you use the correct port . Most tutorials tell you to use the wrong port. The correct port for your server is 7777. Look at the bat file they give you, and you will see.

This game is not finished  and I have found only a few bugs. I would like to see more polish to the game, more monsters, some direction on where to find all the blueprints and some tutorials to help new player.

At the time of my writing, I have played 67 hour and I look forward to many more. Buy a 4-pack and gift it to your friends. There is much to be enjoyed here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've given this game 80 hours of play, and I must say I gave it far more chance than it deserves.  In its current state don't even try to get into it as it's so imbalanced and lacks basic features and common functions that even solo developers get right and in game long before these guys are even considering that it might be a good idea.  It's got plenty of potential but unless the devs pull their heads out their asses it's going nowhere.

Some of the plaguing issues with this game include:
-Extreme level based PVP imbalances. (Passive upgrades & gear.)
-Extreme lack of viable base defense options.
-Easymode 10 minute wipe the base EMP bomb that takes 15 minutes tops to farm materials for if you have the levels.  Of course you spent way longer actually building that base but it's gone now isn't it.
-Game logs you out and back in to transfer the player from planet to planet, you actually see the main menu here.
-Poor UI functionality such as ability to quick move items into player inventory but not out of and a number of bugs.
-No sound adjustment settings at all and the guns are so loud you will never hear anything else if you wear headphones/set.
-Monsters will spawn inside of your base, yep inside your base.. if not that they actually walk right through the walls often enough.
-Very little monster variety.
-If you're looking to explore and see different biomes don't expect much more than different lighting or color fills on the objects in most cases.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The description of this game is misleading. While on some levels it is indeed a sandbox survival game, it has much more in common with a MMO, especially in terms of the grind. Gathering resources and levelling up is a very slow process, and to make things worse, the only way to progress in the game and unlock things is to get random, rare blueprint drops.

Overall, the current state of the game is grindy and tedious, which is a shame since it looks like there's a lot of places I would like to explore but lack the time and interest to grind through the game to get there. Hopefully the devs will streamline the progression soon, but for the time being I can't recommend this game unless you're fond of the terrible MMO time sink of random rare drops for critical items.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll keep it simple. Grav is in Early Access Alpha. The biggest issue I see now is some sporadic server lag spikes which the Devs have acknowledged and are working for a fix. With that being the biggest issue, Grav is the game I have been looking for. In it's current state it offers fun RPG/survival elements in a harsh NPC world. The map has zones which lets you know what level the creatures are. Being one of the biggest Rust fans I think I have found something to keep me satisfied until that game is finished. This game offers more playability than Rust did in the legacy mode. It's fun sci-fi techno feel really got me hooked and I can't wait to see how the game evolves.

If you don't mind random lag for the time being and your system can handle it then I encourage you to pick this one up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off I would say I purchased this during a sale where it was $9.99 USD, so it was definitly worth it especially considering that it is still early access.

This game is pretty fun overall, it pulled me away from fallout 4 during the free to play weekend where i tried it. That being said it is not perfect, some cons include:

The mob spawn rate is rediculously high-you will clear a zone of mobs in a cave, and they will be back within seconds sometimes

The game can be very resource intensive, especially in the ram. There were times where the game itself would use over 8 GB. Some people say they get low fps, but I have a 970m so I couldnt tell you.

The community, at least during the f2p weekend, was a bit mixed. There are some major d**** in this game. They will get a small group of three or so who are several levels higher than you, and take everything you have or have built. That being said, there are some really nice people who are helpful and dont kill the newbies.

Someone else has said that the combat is a bit weird, and that is rather true. Melee is basically unusable except maybe in some pvp cases. The mobs that have to be higher level than you to get the blueprints will two or three shot you. The same mobs will take a couple clips to kill, and if you are far enough away they wont even come at you. (This is kind of a good thing though, considering they will kill you really fast and it takes several bullets to kill) You will need around 1000 bullets for an average cave to be fully safe.

All of that aside the game has some really cool things, and is absolutely gorgeous. I think they will eventually take care of the issues, and the built in VOIP is actually pretty cool. It works based on distance to who is talking, so it's almost similar to talking in real life. someone a couple feet from you will hear you. I would definitly put this on your watchlist, if it goes on sale 10/10 buy it. If not still a solid 7 right now, but there is a lot of potential.

(edit: formatting)

TL;DR : 10/10 - Great Game, Would Grind (like a schoolgirl) Again.

My experiences in GRAV so far:

Came into the world, fresh curious and a bit scared, already knowing a few things off hand to do:  Get stuff, and make stuff.  I zap trees untill I realize these aren't trees but some other kind of weird alien small... tree.  Oh well.  I find and start to get used to seeing the fossils and gems and ore scattered around, but alas no trees.  Plenty of vendors saying hello though no players in sight.

Eventually I find some trees, relived to finally see their true form, and harvest what little was there.  As time progressed other bits grew back and I was able to build a base after running back and forth to grab what meager supplies were around.  Quite proud of myself, and expending myself for the evening, I slept and came back to GRAV the next day.

This day.  Boy.  The forests were plenty.  I was able to gather and build and affter doing what I wanted to and realizing how much I was really wasting, starting to kill and level, and realizing this is how to gain knowledge" and craft new things.  I would trade off

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR If you want a game in the vein of Rust, with longterm lifespan like Ark, gunplay and soft RPG of Orion: Prelude fused with maybe a twinge of Trove and kind of trying to be No Man's Sky aesthetically then grab it, on sale for under $10 if possible. If you have any other build and survive games, stick with them unless you hate their visual style or lack of soft rpg progression.

Definately delivers on the look and feel conveyed in the teaser videos, worth the free play time I got from it for sure. Tons  of fun to group up with friends or play solo and gather, craft, upgrade and pillage. Even PvE has a PvP aspect in that you can destroy people's structures for resources or looting purposes but base defense is quite easy, save for gathering wood enough to keep your defenses online overnight in realtime. Like any game in the survival-building-lootgrind genre you'll need to either maintain a base, or prepare to place lots of small stations when you need to craft specific things (which is more viable with a large group.

The building system is a little hard to get used to and everything is tied to a worldgrid as far as I can tell, which you may or may not like. It's handy for building large structures you may start on a cliff and need to support from below. Summoning other players doesn't always work; if you decline you may have to decline repeatedly hundreds of times over the course of 5+ minutes. It seems who you summon is based on some parameters not made available easily to the player, so our course of action was to upgrade until we could summon everyone in the group at once, which became annoying with the decline glitch.

All in all, very entertaining and easy to sink some time into. If I had a dedicated group of players and no other games that delivered what I was looking for in this genre, I'd purchase it. Server setup is simple, might as well fire one up as there aren't a lot out there, but official servers are surprisingly non-toxic.

Even PvE has a PvP aspect in that you can destroy people's structures for resources or looting purposes but base defense is quite easy, save for gathering wood enough to keep your defenses online overnight in realtime. Like any game in the survival-building-lootgrind genre you'll need to either maintain a base, or prepare to place lots of small stations when you need to craft specific things (which is more viable with a large group.

The building system is a little hard to get used to and everything is tied to a worldgrid as far as I can tell, which you may or may not like. It's handy for building large structures you may start on a cliff and need to support from below. Summoning other players doesn't always work; if you decline you may have to decline repeatedly hundreds of times over the course of 5+ minutes. It seems who you summon is based on some parameters not made available easily to the player, so our course of action was to upgrade until we could summon everyone in the group at once, which became annoying with the decline glitch.

All in all, very entertaining and easy to sink some time into. If I had a dedicated group of players and no other games that delivered what I was looking for in this genre, I'd purchase it. Server setup is simple, might as well fire one up as there aren't a lot out there, but official servers are surprisingly non-toxic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note that this is based on personal opinion and experiences on why someone should buy it.  If you want a review on individual aspects of the game, please consult another review
As of this review, I have played the game well over 30 hours, including over 25 on a US East PvP server, and to be honest, I can't get enough.  The game itself, for an alpha, is very playable, but does not shove everything immediately at you; you earn your way through the game.  Going into new, unexplored territory of unknown dangers and the risk of coming into contact with an extreme PvP player, this is all aspects of the game that give me a feeling of excitement.  The game itself is good, but it’s the interactions with other players and friends that make this game absolutely worth it.

In terms of community, I’ll fall upon an official PvP server.  Unofficial, PvE, and generally other servers may differ from this experience.  For a long time after playing PvP survivals like DayZ, Rust, etc., I have always looked on server choice by risk, having enough players to be a part of the game, but not too much to have a huge threat.  This all changed when I joined this average of 8-12 up to 40 as of this review.  I was genuinely surprised when most people on the server were actually quite relaxed and helpful.  This lead for my clan and I to make a name for ourselves on the server, even if not a prominent as the veterans of the game.  I love new players and rarely anyone PvPs with the friendly community, especially after the seniors demonstrated their caring and generosity.  I have high hopes for my community and its expansion into even more relationships and wonderful memories.

SUMMARY
Grav is a very playable alpha that is especially fun with friends.  The game in itself can feel grindy, especially at early ranks.  However, if you can form or find a good community in the server, make a name for yourselves and start your reform; this will lead to a happy server and the game earning the rightful spot in your memory bank that it deserves.  It runs well if you meet minimum requirements and has fun and unique items and features (notably the dancing; look it up if you have never seen it).  The game is one of chance, you may or may not find a server of generally good and happy players, but the shear feeling of helping someone and being part of something gives you purpose and can lead to great relationships.  This game is very greatly worth your time and money.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I downloaded this game for the free weekend I, I really didn't expect what I got.

I jumped into the single player and almost instantly felt at peace. The amazing, serene music put me in an instant state of tranquility while I walked around the beautiful landscape.
(unfortunately the water is nothing more than a material/texture with post processing color tint under it)

I kept this up for a while. I walked around for nearly 4 hours, simply exploring the landscape.

Then I got some friends in on it, and the real fun began. We built bases, jumped into stargates and traveled to the moon and other interesting and still beautiful planets. We explored GIANT breathtaking caves full of weird and dangerous aliens, (and slaughtered them) and conquered intimidating boss-like foes we at first were sure were going to slaughter us.

I notice a lot of negative reviews with this game cover the PvP. But I really don't think that's the way this game is meant to be played. It certainly doesn't feel like it, and I know I wouldn't enjoy it. In fact, I'll probably never play on a PvP server. This is best as a PvE game in my mind, really. Let these planets steal you for a minute. Take you and your buddies on an scenic adventure. All while conquering your objectives, if you please.

The whole building"and "crafting" system isn't too complicated
recommended: but it leaves room for challenge and things to be sought after. It does its job and it does it pretty well. This IS NOT minecraft. Nor do I want it to be.\n\nThere's a few things in the game that give a vibe that the game doesn't take itself very seriously and it's obvious. Such as
hoursPlayed: dancing at a campfire to regain health and stamina instead of just sitting and resting. Or
voteText: the ability to poop wherever you please. over
helpfulPercent: and over
votesHelpful: and over
votesTotal: and over again. The former I can get over
votesFunny: I hardly need to use the campfires anyway. But the latter
commentsCount:
REALLY can ruin the experience for me real quick. Luckily this can usually be avoided if you're playing with a mature group.. hopefully.

Play this game. Don't judge it as a survival game along all the others. This is its own piece of art.
I'm only 17 hours in right now as I've only been playing for two days. but this time will skyrocket. I know it.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Would I recommend this game? Yes, with caviats.Would I recommend this game? Yes, with caveats.

I've played little actual single player with this game, and with good reason. This game gets pretty boring when it's just you. You're basically dumped in the middle of an uninhabited planet, with the only goal to explore and make yourself comfortable.

As such I tried the online servers, and was promptly killed soon after arriving, twice. As is common in these kinds of games. So instead I decided to go PvE, but doing that alone would've been boring as I said above. So I setup my own private server, set it to PvE, and invited a friend. We've since had a blast just wandering around finding stuff, surviving hordes of creatures at our front door, and building a variety of structures and contraptions.

This game has its variety of bugs, which is par for the course in Early Access games, but very few game breaking bugs, besides the odd crash and freeze. Getting onto private servers is a bit too complicated, and really needs a GUI interface with favoriting, instead of manually typing the IP into an in-game commandline. Other in-game things also would benefit with GUI, like changing suit colors, since they are also currently relegated to the badly documented in-game commandline.

Overall, this game is grindy, but it really shines in exploration, and has an interesting future. Though currently, this game isn't worth $20 because it does still need more content, and better fleshed out mechanics, tutorials, and settings. But  if you can pick it up for around $6 to $7 on sale like it is at the time of this review, it could be worth it for you. Though if you hate getting randomly killed, you'd best find a PvE server or a make private server with friends.

PS: There's a nice Server GUI[www.jimbobslimbob.com] available that can make setting one up much easier. Please keep in mind that your server will need a decent chunk of RAM to run as it maintains several worlds, and unless you have a fairly beefy PC it's best to run it on a separate machine from the one you'll be playing the game from. Otherwise you'll likely run into performance drops and in-game lag.

PSS: If you get into the game and experience terrible frame rate, make sure the game is running on your discrete NVidia or AMD card, and not your integrated Intel or AMD graphics. By default, NVidia's control panel selected integrated for this game, which I had to manually set to discrete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Survival games are one of the biggest genres in modern gaming, especially when it comes to early access games. I’ve played my fair share of them, and I can easily say that GRAV is better than most of them out there. However, even though GRAV is touted as a survival game and everything, it is actually more of an RPG with slight survival mechanics, even feeling like an MMO of sorts when played on multiplayer servers. This is because there is almost no threat from survival mechanics, you spend most of your time killing enemies for experience and loot, and the grindy job system lets multiple players to work together.

I spent about 17 hours on the game, which let me see pretty much everything the game had to offer, except for getting to see all the available blueprints. The whole time was spent on solo mode instead of playing online with players, which allowed me to focus more and I even learned something important about the game. One of the last things that happened to me while playing was that an object spawned in the middle of my base, which caused enemies to appear around it and since I was the only one there and defensive turrets weren’t working for some reason, I lost all resources that I spent 15 hours gathering. Luckily, you never lose equipment or blueprints you have obtained even if you die so I still had those. Since solo and multiplayer is exactly the same game wise, you are severely handicapped when playing alone. The biggest thing is that instead of multiple people training different jobs, you must train every job in order to do stuff yourself. This is especially bad when you must spend a long time killing enemies just to use advanced vehicles as a pilot. Want to then efficiently build a base? Spend another 20 hours killing enemies for experience so you can learn passive talents. If you’re looking for a fun game to create large bases and have with with all the cool things you can create by yourself, you might as well go somewhere else unless you want to spend 100 hours unlocking everything.

Other than solo mode being handicapped, which was discussed previously, there are a few other things that are severely detrimental to GRAV. While it is good and bad that each job must be trained separately, the fact that you only get experience and blueprints from combat makes no sense. The hunter job, which is focused on killing enemies, makes sense to train it with combat, but why would someone with the jobs to make building bases and gathering resources more efficiently want to spend hours killing enemies, instead of actually doing their jobs. Instead, most of everything in the game should grant experience and blueprints, with bonus experience rewarded if it is part of the job you’ve selected. Combat is also very plain and boring, as it just involves you running backwards while you shoots tons of ammo at enemies. The only time that you die in combat is if you’re in a cave or other dungeon area, where enemies will pretty much just spawn on top of you and your character gets stuck.

Read my full review at http://www.ratsplat.com/grav-early-access-preview/

Follow my curator list for future early access game recommendations:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6856568-Should-You-Play-This-Game/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclaimer - I have been gifted a free key for this game for review purposes, however my review will be kept as truthful as possible, since I am meant to help developers and buyers/gamers.

GRAV [8.24]

Beggining
GRAV is a sandbox experience where you explore a multitude of planets, hunt strange alien creatures, build and defend outposts, craft weapons and armor, and attempt to survive against other players in a hostile environment. You can do it in solo play or multiplayer. But remember, there's always danger around you,  so beware of it, try to fight it before you drop dead. Wether it is a player or creature, a gun or melee, turret or not, it can always defeat you. You must become dominant, build your base and upgrade upon it. Creat new armour sets and give them enchants, such as 'Fire' or 'Ice'. Explore new places that are unlike any other game you have or haven't played or even seen before. GRAV is a game which needs you to have power, enough to stay alive. Will you fall to a Yeti? Will you die to a shotgun shot? It's up to you, what will your choice be, adventuerer?

Overview
GRAV is a sanbox where you can explore, build, craft, hunt, attack with your tribe, and hopefully survive. It needs true focus on a populated server, however GRAV has servers that aren't that popular, maybe because of the price tag, or just because people always say don't trust Early Access" or something along the lines of that

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is early access review: The game is awesome. It kept me hooked for 259 hours. Even Fallout 4 didn't manage to do that (90 hours played and never touched it again). And I'm comparing AAA game for early access game. :D

After reaching the end-game (Rank 420) the game kinda dried out for lack of content. But oh boy what fun I had on the way reaching it :) The game community is awesome and I made new friends and I built some stuff and I was astonished by new breed of survival action game. Naturally there are some bugs but luckily I didn't experience major issues.

The reason I'm having a pause from the game is definitely not the community and guys in-game but the game itself. And the reason is simple: When you start a game you need to have goals. When you achieve the goals and there is nothing to do the game kinda dries out. And this happened after reaching the end-game. Meanwhile doing so I have reported some bugs and I hope I have done my part with all the feedback I've given to make this game even more awesome.

But at this point of the development we have to remember that Grav is a living breathing and evolving game. So we need to give some time for developers to make Grav perfect. And I definitely want to see that!

My gaming rig exceeds the recommended system requirements and the game runs smoothly without hiccups. Extremely well optimized for mediocre computers (by the standard of computer part manufacturers).

So yes, I'd recommend the game. I had so much fun with it :) And I'm sure I will have more fun when the game gets new content.

P.S. Who ever did the sound track to Grav is a genious. I love the in-game music.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI got this game as part of the latest Humble Bundle and absolutely love it. It's definately a game that gets better as you invest some time into it. It's a hard recommendation if you prefer games to hold your hand and to point you in the direction you need to go. It's very much an open world dynamically generated survival game. I put about 5 hours into my first play through, completely and easily losing track of the day. It's difficult in a good way and the graphics are solid if a bit underwhelming at times. Some of the enemy AI is questionable but the overall gameplay mechanics this early on in the development show a lot of promise. It's easily worth the initial asking price.

Uninstalling for now, because I don't want break my computer. I'll have to wait for my newer one to get fixed before I play this.

specs using
i7 975x
8G RAM
270AMD
p6td deluxe

Eh nevermind, it's just my videocard dying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well I got about 30 minutes into the game and couldn't go on.
The game has a lot of potential for sure but doesn't justify the $20 price tag.

Here is my reasons:

Pros:
1. Cool graphics.
2. Music is good.
3. Lots of potential.
4. Game menu is easy to navigate.
5. Mobs drop items like Borderlands, which is cool as funk.
6. Solo/Multi/Coop.
7. Runs smooth.

Cons:
1. Game craft progression is way to easy.  (I had a pistol in the first 5 mins)
2. Items drop in a way that is hard to mentally keep track of.
3. Inventory is not very immersive and makes me want to exit the game when I see it.
4. Mouse sensitivity is super sensitive and requires file editing to fix.
5. Blur is default and also requires file editing to turn off.
6. Collecting resources is not at all immersive. (Not a good deal for a game that requires gathering for progression)
7. Auto loot. (See #2)

Final Thought:
I support the concept of GRAV but not at the price of $20. I believe GRAV will be a top notch game but I think their devs need to rethink the price in respect to the paying customer. Terraria is a hit game yet still only charges $10 for a copy. Terraria teaches a lesson that needs to be learned.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first survivor MMO style game done correctly?
If you like WoW/Borderlands/ARK you'd like this game. Can be a tiny bit grindy at times but pays off with intense battles and beautiful planets to explore. Lots of items in game with a quality modular building system. Building system relys on these modular blocks which can be used to quickly build up a base.
Really nice community online (I'm on EU PVE server 7)
Can get buggy at times but dev's are pretty good.
I generally don't like sci-fi games but this really did work for me. definitely worth the price!

8/10

Cons

Overall great game.

So if you like survival or sandbox games this is a must-have.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Cons:

I played this game while it was on the free weekend. I played 3 hours of it to get to level 10. I must say it is a great game to play but it's missing a couple of elements to it. Where are the spaceships? My understanding of going through the construction phase of what you can build is you can build machines, planes, cars, tanks, whatnot. But you jump through portals to get to other planets. Wormholes I understand but portals? The portals lead to other dimensions, of course.

Then when I pushed the button to travel in the portal to the moon. The game got really buggy and crashed on me. :( I'm not too happy about that. So I reloaded the game again and got back in it and it seems like it took forever to load for me to travel to the moon, the second time around.

When I got to the moon, I found out at the loading screen there is 'TIPS' you can read about the game. One of them was you have to build a special oxygen tank or special suit to travel to other worlds. Then when I was on the moon, I only had maybe a minute of air to walk around. Which this building the suit ties into getting 'Element X' and you have to build a machine to mine it. I would be just happy with a pick axe. :) Or the mining gun on my arm to mine it. :) But you have to have all the right material for the machine to build it and mine for you. The mining takes up real world time too. I'm not a fan of real world time.

You have to wait until you are at certain higher levels to build stuff or build buildings. & then you have to research the job that you are wanting to build those buildings for. You can interchange between different professions. :)

The other thing I looked at was the feed for all the bugs that were fixed. :/ Granted this is a beta game right now. But I guess I was hoping for a lot more from the game. My expectations were set high. So from 1 to 10 I give this a 6 rating.

Pros:

When I got into the game the visuals and floral and skys, clouds, sun are beautiful. I'm a total fan of that. Breathtaking in fact.

The concept of the monsters are gorgeous and otherworldly. I kept dying at level 1, while the monsters were level 6. Because that's where I kept spawning was around those monsters. It definitely feels like I want to play more of the game when the bugs are fixed and there is no freezing up or crashes. :/ The concept of the game is to build and loot from the world on different planets and in space on the moons. I love that idea!! :)

The idea to travel to other worlds and visit dungeons but in this case its caves on the planets and see what all is there. Mine with the building machine, if you have all the right components. You can get a mount but in this game it's a circular cycle machine. I forget what they called it in the game. But you have to have wood to keep feeding it and lots of it too. :/

The cycle machine does get me around a lot faster but needs to be improved upon with turning, while you press the A and D keys.

Building your own home is pretty cool as well. As long as  you have the right materials. :)

I would recommend this game to players just starting out with space survival games. It seems like it is perfect for beginners who want to get into the upcoming genre of these games. :) I just wish they would have spaceships to fly to other planets or the moons and then if you run out of air, go back to your spaceship. :) Every game deserves a chance to be played and who knows my opinion would difffer to someone else who enjoys the beta game. :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY REVIEW - TO BE UPDATED

I'm playing this singleplayer only, and after reading through a guide to get my head around the game a bit better, I can safely say there's a great deal of sandbox/gather'n'craft fun to be had here. The game world is jolly attractive, I like the in game music and the mechanics are solid. It feels like a 3D Darkout (minus digging) for me with a greater focus on dungeons, finding loot boxes and hunting blueprints.

Ah, blueprints, something that I could see being a bone of contention amongst many players - to craft an item, you have to have its blueprint. Blueprints drop from enemies, but reasonably reliably drop from boss/named monsters which can be found on the surface, but are better hunted underground. I could see this system feeling a little grindy" to people - blueprints are on a % chance to drop and although some things can be unlocked through research I am unsure if all can be researched.

Caves dot the landscape and the in game compass points you towards them
date: and dungeonrunning for the loot crate + named bosses at the end of each cave is essential
recommended: rewarding and maybe a little frustrating as enemies respawn a little randomly. In addition
hoursPlayed: resource nodes dot the cave that can have extractors built on and defended while they gather the resource for research.\n\nThe game seems to encourage (at least in the beginning) wide range exploration - respawn terminals are cheap
voteText: as are crafting stations
helpfulPercent: so creating little outposts as you explore rather than setting up a primary base is totally viable.\n\nThe "survival" aspect of the game appears to only be a stamina/hunger system alongside "hazardous" environments in some biomes
votesHelpful: and not dying against swarms of enemies. This may or may not be your sort of thing
votesTotal: personally I enjoy the "survival-lite" feel.\n\nMy current objectives are to build a wingsuit and find a way to get to the moon. I'm yet to even encounter artifacts or elemental weapons
votesFunny: or unlock the extra "jobs" you can level up for permanent skills and active abilities
commentsCount: or blueprints for vehicles
column16: or actually start using the base building tools (which other players have made some impressive things with)...\n\nIf you tried the free weekend but raged at griefing
column17: I heartily recommend playing it singleplayer instead. There's plenty of content to get your teeth into and I'll be interested to see where the game heads from here."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Free weekend is coming to an end and I just feel like writing a review! :)

First and mostly of all the game is beautiful! Considering it's in alpha there will probably be lots of detail added... at least i hope so (little butterflys here and there! xD).
The soundtracks are great! Very pleasant and smooth!
The whole idea of exploration on mutiple planets, flying with jetpacks and crossing desets with doom buggys is very appealing.
Comabt also shows lots of promise but definitely need lots of improvement and variety added.
The job system gives a nice replay value to the game as if you are leveling a new character except it's the same one. I like that.

Now as I said before. Combat needs lots of improvement. The AI is not very respondent. Sometimes it feels like the mobs don't care if i'm attacking them. Makes it very easy to kill them overall. As I see it the only danger is the high respawn rate. Especially in caves. Never know when something spawns right behind you. In my opinion mobs should react more aggresivly, dodge attacks and have all kinds of tricks up their sleeve while in the same time spawn rates should be decreased giving us players the time to deal with an encounter.
Now about the weapons. I love shooting things! But once i went from Combat Pistol to The Remodeler i never went back. I just hated to have to click so many times to shoot. I felt like i was back in 90's wishing i had a turbo controller! :D
Also a shield would be dope so i could block shooting attacks in tight cave tunnels.
Something that annoyed me a little was that driving a monocycle there was no used for the A and D buttons. It seemed like they should let me look left and right while driving straight looking for thouse precious big red loot boxes i mean like cmon i opened like 10 and no free key? WTF? <_<

P.S. Almost forgot to mention that there needs to be some sort of way to sell off unneeded items not just storing them or dropping them. What if i want to quit for a month and cant be active at keepeing my house and storage safe. An option to trade items for resorces would come in handy so i could just keep everything in my inventory and log out with no worry on mind. :)

Best of luck to the devs! Good job! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY REVIEW - TO BE UPDATED

I'm playing this singleplayer only, and after reading through a guide to get my head around the game a bit better, I can safely say there's a great deal of sandbox/gather'n'craft fun to be had here. The game world is jolly attractive, I like the in game music and the mechanics are solid. It feels like a 3D Darkout (minus digging) for me with a greater focus on dungeons, finding loot boxes and hunting blueprints.

Ah, blueprints, something that I could see being a bone of contention amongst many players - to craft an item, you have to have its blueprint. Blueprints drop from enemies, but reasonably reliably drop from boss/named monsters which can be found on the surface, but are better hunted underground. I could see this system feeling a little grindy" to people - blueprints are on a % chance to drop and although some things can be unlocked through research I am unsure if all can be researched.

Caves dot the landscape and the in game compass points you towards them
date: and dungeonrunning for the loot crate + named bosses at the end of each cave is essential
recommended: rewarding and maybe a little frustrating as enemies respawn a little randomly. In addition
hoursPlayed: resource nodes dot the cave that can have extractors built on and defended while they gather the resource for research.\n\nThe game seems to encourage (at least in the beginning) wide range exploration - respawn terminals are cheap
voteText: as are crafting stations
helpfulPercent: so creating little outposts as you explore rather than setting up a primary base is totally viable.\n\nThe "survival" aspect of the game appears to only be a stamina/hunger system alongside "hazardous" environments in some biomes
votesHelpful: and not dying against swarms of enemies. This may or may not be your sort of thing
votesTotal: personally I enjoy the "survival-lite" feel.\n\nMy current objectives are to build a wingsuit and find a way to get to the moon. I'm yet to even encounter artifacts or elemental weapons
votesFunny: or unlock the extra "jobs" you can level up for permanent skills and active abilities
commentsCount: or blueprints for vehicles
column16: or actually start using the base building tools (which other players have made some impressive things with)...\n\nIf you tried the free weekend but raged at griefing
column17: I heartily recommend playing it singleplayer instead. There's plenty of content to get your teeth into and I'll be interested to see where the game heads from here."
column19: true

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome.  Feels like a good combination of features from Rust, Planet Explorers, and a little DayZ.

The enemy killing is great.  The building is well implemented.  The grinding for materials/blueprints is a little rough, but it's early stages.

With that being said, don't buy this if you have less than 16GB of RAM.  The client itself can eat up to 8GB on it's own, and it eats your CPU as well.

I'm sure these are issues that can be ironed out during the alpha and beta phases, but for now, it's a huge resource hog.

HOWEVER, on it's value as a game, it's very fun and has serious potential to be a good sandbox survival game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

FREE WEEKEND REVIEW
Grav is my first approach to the MMO version of/open world/survival/sandbox genre so my words are from someone who can't comparate it with anything.

First of all, let me say I'm recommending it just because it's on Alpha, so much can luckily change in better, otherwise the cons would be unacceptable ever for a Beta.

The initial impact is huge: vast open spaces and you, little in the enviroment, it's a really nice effect. Game mechanics are the basics, gather resources, find blueprints to build stuff, ultimately build stuff, get better, go on.

Initial tutorial covers the most basic bases, while unfortunately leaves some pretty crucial things, like the fact that every building you build decays over 1 day real time initially, so if you log out after building a nice looking house or a big coumpound you returt 2 days later to find... Nothing, and is something I find extremely annoying, it may be the norm in this kind of MMOs, but as I said above, I don't know. You can ultimately prevent this process by finding a blueprint that allows you to build a shield, but let's talk about blueprints now.

Blueprints are the basics to get better and aquire new building and equipment, but to obtain'em you have to grind mob, which can be a frustrating stuff, since normal mob have an extremely low chances to drop a blueprints while bosses have around 80% chance to drop, but once you start collecting blueprints, if a boss drops a project you already have you simply gain nothig, making it more luck better than anything else later on.

That being said, there's much to explore. Worlds are huge and you can traver within and beyond'em, even go on moons, using stellar gates to get to other planets. There are diffrent biomes to explore and many things to see and diffrent resources to gather, the problem is that you have to run for looooong distances, there are however, some vehicles you can buy at verdors for ridicolously high prices or build'em using blueprints... and yes... see above, so you either are lucky to find a vehicle blueprints or nothing.

Last thing is... well, griefers. I know, I know, since is a MMO you must expect to deal with human natural ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ry, but even in PvE servers you can very well find people who just destroy your stuff because probably they're having the best time in their life doing so, and you can do nothing because it's a PvE. You can repel it by building certain defensive systems an by being careful where you place stuff, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ son...

I really hope this grief problem are just a free weekend thing because honesly, if you spend money to put down people your life must be very miserable.

And that's just about Grav for now, worth the current price and acceptable due to the Alpha state

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After +30h on the record it's time to change my original rewiev:

Pros:
+ High quality graphics
+ Intresting Aliens and Enemies
+ Different types of Biomes (Beach, Highlands, Forrests, Dungeons)
+ Oh did I mention you can dance infront of a campfire? YES YOU CAN!
+ Trees regrow and other ressources spawn every 2 ingame days.
+ Interactive structures you build can be locked by you so no one else can use them.
+ If you die you don't lose crafting items you gathered. You still lose your weapons, armor, stims and ressources tho.
+ If you die you got a 60 minutes lock on your stuff so no one else can pick it up.
+ Non-hostile aliens. Now go play with your alien and have fun.
+ Mines to explore. Also Becons for marking special locations.
+ Let the Flareguns SPAM the message!
+ Different types of weapons: Club, Sword, Elemental Butter Knifes, Shotguns, AR and more.

Cons:
- If not on a stable server, this game will lag most time.
- If you go on a server for the first time you need to download this server first. Thus you need to wait 5-10 mins to play on it.
- Even on good computers (like mine) the game plays a bit clunky.
- You can only destroy your STRUCTURES by shooting them. Structure removal tool or something would be nice.
- Health regen is slower than my grandma!
- Even the weakest enemy targets you. Making enemies annoying even if you're a high level player.

+30h Note:
The game is as you see still in development but the devs, damn this DEVS are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome, work on it every day. I've never seen a game with such active developers. Give the game time and it becomes a RUST in SPAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE! sry.
Oh did I mention you can do the Gangnam Style? No. But you can.

I know it is still in alpha and I know the devs working on stuff. I won't blame their game, nor do I stop playing it. It has unbelievable high potentional. And for 15€/$ it is worth every little bit. If you're not a fan of begin with nothing getting better very slow and be awesome after some days" than this is not your game. If you like building your base and gather stuff than buy it.

My score: 9.5/10

- Brecken"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am messing around in-game.. and I notice a lot of lag and very few graphics options. My PC met the recommended specifications but I am still experiencing very low Frame-Rates if I turn all of the lighting and shadows on.  Obviously I do not have much time into the game but I will post an updated review once I get a good 20+ hours into it... I was really looking forward to that lighting.

The game itself is very enjoyable so far.. I met a few random people and we made a base together, found another random who then attacked us for no reason (Which was very entertaining) The crafting system is easy to use, once you have the blueprints you need.(which drop from enemies or lootcrates) Leveling up takes some time, but I'm only saying that because I spent more time collecting materials then I did killing enemies. The ability to hop into a world and have nothing but a mining  tool and a knife, being able to meet random players and explore the large environments made this game worth it. Once I joined an empty server I was able to turn on Post Processing without the intense amount of lag and the game looks beautiful.(running in 1080p with all of the lighting/shadows/post proscessing Enabled) I recommend this game and I'll keep updating this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SLG's First 10-hrs. Review
---The Short 10-hrs. Review---

PROS

+ Amazing visuals through use of the Unreal 3 engine
+ Large, open-world concept with many biomes to explore
+ Controls are fairly decent for an Early Access game
+ Crafting system is very thought-out and well-built for an Early Access game

CONS

- GRAV is very laggy even with a good connection and low ping
- Some environments are 'broken' and players/enemies fall through
- Mining for resources is very time consuming
- Player progression is slow

OVERALL

+ Score: 8/10

---The Long 10-hrs. Review---


Premise

What is GRAV? GRAV is a unique sci-fi Craftbuilder/Survival MMO allowing players to build bases, tools, and vehicles in order to aid them in their exploration and survival of the planet they are residing in. GRAV has no classes, no real currency, and no ranks, making every player equal in their ability to mine for resources and hunt monsters.

Visuals

GRAV is built on the Unreal 3 engine which makes it a perfect candidate for stunning visuals on a large, open-world game such as this one. The planet is large, and contains many different biomes such as a bright blue wooded area with colorful red and green leaves, or a sandy beach with large, rocky mountains. Caves are dark and narrow with many faultlines inside, and the sky is filled with clouds and distant planets staring us down. As the day leaves and nightfall arrives, the terrain becomes hardly visible except for a few monsters that glow in the dark. The Unreal 3 engine really does a fantastic job of portraying a real planet with its night and day sequences and GRAV really shines in this respect.

Crafting

Unfortunately, GRAV struggles a bit with the crafting system. Yes, there are many amazing things a player can craft in this game, however, the resources required to craft anything other than a campfire or Uplink (respawn point) is a bit outrageous and will require several hours of mining in order to acquire a decent amount of resources. In the ten hours of playtime on GRAV, I have spent at least seven of those hours wandering this vast planet exploring caves and mountains in search of enough ore and gem deposit to build a simple 4-bedroom base to call my home on this planet. Once crafted, there is also the risk of a monster or even another player coming up to your newly built home and bashing it into nothing but resources for them to take. So, while the amount of things one can craft is vast, the tedious mining for resources can be a big negative for those not looking to spend ~70% of their playtime roaming the planet in search of gems, ore, and wood.

Gameplay

For an Early Access game, the controls are fairly responsive. When engaged in combat or mining, GRAV features a non-targetting combat system similar to Dragon's Nest or GunZ: The Duel in which the player must click on the object in order to perform the action. This is a very good thing when fighting multiple targets in the open or a cave, as it lets the player run freely around the enemy and attack simultaneously. At times however, the hit detection is off a bit, possibly due to lag issues or when the player or enemy encounters certain environmental obstacles such as a tree or a mountain. In some areas, a player may even fall through the map or get stuck in a continuous jump if they approach a mountain at the wrong angle. Still, for an Early Access game, the controls are solid.

Overall

GRAV is fairly new and is still in its pre-Alpha phase, but it does show true potential to be a contender for a fairly fun game in the coming years. Thanks to the Unreal 3 engine and the artists, the game is visually impressive with a large, open-world planet to explore and beautifully rendered monsters and textures. The controls are fairly responsive and decent enough to not have an awkward hand position while playing, and the non-targetting combat system works very well for this type of game. Unfortunately, GRAV can be quite tedious in the hunt for resources, but it makes up for the hours spent mining by allowing you to create large bases and craft better tools to aid you in further resource mining or combat. The lag issues are becoming less frequent with the new patch, but it's still an issue when playing for more than a few hours as it will often get you killed or simply prevent you from exploring the planet.

With that said, I would still recommend this game for anyone looking to try out a sci-fi craftbuilding MMO in Early Access. Unlike other games, the development team is actively releasing patches and the community, while small, is very helpful to newbies.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend GRAV, it is a giant open sandbox to PvE and PvP in!  For one its all about the crafting and collecting resources to build in. I mean its gonna take a while to get things, but that's what makes the game fun.  I have read that the crafting takes forever, I would have to strongly disagree with that. You may not get things instantly in your inventory, but you can farm enough material for a set of gear in 20-30 mins which is very reasonable.

The Bases are just amazing in this game.  You get to create a defence and your own way of how you want your base, well also you will need blueprints(bps) to even make the items. Speaking of bps, once you start collecting them you can make some really cool gear. When starting out you can create an armory to build your gear. Then there's a factory you can build so you can create your vehicles such as a monocycle which is really fun to ride and even a jetpack.

Then there is PvP, i dont mind it actually because you can kill people to get blueprints which have an essence of PlayerSoul, and that increases weapon dmg and increases armor reduction for pvp. Gear is a vital part for PvP.  But like all other things, it isn't too hard to farm and craft. I craft sets all the time for my brother and friends.

I enjoy PvP, but PvE is great too because you will never have to worry about getting ganked. The only problem about PvE for me is the griefers that destroy your base(s).  Although this can get annoying, it can also bring about a challenge within the PvE environment similar to PvP, base defense!  So rather than combating a person, you could build shield generators that protect your base since you cant kill them. In PvP you can alsso add a strong defensive weapons system to kill enemy griefers!

Grav also has a class like system called job that maxes out at level 60 while your character rank maxes out at 300. The jobs let you kill things your current job lvl or less, but be warned, try to kill higher job lvls and your dmg output is reduced significantly.

Something new to the game are tanks! They look alien with electricity underneath and anything you hit with it explodes and does a ton of DMG.  They sit two people inside which is nice.

I really recommend this game! It's a great price for a good indie game with so much potential for an alpha.  The developers (DEVS) are doing great to this game so far and you will see them in game often. This is why I enjoy and continue to play this game, I hope you take the time to give it a try!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun. It has good music. It has good visuals. You can run your own dedicated server and have a private sandbox. There are some bugs but it is in Early Access. If you like the style of the game you will be happy for 150+ hours.

It is Player vs. Player by default. There are Player vs. Enemy servers where you can't kill other players but they can still destroy your stuff provided you don't have a shield with an active generator. PVP is where it's at for me. If you don't want any of that there is also a solo mode.

You can easily be lulled into a sense of serenity with the music and peaceful nature of gathering resources and building structures. This makes it all the more interesting when encountering other players because you don't know what will happen. They may be nice and give you tips on building or they might kill you and take all of your gathered resources. It is all up to the individual player. We can be ruthless or we can dance around a fire (which will give you health and stamina). Getting killed sucks (duh) but you are largely on the same playing field with other players (unlike the enemies). They can loot your dropped items but you will always keep your slotted items (including weapons).

I look forward to more GRAV content from Bitmonster.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I should say at first, you should better buy this on a sale, unless you feel you want to help the developers more, which is a good thing.

GRAV combines elements of MMOs and survival/crafting, wrapping them in worlds of wonderful design and fine interaction mechanisms between players, but being an early access game there's a lot of crudeness around, which if you're willing to overlook, you can find this game enjoyable, as I do.

By the way, no, there is no map, there's only grid coordinates and a compass with icons. If you need to find another player, the player has to use a flare and you have to go looking for her. I find this great, it adds a weird aspect of realism in the game.

It has had its ups and downs (server problems etc.) and it can get very heavy if some users have built enormous structures around (which take too much time to load), but I still enjoy the experience. After a while it can get grindy though.

I really want to see what the future holds for this game. Because of some of the (hopefully temporary) omissions and issues, I'm not sure if I should actually recommend it at this time, but judging from my personal experience, I have to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to write a review on this game because I do believe that this game could have lots of potential. With what I would like to share some of my opinions on the game.

When I played like for the first 2 hours of the game I was just killing things, getting killed, and getting resources that i thought I needed. When I got some friends to play with me, it went a little faster, getting a base up (wood) then going to the moon and eventually having cool plasma armor.
So far it was fun, had some run ins with the game not wanting to load the map and or damage was not being dealt.

Ok so I left the game for a month and came back to one new update ( did not really see a difference) But was playing with even more friend and did more things than just go to the moon a get plasa armor, and as of right now we almost are the highest rank that you can possibly be on the game and have everything that we need for a long time. But that does not take away the fact that we love going into caves and fighting bosses and fighting our way through a dungeon.

I get why it may be boring and i know that it is early access, But that does not take away the true work behind it. there are problems with the game that I hate and really wish was fixed like vehicle go under the ground in some parts of the map or base building items don't really do what you want it to. It is a big grinding game, which is the whole point of it. You don't have to have a story or missions to make a game good or in this case, progressive improvement. I don’t want players to leave the game because of hackers or Bugs or random things that get over dramatized out for. although there could be some big improvements to the game that I would like to see in the next few monthly updates are ( bug fixes,more vehicles,variety of enemies, and base building items) to list a few.

We all want something from this game and i think that they want to work on it as much as they can but it may take time, and time is what this game has.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 91 hours and playing this game since almost the beginning, there is a lot to say:

To start off, this game has progressed tremendously from where it started and all for the better. It has a great group of creators that are keen to listen to the comments and concerns of those playing and testing it. Very thorough and detailed patch notes are also a personal favorite of mine. The game is ever expanding and every time I log back in after a week break something is new. Not to mention the learning curve is relatively easy compared to most open world builders out there.

However I will say it is not ideal if you love base building. The objective seems to kill, collect, build, level up, then move. This makes base building for that perfect stronghold kind of moot. Not to mention if you do not log in every day you are likely to come back with your base just destroyed as if it were never there, either by other players or random AI's.

All in all, great game, havent regretted the purchase
