reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this during the Humble Bundle End of Summer Sale, thinking that I could finally satisfy this bad Sandbox itch I've been trying to scratch ever since I burnt out on Minecraft.

Suffice to say, that search continues on.

Now everyone is aware that the game is still in Early Access, but I feel that EA Games should not have a free pass to being crap and this is, in one of those cases.

The game drops you in a random world generated, with nothing more than a Multitool and other things. It puts you through a very rudimentary Tutorial on how to build three different Workbenches in order to craft your starting gear(some of this gear is once you make it, it's permanently yours).

After the very brief tutorial, the game throws you out into the harsh enviroment of whatever world you're currently stuck in and not only lets go of your hand, but slaps it away as if you're supposed to strike it out on your own.

So you wander aimlessly around, harvesting stuff from trees and rocks and other various little things as you explore the world. Blueprints to other items can drop from Monsters that wander around aimlessly, but this is slightly rare for it to happen.

There's also Caves, or Dungeons, that let you raid either with a friend or by yourself if you ever fancy yourself giving it a shot but dont expect rousing boss battles.

You can also take a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ on the ground. I don't really understand why I need to take a ♥♥♥♥ on the ground, but I guess it's funny?

There's random NPCs that pop in and out of existence if you're ever in Solo Play that just wave their arms at you and go fade into the rock wall like David Copperfield.

So what EXACTLY am I supposed to do? Traipse around, collecting resources, beat the everliving ♥♥♥♥ out of Bugdogs for their sweet, succulent Hearts? The game is literally begging you to be EXPLORED and taken by the reins, but it feels so  bland, and so boring, that there's nothing to do except Mine resources.

GRAV is a very sandboxy Action RPG Crafting game, but it's vastness and complete lack of anything WORTHWHILE to do could spell it's doom.

VERDICT:  WAIT

After playing Grav for about 3 hours last night I found that this game is indeed what the videos have been showing plus more. For a Alpha build it is doing quite well especially for at least on my end most of the objects work and function like they are supposed to. Creatures give the game a new meaning which thankfully drops the PvP in the game quite drastically and allows for a rich experience to play with others, which was not seen in Rust. The graphics and detail in the game is stunning allowing for a rich experience without paying the $60 price of a higher up game.

Overall I am looking forward to this developing in its building and crafting along with fixing some of the lag issues. But for my beginning experience into the game it has been relatively smooth. This game has great potential. I mean you can dance around a fire and get health with some techno/dub in the background ;)

GRAV is shaping up to be a fantastic game! Ten Outta Ten.

It is still quite new but offers quite a lot. It is an action survival MMO with resource gathering, monster farming, and player interaction. I feel PVP offers a lot more in this game as it adds a benefit to working with others and a concern when approaching an unfamiliar face. When you die you drop most of your items (can be reduced later) but they are unable to be looted for a whole hour (which can be extended, later) so this means you won't lose all of your work when you die and will have a good chance to regain it. Additionally, the crafting recipes you learn are bound to your character.

After 16 hours I have not experienced any game breaking bugs and have suffered only 1 game freeze that decided to eat through 180 assault rifle bullets... I'm sure SAO had its bugs early on. :}

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the game description, trailers and other reviews i have expected an intersting Survival / Exploration Game with fast paced Combat and rich atmospheric Graphics. If you expect the same, then this review might be a help for your buying decision.

Note: I have revised this review, after digging deeper into the game and finally it has convinced me to recommend it.

Gameworld / Environment

It's an open-world with no limitations in the player movement other than the boundaries of the map. Flying rocks can be reached with rocketpacks and are fully functional (eg. for base building). The procedurally generated terrain looks nice, but after some time you have seen all variations and it just repeats over and over. There is a day and nightcycle and a rudimentary weathersystem (does not effect the gamemechanics). The dungeons are crappy and monotonous. Soundeffect and music are okey, but could be better. There are only a few different creature models varying only in color and size. Boss- or elite-mobs are just bigger variants of their normal counterparts. The NPC AI is limited to the minimum (hostile, friendly, aggro, non-aggro).

Gameplay

The gameplay is best described as third-person shooter, with crafting elements, in an open-world sandbox scenario. Combat is fast and action driven. Atm there are only a few special moves like dodging or an alternative special melee attack. With higher level you can craft rocketpacks, wings and a bike-like monocycle - all with reasonable high movement speed. The vehicles are a big fun factor in the game.

You have to grind a lot to get resources, but with higher level it gets easier. Leveling your character is kind of the same as in other mmo's. There are level zones and you move on to higher zones with better resources, grind, level up, get better gear and so on... Between that, you can build your base. The cubic base modules do not add much visual variety, but there is a wide spectrum of different base enhencements, that offer interesting functionalities like shields, auto-turrets or jumppads. By building stargates you can explore more planets and moons, adding a nice exploration experience.

There are world-events every 7-8 days (ingame-time). Actually the only event type happening, are extra mob spawns near your location in your level range.

There are no mentionable survival mechanics atm and the atmosphere of the game does not fit to the survival genre. To give an example: You have to dance at fire to recover health. When you do that, some kind of techno like music starts to torture you (or me). You have to disable (all) Music to get around this annoying effect.

Singleplayer Mode

SP is actually realized by a One-Click" Local Server. That means: server and client run on one pc - that needs resources - specifically alot of RAM (take a look at the recommended specs in the description). Also you cannot pause the game
date:
you cannot save / load a game and you cannot have multiple gamesessions at once easily. To start all over you need to delete the server files. This all will get better with ongoing development.

PVP

I haven't tested pvp so far
recommended: because it is too time expansive for me. From what i have heard it seems a little bit unbalanced. There is no lvl protection (low vs high level). Games with a high grinding factor to get gear or build things are known to be problematic in pvp. Open pvp servers are most likely not much fun for players
hoursPlayed:
not willing to invest lots of time. But it might be fun to host or join a private server for Teamfights with home-brewed bases.

Development progress

Beside minor issues (unpolished UI
voteText: buggy base-building)
helpfulPercent: the game is well developed and fully playable with no game-breaking bugs. There is enough content for a long playtime. Updates are coming in frequently with new content
votesHelpful:
balancing and bug-fixes.

Check the Trello board of the game to get an idea of the direction the development takes:

Development Roadmap for GRAV (Trello Board)[trello.com]"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well i bought it, 19EUR... I don't feel bad spending the money at all. For a 6-month old project it's already pretty solid. The graphics and the atmosphere overall are simply beautiful. New updates including new items like vehicles, armor and weapon sets are pushed every week by the devs. The community is mostly mature. Some sort of grief prevention is already in the game and there are a dozen of new servers coming out every day... It feels like a mix of starbound in 3D and Borderlands. Hell, there are even NPCs that look like Clap Trap!
Gameplay is a bit laggy on a full 32/32 server but tweaks to lag reduction are in every patch and latest patch already removed like 70% of the lag.
Mob movement seems a bit laggy for now but as i said, i play on a full server and that might cause it. Gameplay consists of grinding dungeons for armor, weapons or buildings blueprints, materials and exp. There are world events where u can level your character pretty good. You can build bases, mob traps for item drops and soon you can travel to the planet's moons or even other planets.

You see, there is alot to discover in the world of GRAV.
You wonder if you should give it a try or not? I'd say do it! On the other hand keep in mind it is EARLY ALPHA and things will change. It feels unfinished but maybe in 1-2 months it will be different. Mobs are pretty much the same, there are like 6 mobtypes in about 4x4 elemental types. There will be more soon i guess... PVP is crap, people can log off, there is a 1h cooldown to pick somebodies backpack drop and in that time they can always pick it themselves up so a PVE server would be the best option. Weapons consist of different types of swords, assault rifles, pistols, shotguns (my favourite :D), soon to come rocket launchers, light sabers etc. Go to twitch and search for a stream, watch it and make yourself an opinion on the game before your buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV looked really good before I bought it, but turned into a mess on first load. Second time around it worked fine. No idea why, but why would I care as long as it works?

So far, GRAV has incredible environments ingame, and I have barely scratched the surface. The controls are easy to learn and I am addicted to jumping in this game. It is just cool.

As for bugs, the most major one was the game launching the first time created a process that couldn't be shut down and prevented my computer from shutting down normally (off buttons are great).

Pros:
+Fun gameplay (just started, so don't know how grindy it really is)
+Epic environment
+Jumping is awesome

Cons:
-Game's community seems to have thinned alot, but I just got the game so I don't know.
-Creepy NPCs that feel the need to wave at you as they walk by.
-Outdated support info and missing support info. The wiki and forums are a bit lacking in help for topics that aren't spread to basically everyone, so solving issues can take you on quite the journey. Also, I don't think the devs have posted in the forums recently since they announced the big update (as seen on store page), so getting help from them would be unlikely.

I give the game a 8/10. So far a very good game compared to a few other EA games I have tried.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello to whoever reads this!

GRAV, is a big game. It is a bit hard to learn. There is not really much usefull explenations on their wiki. Wich is really needed for new players. Though it is easy to learn how the game works. You can jump, run, dance, hit etc. That is the easy part. You gather wood and start to build. It is a really easy process to build the first stuff. You then have a house with a door, some rooms and some windows. What now? Most pepole would not know what to do then. Basicly you kill monsters to get blueprints, (they drop) you find dungeons with a decent level for you. Kill, get loot and blueprints for new stuff.
The way you should play the game is that you make a gun and combat knife from the amory. Maybe even some armor if you want to. Then find monsters and kill them. Gather lots of stuff. Even get some of the nice blueprints, like storage box, forcefield door, generator, you would also like to have something so that youre base wont decay.

Basicly there is alot to the game. You learn something new all the time. It's a really big game and there is so much stuff to explore and get.

I def. recommend this game. The game is still in alpha, so keep that in mind!
This is a survival ♥♥♥♥♥♥me. But the mmo is actually good, so it does not really get too boring, and does not really take long to level up!

Hope someone could use this review!
Peace!

Cons:
General Conscious of the community - Shoot first, Loot and run.. screw questions

PVP Servers are the only way to go, but people are ♥♥♥ Hats in general that you have to go far off the beaten path to progress well in the game.
World has some Glitches where mobs will spawn inside rocks and still hit you while you can't hit them.

I love the game, don't get me wrong. Once more development is put into the game, some of the kinks and balancing is done it will be a game worth playing and rival No Man's Sky easily enough. But I suggest buying the game on Sale instead of full price for the Early Access, full price for this game isn't justified.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is absolutely gorgeous. It is the game I've been waiting for. Sure, it is in early access, but that is not a reason not to support the developers, they are very active and they do provide when demanded to do a hotfix. Trust me , I've tried a great deal of early access games and most of them were ♥♥♥♥, sure some were good , but this one, takes the trophy for the best early access game ever. I've spent hours in the game, having fun, killing monsters, building, exploring. It is indeed a little bit grindy, and TRUST ME when I'm telling you, I absolutely despise grinding, but I actually had fun killing the same things in this game, maybe it is because I finished it for the first time and didn't have any spoilers , but needless to say, I had fun grinding. The building system is pretty shabby now, but they said they are working on it, and they recently uptaded it so it is all good. For Christ's sake guys, the game has a MIB 3 like vehicle, a jetpack, they promised a hover bike/hover board, a plasma shield. Simply amazing. The game is pretty laggy because it is still in early access but I have high hopes for the optimization, it is running on Unreal Engine after all. Buy this game guys, you will sink 20 to 30 hours in it and you will finish it eventually but then you will be so eager for the next BIG UPDATE, or you can just do like me and wait maybe 3-4 months so you can log in and find A LOT of new stuff ingame. Please people, keep this game alive, it deserves a lot more hype than it got so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, this may depend, and hopefully this will help you decide.

Pros-

-The graphics are very pleasant and I think there honestly very solid and for the final game.

-The mechanics are quite nice, with the ability to build forts which monsters will attack from time to time, and craft weapons and  gear, as well as swap between melee and ranged weapons,mine resources, they hold up well for an early access game foundation.

-The game shines beyond all else in its random generation, with varying worlds that are never the same and give everyone a different experience, and the dungeons which just compliment the game so well, as they are also procedurally generated, which makes amazing high risk, high reward, and the ability to go into higher level dungeons and perhaps sneak through and get to the treasure trove of rare minerals is a very rewarding and nice experience.

Cons-

-One of the only problems I have with this game can pretty much be excused by the fact that its early access, and they will probably change, is the system requirements , which are a little over the top, and with no options to change the settings down or up (Something I truly believe they should implement.) it is a quite annoying.

-There are the obvious early access bugs, but hey, all early access games have them, and they are being patched.


Overall, this blend of subnuatica and starbound is very quirky and addictive, but a there are few early access bugs that bog it down a bit.I would recommend this game if just to wait for the full version to come out, as the devs are active, and  the concept and execution is a great foundation for the content the developers keep churning out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got this game from a friend for Christmas and my first impressions of this game is basically Minecraft + World of Warcraft  + Space Marines had a three way and a baby was born named 'Grav'. Within the first 2 minutes of the game I was killed three times by PvP'ers farming Newb Loot.

Pros :
Awesome Expansive Worlds
Wide Variety of Mobs
Dungeons
Co-Op
Huge Crafting List and BluePrint System is fairly Intriguing

Cons:
General Conscious of the community - Shoot first, Loot and run.. screw questions
PVE Servers are full of trolls that can destroy what you have and you can do nothing to prevent it.
PVP Servers are the only way to go, but people are ♥♥♥ Hats in general that you have to go far off the beaten path to progress well in the game.
World has some Glitches where mobs will spawn inside rocks and still hit you while you can't hit them.

I love the game, don't get me wrong. Once more development is put into the game, some of the kinks and balancing is done it will be a game worth playing and rival No Man's Sky easily enough. But I suggest buying the game on Sale instead of full price for the Early Access, full price for this game isn't justified.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I did really not want to buy this, mostly because I do not play well with others beeing the antisocial individual I am and secondly the early access thing, been disapointed way too many times before trying that. But the came kept showing up in the games you might like section and i somehow really loved the visuals so i bought it.

I have played it for 25 hrs. and it´s been 25 hours of grinding, exploring, building and looting and loving it. Sure there are bugs it´s early access so of course there are bugs, but it´s really playable and really enjoyable.

The graphics were what first drew me to the game, and they are bright colorfull and the animations for the main character are wonderfull, i cannot help but greeting back every time one of the NPCs greet me or do some dance moves to the backdrop of a rising moon. The wildlife in the game is not that varied, but i´m sure that will change over time, the day/night cycle suits the game, and different creatures come out at night and they are usually tougher and more aggressive. The different planets could look more different though,  for now it seems the only thing different is the colors used and some of the plant life.

The base building is really easy and really inituative and you can make some empressive looking structures, I hope that there in time wil be more ways to make your building stand out though, but again early access. Crafting is fun, you earn blueprints by killing creatures, and different creatures drop different building materials, these you have to combine with refined forms of wood, fossile, gem or ore. Crafted my first armor of refined wood, the ugliest looking armor i´ve ever seen, the helmet being a hollowed out piece of log, with holes cut out for eyes and mouth there´s even a little branche sticking out, love it, really funny stuff.

The bad is the way servers work right now, it really is difficult making your own server since you have to mess around with text files and the command interface, you of course can use one of the many servers allready being there, but twice i experienced these servers gotten closed down, and all my progress lost(I really miss my monocycle.. sigh!!) So i promised myself not to play the game until these things get fixed and making your own server gets easier. But if you do not mind that I really give GRAV the thumbs up, and it seems the company behind it works hard to implement new features and best of all, they seem to listen to the ones playing the game.

For my self i can only say, i´ll be back and if the publishers keeps it up, This really will be a great game.

Well, this may depend, and hopefully this will help you decide.

Pros-

-The mechanics are quite nice, with the ability to build forts which monsters will attack from time to time, and craft weapons and  gear, as well as swap between melee and ranged weapons,mine resources, they hold up well for an early access game foundation.

-The game shines beyond all else in its random generation, with varying worlds that are never the same and give everyone a different experience, and the dungeons which just compliment the game so well, as they are also procedurally generated, which makes amazing high risk, high reward, and the ability to go into higher level dungeons and perhaps sneak through and get to the treasure trove of rare minerals is a very rewarding and nice experience.

Cons-

Overall, this blend of subnuatica and starbound is very quirky and addictive, but a there are few early access bugs that bog it down a bit.I would recommend this game if just to wait for the full version to come out, as the devs are active, and  the concept and execution is a great foundation for the content the developers keep churning out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV looked really good before I bought it, but turned into a mess on first load. Second time around it worked fine. No idea why, but why would I care as long as it works?

So far, GRAV has incredible environments ingame, and I have barely scratched the surface. The controls are easy to learn and I am addicted to jumping in this game. It is just cool.

As for bugs, the most major one was the game launching the first time created a process that couldn't be shut down and prevented my computer from shutting down normally (off buttons are great).

Pros:
+Fun gameplay (just started, so don't know how grindy it really is)
+Epic environment
+Jumping is awesome

Cons:
-Game's community seems to have thinned alot, but I just got the game so I don't know.
-Creepy NPCs that feel the need to wave at you as they walk by.
-Outdated support info and missing support info. The wiki and forums are a bit lacking in help for topics that aren't spread to basically everyone, so solving issues can take you on quite the journey. Also, I don't think the devs have posted in the forums recently since they announced the big update (as seen on store page), so getting help from them would be unlikely.

I give the game a 8/10. So far a very good game compared to a few other EA games I have tried.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

only 5 hours into playing so far, as someone with plenty of experience with other games similar like minecraft, ARK: Survival Evolved, and Rust, I can safely say this is one of my favorites of the 3 with minecraft second. I really enjoy the atmosphere of these alien worlds with alien creatures and futuristic tech and silly rotted wood armor to start with. I see a lot of complaints on grinding and being griefed but if you ever find this issue and want to avoid it but still play multiplayer, seriously put in some time searching for a PVE dedicated server, it makes a world of difference in your experience and the best part is that I have neighbors now across the river where I built my base.

And to piggyback onto everyone on the grinding, its really not so bad, trees cut down so easy and quickly as you level and the funest part is killing the monsters, especially when exploring at night and you have to set up a camp fire to last the night and fight off hoards of giant bird chocobos.

Out of all the early access games i've played this is the best one yet with minimal issues.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello to whoever reads this!

GRAV, is a big game. It is a bit hard to learn. There is not really much usefull explenations on their wiki. Wich is really needed for new players. Though it is easy to learn how the game works. You can jump, run, dance, hit etc. That is the easy part. You gather wood and start to build. It is a really easy process to build the first stuff. You then have a house with a door, some rooms and some windows. What now? Most pepole would not know what to do then. Basicly you kill monsters to get blueprints, (they drop) you find dungeons with a decent level for you. Kill, get loot and blueprints for new stuff.
The way you should play the game is that you make a gun and combat knife from the amory. Maybe even some armor if you want to. Then find monsters and kill them. Gather lots of stuff. Even get some of the nice blueprints, like storage box, forcefield door, generator, you would also like to have something so that youre base wont decay.

Basicly there is alot to the game. You learn something new all the time. It's a really big game and there is so much stuff to explore and get.

I def. recommend this game. The game is still in alpha, so keep that in mind!
This is a survival ♥♥♥♥♥♥me. But the mmo is actually good, so it does not really get too boring, and does not really take long to level up!

Hope someone could use this review!
Peace!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello Fellow Gamers!
I'm kinda ashed to admit this but in the short amount of time I've owned Reborn and hours spent playing... well lets just say I'm seeing kinda crossed and at times typing stuff backwords. xD

Yes I've had so much fun on this game and yet in all the hours spent online I still don't even think I scrtched the surface, and this is an early access game!

My Pros:
Action: At times it kinda seems fast pase but at same time is very relaxing kinda casual action game but will lots of action anything you do in this game since completing moon has enemys almost constantly coming after you. If you like to shoot a lot or if your very good at dodging and like to use sword and just go ham then you'll like this game. When it comes to shooting I think the enemys could possibly have a longer sight when getting shot from a distance, maybe even code it in so that when damaged by you they come at you instead of just standing there till you get close enough but I guess that is combated with no xp if you to far away.

Still I've been having lots of fun with game so much so that I created my own public unoffical PvE server. (Might change to PvP in future but currently just want my server as a noob friendly get used to the game type of thing)
Last little thing I'm going to say about action is that everything you kill has a chance to drop blueprints which as you guessed is used to do all the crafting. Not going to be going into great detail about it since I want to to figure most out yourself.

Crafting: I like it, go around the world collecting resources and use them to craft most if not everything in the game if you've of course have found the blueprint for it.

Building: kinda reminds me of old rust but with its own twist. Kinda have to play around with the rooms and figure out how to build your floor plan. If you don't know what your doing could get complicated if you are trying to build something big with lots of halls and seperate rooms (I could just be a noob though :D )

Cons: So far have run into bugs bugs bugs but this is Early Access so what ya expect? :P

Not going to spoil anything else, just buy the game already and join my server! <3

SteamServerList: grav.gamingpastmidnight.com:27059      (Will be changing in the future)

Game Press Tab: open grav.gamingpastmidnight.com:7825

If you can't connect to server please contact: http://steamcommunity.com/id/MidnightDusk/
So he can get it in working order again!
One of the current Grav server bugs is causing it to crash. This will be fixed in the future(I hope)

Server is currently only a 20 Slot and PvE with Vanilla settings.
Noob friendly will answer any questions if online and around.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I got hooked on this survival game really quickly.  It looks great, is pretty easy to get into, will take a long time to max out and doesn't require zombies to keep you challenged and entertained.  You can play on your own world, or do multiplayer with either PVE (Player Vs Environment) where you can't kill other players (but you can steal some of their stuff), or PVP (Player vs Player) where you have to build up defenses to stay alive.

It's Early Release, so needs some polishing (yet does not have a Beta feel to it). The developers do regular updates (sometimes even a bit too often for my taste) and listen to requests from the player community.

All in all well worth the cost (even if I hadn't gotten it while on sale) :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't always take the time out of writing reviews, but I feel impressed to do so.   I have purchased many, many early access games and have always hoped that the game would get better.

Currently, there is a ton of content and things to do.   The game has been out for 6 days now, and it has had  patches, so the developers are working very diligently to fix some of the things that are causing grief (mostly lag and performance related).

We play on a teamspeak and have other people on our server as well.   There is a component that you can play solo, or with other players.   The dynamic landscape is amazing and great to go adventuring.

We have had multiple conversations about this game, and all of us agree that it feels like the developers are actually gamers too.

I am always hesitant to get ea games, but I am more than happy that I bought this game.   It is definitely worth more than what it is selling for, and as long as the updates keep coming (maybe not as frequently as the devs can't get burned out!), then we will be very very happy players.

We play a number of games within our community. but this has captured everyones attention and everyone is having a ton of fun!

GREAT GAME.   GREAT VALUE.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say, I'm not normally a fan of Early Access games. They pull you in with promises and silly gimmicks, and rarely deliver, or do it quite badly. I think my playtime will tell you that GRAV did not disappoint me.

Grav impressed me from the very beginning. I picked this game up on sale for $14, thinking it'd be a decent time. After playing for about an hour on solo play, I realized that I was having a great time! The PvE combat is intuitive, the crafting system (while slightly unbalanced at high-level - those damn artifacts will be the end of me) is very versatile, and getting resources is actually kind of fun! You can run about the overworld trying to find what you want, or you can go into Caves, which is the best way to both gain resources and level up.

The game itself is gorgeous. The sky turns a brilliant yellow/orange as the sun rises, it has countless, beautiful stars in it at night. While slightly buggy because of the REBORN update, the gentle slopes and steep cliffs combined with pseudorandom placement of trees and such is reminiscent of a real place, and you get sucked in. Waterfalls, rivers and grand vistas from mountains capture your eyes and give them a true feast when playing. This is not to even mention how uncannily well they did when you go to a moon or another planet - each is beautiful in its own right.

Following the REBORN update, there was a server wipe. Even though everyone had lost their progress, it was okay. Bitmonster has done everything they can to prevent this, and only did it this time because REBORN feels like/is an entirely new game, even better than before.

What makes it different from other survival games?

Tanks, different planets, specialized classes that can upgrade certain aspects of your character, jets, actually claiming territories, and the game is an absolute blast when playing with your friends.

As a note here, I just wanted to also say how EASY it is to set up your own personal server for your friends. You just make an .exe, make sure you have a password, port forward the game and voila; you have a universe for just those that you want.

On top of this, Bitmonster has an excellent staff. I commented on the forums here on steam with a problem with creating a server, and within just a couple of hours one of the staff had responded with a fix to my problem! Anyway I need to get back to expanding my battlestation

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say, I'm not normally a fan of Early Access games. They pull you in with promises and silly gimmicks, and rarely deliver, or do it quite badly. I think my playtime will tell you that GRAV did not disappoint me.

Grav impressed me from the very beginning. I picked this game up on sale for $14, thinking it'd be a decent time. After playing for about an hour on solo play, I realized that I was having a great time! The PvE combat is intuitive, the crafting system (while slightly unbalanced at high-level - those damn artifacts will be the end of me) is very versatile, and getting resources is actually kind of fun! You can run about the overworld trying to find what you want, or you can go into Caves, which is the best way to both gain resources and level up.

The game itself is gorgeous. The sky turns a brilliant yellow/orange as the sun rises, it has countless, beautiful stars in it at night. While slightly buggy because of the REBORN update, the gentle slopes and steep cliffs combined with pseudorandom placement of trees and such is reminiscent of a real place, and you get sucked in. Waterfalls, rivers and grand vistas from mountains capture your eyes and give them a true feast when playing. This is not to even mention how uncannily well they did when you go to a moon or another planet - each is beautiful in its own right.

Following the REBORN update, there was a server wipe. Even though everyone had lost their progress, it was okay. Bitmonster has done everything they can to prevent this, and only did it this time because REBORN feels like/is an entirely new game, even better than before.

What makes it different from other survival games?

Tanks, different planets, specialized classes that can upgrade certain aspects of your character, jets, actually claiming territories, and the game is an absolute blast when playing with your friends.

As a note here, I just wanted to also say how EASY it is to set up your own personal server for your friends. You just make an .exe, make sure you have a password, port forward the game and voila; you have a universe for just those that you want.

On top of this, Bitmonster has an excellent staff. I commented on the forums here on steam with a problem with creating a server, and within just a couple of hours one of the staff had responded with a fix to my problem! Their service, on top of production, is something rarely seen nowadays. These guys really care about making a damn good game.

Get GRAV.

An amazing game where players are the most friendliest things you will ever see in the game ! The community is absolutely amazing but, on the other hand, the game? Its the most ♥♥♥♥♥iest trolling game i have ever seen in my life.

*Mows down caves filled with enemies*
Now, obviously the game thinks its funny to spawn heavy mobs behind you while you are fighting something else infront of you and game wants you D E A D !

Also, there are no procedurally generated stuff, everything is predefined as of now.
But the game is aboslutely awesome !

Detail part

Endless Worlds - The planets of GRAV are procedurally generated from composite parts. This allows for a near infinite combination of biomes, alien sites, and dungeons.  [[[ NOPE . There is no procedural generation.]]]


Procedurally Generated Dungeons - The planets of GRAV are full of dungeons that are created specifically for that planet. Full of rare resources, dangerous foes, and environmental obstacles that provide a high-risk high-reward play area.  [[[ NOPE . There is no procedural generation.]]]

Multitude of planets ? [[[ NOPE . There is no procedural generation.]]] Ptff...  You can visit 1 planet of each kind per rotation, 1 moon , 1 low , 1 mid , 1 high. Some of these are even copies of each other. For eg, Desolate moon (#2 moon) is same as one of the high planets... Like that...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had always loved sandbox survival games, so Grav looked like it the perfect game for me. I'm not saying it's the perfect game, but if you like:

- Space / Alien based games
- Open world exploration
- Crafting your own Items / Gear
- Fighting Giant Alien Monster to get resources

then this may just be the game for you. Think of Grav as a mix between Minecraft and Halo. The gamepley itself is crafting tools and weapons in a world where countless monsters want to beat the crap out of you. The game specs are like Halo - Furturistic, Aliens, Guns, Spaceships, etc. The actual grapics also look like thery were inspired by the Halo franchise.

CON: This is early access, and I don't have the best proccesor in the world, but the actual gameplay was incredibly laggy. I had trouble launching it half the time. When I tried opening a Solo World, the program became unresponsive and I had to open Task Manager to end it. Multiplayer was out of the question. I was kindly provided a heads up that connecting to a multiplayer server would take a few" minutes. But as with the singleplayer sworld
recommended: and I had to shutdown my PC. If you're curious as to what specs you will need to smoothly run the game
hoursPlayed: I would reccomend anything better than what I have- At least 8 GB of Ram and 3 ghz."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Compared to other sandbox games, this one beats them all day one.
1) The price isn't insane.
2) Feature complete- Although more is to come, you can easily get hundreds of hours building, leveling, exploring, crafting, gearing up, exploring dungeons etc.
3) Stable- Yet to have a single crash, runs smooth at 80-120 fps. Doesn't hog memory or cpu (4gb of ram pre-memory leak patch and 20% cpu day one)

Pros:
-Cheap
-Many features.
-Stable.
-BLOOMY graphics.
-Good sound engineering.
-Death penalty is perfect, you lose a percentage of items, which you can pick back up, way better than other games.
-Most people are friendly, the 'hello' and 'high five' feature get spammed a lot with shockingly low pvp, and many people working together, not sure why, it might be that there isn't full loot drop pvp.

Cons:
-Player structures are too fragile, one person can take out an entire player base in minutes with the starter knife.
-Server list type game.. For me I rather mmos with huge playerbases, the player cap per server seems to be 64, and for me that is a thousand times too low, this game has the potential for all the worlds to be connected with the Stargate network, so why break it up so much? Very dissapointed when I discovered that.

Conclusion, awesome game, some people have trouble getting the game to work right, which is a shame, but its early days, and I pour one out for them, but have seen zero sign of those problems.
I'm sure some people will even find my cons" to be "pros"
date: each to their own.. Just not my type of game
recommended: I would rather things be more persistant and meaningful like a real mmo than a server game where your stuff gets destroyed every night."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Positives
------------
-Grav is a beautiful game with almost no hiccups or slowdown if you have a decent rig. The main time I have seen it is posting too many powered lights around our base.

-Lush worlds, and constantly changing cycle of moons and varyng categories of planets to travel to via Stargates.

-Good variety of class types with different skill sets, making the unlock of new skills and blueprints an interesting progression

-Character and monster designs and  animations are good, and dancing is always a blast.

-Fun mellow soundtrack, and though more tracks are always welcome, the current set of songs is easily loopable for hours.

Mixed
------------
-Variety of monsters is sparse currently, likely you'll have seen one variation of each by level 10.. There is varying classes and sizes of monsters, all with different abilities and traits though which is good. Hoping we see more types later on.

-Water areas are currently pointless, and lack a change of gravity, monsters, just any purpose. Still better than prior instant death that can still be found in oceans on moons.

Negatives
------------
-Wood resources are worst grind after establishing a base. Maybe lowering requirements on generators or having trees produce more wood.

-Female models are still not in the game. Play with wife, and models were shown and said to be coming with last server wipe.

-As far as I understand all game operations are optimized, so there's almost no options for fine tuning the video or audio experiences.

Ending thoughts
-----------------
I jumped into Grav with no guidance and the game told me all I needed to know along the way, and I felt like I was still being surprised by new things 30 hours in.

A good majority of retail games dole out a 6 hour experience at a full $60. Grav has also been on multiple gaming sites sale rosters, and I actually got mine on a sale on Humble Bundle dirt cheap, and I often tell friends it's the most game for my money I've ever got. I got my wife a copy as well, and I know she agrees.

The game is somehow heartwarming, and soothing to play. I've gotten lost in it for hours at a time, and it's a great multiplayer experience especially if you bring friends to the party. Obviously it has some kinks to get out, and could use a smidge more content to be excelsior. But hey, you can drop logs for people to walk through, and dance as stupid as possible with friends by a nice camp fire.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun, engaging, and really makes you want to explore. Discovering the new creatures and blueprints was so fun I got lost in this world...For the first 10 hours. During those 10 hours I had much fun discovering new things and setting goals for myself. The classes were an effort to extend the life of this game. Now, I haven't tried the multiplayer first because of the many reviews about the hackers and second because I have no friends who play this game. This is a singleplayer review.  One of the goals I set for myself was to go to the moon. I spent time getting the resources for the portal (and I was a little disappointed it was a portal and not a ship, but it'll do) I made it there and I was sad to discover it was severely underwhelming. There were a couple of new creatures, but it was tedious getting oxygen and it was outright boring for me. Overall, this game was about a 7/10 for me. The pros and cons are below.

Pros

-Beautiful graphics

-Good tutorial

-Flying is fun

-Great exploration

Cons

-Gets VERY grindy

-Combat was sometimes tedious and annoying (finding glitch tactics to kill some creatures which were very overpowered)

-Not much to do after you built a base and went to the other planets, many can lose interest fast

-Blueprints can be a nightmare to get because of the randomness

reviewText:
Early Access Review

People posting bad reviews on this game are not following the games tutorial or even exploring the game. This game is not for people who want to faceroll or can't comprehend what to do. Was simple for me but not for most...

Current Rating: 7.8/10

This game could easily be a 10/10 game by most gamers who are or were into:
WoW, Rust, Entropia Universe, Rift, Planet Explorers, FPS games and more...

I'm going to post some pros and cons and some things that need a bit of tweaking.

Pros:

Decent Graphics
Decent gameplay
Amazing Exploring
Amazing Crafting system that is very balanced
Amazing Opportunitys
Amazing Mission/Quest/Job system
Amazing Dungeoning/Instances
Amazing Loot System
Amazing Player Interactions / PVP / Party Systems
Great Survival Concepts
Great PVP system, allowing low level players a good chance to kill high level players
Great Environments
You can poop


Cons:

Tutorial Starting is hard for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to follow
Jumping Animation is complete ♥♥♥♥
Starting Areas are too flooded for people to experience the game
High Level players can spawn kill you
Dungeons are open world... Kinda
Server populations are too large
Bases are Everywhere and require small amounts of farming to build them
Loading time takes forever on some PCs (Up to 10 minutes)
Base Building influences monster spawns
Blueprints are hard to find when dungeons are being cleared by others
Starting Instances/Dungeons are not noob friendly enough both to locate and complete
Starting areas are WAY TO ♥♥♥♥ING CROWDED!
Not enough starting planets or areas.



Suggestions for Developers:
Fix the cons, There not much but they take time to code in and adjust.
Create more Servers and Adjust the server populations until the next suggestion is dealt with.
Develop more planets and starting areas so that people can explore and actually play the game
^^(Will save you ♥♥♥♥ reviews)^^
Develop Difficult endgame content maybe A planet that you can not build on.
Develop planets you can not build on for exploring and looting(endgame/tutorial planets?)
Develop A more interactive monster system.
Develop an ocean/river interaction(not sure if there is one but there should be)
Develop a fuel source besides wood(Maybe coal harder to find than X)


If these were added and fixed, the game would be a 10/10 for me, I think the game has insane amounts of possibilities and could easily be one of the best games i have played. The game has so much to offer it is unreal.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a good game but spoiled by  looters and  too much mining. * (edit: They just fixed looting issues in an update)

tldr: 7/10.

Bought on sale for $7. Impossible not to reccomend at that price despite some issues below:

Pros:
- Big worlds to explore
- Solid and pretty graphics - performs well.
- many hours of gameplay.
- Great fun with friends. (You will need them, because even on PVE servers people are just horrible).

Cons:
- Grindy. You spend a lot (I mean A LOT) of time mining wood, ore and gems. Too much in fact, prob 70% of time is spent mining.

- No story arc. Would be nice. You sometimes wonder why you are here.

- No LAN coop/ multi. Sometimes you don't want to play with strangers.

-  Looting, death and protecting your hard work. This is the biggest issue in the game for me. Let me explain: When you die away from your uplink/save point, roughly 80% (estimating that number) of everything in your inventory stays where you die in an orb which can be looted by anyone. So 9 times out of 10 on a multi server you will lose all your hard work over and over. That's on a PVE (peaceful server)!! It's infuriating. It turns out that people on the public servers are greedy pigs who will take your stuff without question. IMHO The game should allow you 10 mins to get back to your stuff at least. Next, protecting your hard work. Build a base (which requires hours and hours of mining), come back later from a mission and half of it will be missing and your chests (where you put stuff to to stop death looters) will have been destroyed. Yes, locking a chest does not mean it can't be blown up. The same goes for harvesters (which you cannot protect at all) Why do people do this? It gives them ore,gems, wood etc. The balance between how hard it is to build stuff and how easy it is for other people to wreck it is completely off. It's not all bad, because you can eventually put shields around your base which stop others stealing, BUT shields also need generators which need fuel which can run out.

Long story short, if you dont want people knicking your stuff, you will need to mine and play for about 10 hours just to be in a position to lock a chest from looters. Oh and don't die doing it or you will lose all the stuff you need to lock your chest..
(FIXED on update 19/11/15. Game much better now.)

Minor quibbles: Caves are all flat (you don't ever go down!) and fairly repetitive.

Exploration: Sadly the most fun thing to do is quite hard. Would be much better if you could jump to multiple uplinks (save points) earlier in the game. You can only have one active at present and will need to spend 20+ hours to get the teleportation room.

Summary: Good fun overall. Lots of potential. Community are all horrible thieves with no respect. 7/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGRAV is an extremely unpolished, rather pointless survival tps. While it looks decent, and has acceptable combat mechanics the poor performance and the glitchy gameplay makes it barely playable. Progression is lackluster, there are classes, but they do not give enough variation. Blueprints can be found by defeating mobs, but just like leveling it is too slow and gets grindy right from the beginning. I died on moon with around 2000 of many of the resources and I got only 200 back when I got revived. I could not even find my backpack, neither the backpack summon stim worked. Hours worth of grind wasted mostly because of bugs and performance problems. As the game got bundled recently and updates are pretty much died out for a few months now, it seems like GRAV is going to be another failed early access title. In its current state the game is not fun and does not have much to go for, it is simply a waste of time.

Gameplay: 9
Graphics: 9

HOURS PLAYED: 150

GAMEPLAY - GRAV is an open world survival crafting Action-RPG game that feels like an MMO, but plays more like 3d Diablo with guns. The world is an open map with underground dungeons. The whole map is accessible to anyone on the server: no areas are instanced" as you would find in traditional MMO. You start on a homeworld
date: then you can craft stargates for space travel to moons or higher level planets.\n\nThere are RPG style classes called "Jobs" that you level up and then unlock abilities. Each job has different abilities
recommended: but the class progression isn't totally central to progress
hoursPlayed: your crafting is more important. Crafting is fun and requires building different supply stations that you use to manipulate the raw materials you find dropping from enemies or loot crates. Base building is well developed and currently you can build a few dozens options for room types and powered items such as gun turrets

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be brutally honest, it's fun for a little while, but No Man's Sky is going to blow this out of the water when it comes out.

Contents of Grav:
-There are like 6 different monsters total, each with different coloration but the same abilities.

-It's minecrafty, but little if any procedural generation. Environments are randomly generated, but you come across the same rock or cliff formation or inaccessible outpost over and over again.

-I believe it is restricted to one or two planets, but I have never been able to get off-world, if that is even possible.

-No story, no lore, just mindless shooting and mining and bashing the same damn slime thing over and over.

-The only goal is to kill monsters to get cooler gear to kill monsters faster.

-Water kills you. The developers have spent so little time developing their underwater textures that they merely slaughter any player who so much as steps in a puddle.


Don't waste your time. I hate to advertize games, but if you want a cartoony planet-hopper, go pre-order No Man's Sky.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is more like a MAYBE review than a positive one.

I loved GRAV, enjoyed it a lot, but there comes a point where you're at the end game and there's little more for you to do. Which is fine for singleplayer, could use a solid story, some worldbuilding and some lore. Filled my cup of tea anyway.

However, go to multiplayer and it's a different picture, with pros and cons. It's still fun, still great, now with neighbors to get along and trade with. In PvE, your bases are generally safe. In PvP, not really. Back on PvE though, you'll still hit that end game. Once you do, you might quit. My bases have multiplayer-deteriorated by now, so I have even less interest in coming back.

Gameplay aside, there were still technical issues as of late 2015. It was poorly optimized for a game made with the Unreal Engine. The UI has room for improvement, but it's not utterly atrocious either.

All in all, I'm voting Maybe" on this one. Pick it up at a discount if you're on the fence."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I only played GRAV during the free weekend, but since I found it to be clunky, convoluted and tedious, I don't plan on buying the game. It only piqued my interest, because it was compared to No Man's Sky. Since NMS is not out yet, I can't really comment on that, but what I'm looking for in those types of games is a sense of wonder & discovery, freedom of exploration and a really good illusion of a living, breathing world. GRAV exhibits none of those things. You're basically greeted with limitations and what awaits you is a long and painfully exhausting grind just to make the experience bearable.

GRAV features slow movement, fast rate of fatigue/hunger, ultra fast day/night cycle (and the night is annoyingly & overly dark, thus barely playable), awful uncustomizable avatar, animations with too few frames, which makes every action & combat look twitchy/jerky. The virtual world is flat & boring, also feels gamey - sprinkled with repeated objects & mobs of even lower variety dropped randomly here and there, moving awkwardly in small radius. It lacks a lot of basic game & UI functions. It's littered with tiny issues, that may feel insignificant and be easily dismissed each on they own, but combined together they just overwhelmed me and successfully killed any sense of wonder and the will to proceed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An excellent, early ALPHA sandbox survival/exploration/action/building game.

I highly suggest you play GRAV. The Dev team is highly active and updates roll out constantly.
The community is alive and it is just down right fun.

Pros:
1. One of the best soundtracks I have heard ...and I work in the game industry.
2. AMAZING graphics..it is just downright pretty!
3. Procedurally generated, random worlds - yes, world**s**, each server is different.
4. Fun, easy to get into but hard to master.
5. Awesome crafting system.

Cons:
1. It isn't done yet...damnit.
2. Can get a little bit grindy.
3. Glitches and bugs..it IS AN ALPHA.

As long as you're not expecting a perfectly polished, AAA game = this is about as good as an early ALPHA Indie game gets, and the Dev team is only like, 6 guys? Wow.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

this is an early access review and is not based on the complete game. Some features are not yet in the game.

This game even though in very early access is a thrill to play. The open world procedural generation means that you can go out for as long as you like and explore. The graphics are beautiful, if cpu and ram intensive. I however only have 6 GB of RAM and I am able to run the game through some tweaking of the config files. This then allowed me to play the game. The loading screens take a long time to complete and sometimes may cause the computer to freeze up for a few minutes. However if you let it load and don't try doing anything then it will soon allow you to join the game. Overall the gameplay so far is unique and interesting, the game takes aspects from multiple different games including minecraft, space engineers and multiple other well known games. As more features are added in the future i'm sure we will see the game grow nad evolve.

Each day a new patch is released for the game meaning new features are added and the game is upgraded. The team work around the clock to make the game the best it can be for the communtiy. This is also the reason they state that they have released the game as early access after only 5 months in development so as you can imagine there are multiple bugs and high levels of lag along with a unusual GUI and menu system that takes a little getting used to. Overall the enemies progress in strenght as you explore and the use of caves and dungeons means there is always somewhere to explore. The PVP adds in an extra amount of danger to the world you spawn in and allows you to form friendships and enemies. The advancment of technology and research in the game is interesting and flowing. Blueprints can be collected from enemies to help you build more complex machines and become more powerfull. The addition of sci-fi technology such as shields and automated farms means you feel like a futuristic planet explorer.

A few negatives of the game in it's current state are as I have previously mentioned the lag and amount of CPU/Ram usage. It does require a beefy computer to play at this current point, however fiddeling with the configs does allow you to unlock a massive amount of fps for the game. A second negative is the single player set up as to do this you need to create a dedicated server which takes up even more RAM. Unlike minecraft there isnt a single button you press to get it working, however there is a guide on their wiki on setting up a server. Apart from these few problesm and glitches such as going through rocks, everyhting else is tip top and the creators are very caring of the community.

Overall review scores:

Graphics

+ beautiful design
+ vibrant colours
+ awe inspiring sights
- very cpu and ram intensive

9/10

gameplay

+ intriguing system of technology
+ increasing level of enemies
+ proceduraly generated enviroments
- fallign through rocks and glitches
- not much variety of things to do (will most likely change in the near future)

8/10

multiplayer

+ good use of PVE and PVP
+ co-op gameplay
+ DANCING TO REGAIN HEALTH
- difficult to play single player so multiplayer is the only real way

9/10

overall total

A brilliant game with much promise for the future.

92/100

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes it's another early access, survival, sandbox, base building game but it's a pretty fun one at that. The Scifi setting is refreshing  and so are the gadgets you can build - wing suit, jetpack, doom buggy. It's highly satisfying gliding around the map quickly with the wingsuit.

GRAV Reborn runs a lot better than a lot of the early access titles out there and the visuals are great especially the lighting, which can likely be attributed to the unreal engine.

The game is lacking any kind of real threat, the mobs are quite simple and feel a bit like stock assets. Purely as PVE it might get boring quickly unless you are a big fan of base building, which I did enjoy more in GRAV than in other titles.

The PVP is fun, full loot, large variety of weapons and breaking into bases that haven't been properly secured, or have had their generators run out of fuel, means you can rob them blind.

Did I mention you can hit P to take a dump? Best thing since teabagging.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me preface this by saying after downloading Grav I played for the full 23 hours on my account...straight.  The game play is what I would consider to be a masterpiece in the making.  So why is it a game like this, even on a free weekend, cannot manage to get even a third of their main servers full, of which there are few?  Simple, implementation.

This game is mind-blowingly behind in terms of basic functionality. ANY game I can think of at least has the following:
1) Graphics settings beyond toggle on/offs.
2) Sensitivity options as part of the GUI.  That's right, you need a console command to change your mouse sensitivity, sound levels, etc.
3) Local/LAN/small group play.  You can play solo, but the content differs to an extent.  For the most part you get the same stuff, but the 'backbone' of the game Element X is 10 (hurrr) times (hurrr) worse than on a multiplayer server.  So this might as well not exist beyond the first couple days. Which is why the rest of the points are so damn important.
4) Server Hosting.  While this game has it, it is absolutely horrible.  Most hosting companies won't even touch this game.  They operate each planet on a separate server.  So if you want to host a server, you might end up eating 10GB+ and having seven different commands prompts.  As mentioned, even if you manage to get that far, which my doctorate and 15 years hosting experience barely accomplished, you will spend days figuring out how to tweak the server to your liking.
5) GUI support for passwords.  Yes, if your server is password protected, people cannot click it and type in the password.  They have to go into console and type in a syntaxed command.  Most players won't ever figure this out or bother unless someone copypasta's it for them.
6) This list could go on, but the point is... playing with friends, playing how you want, altering graphics and basic configuration options are such a pain that it makes this a research simulator.  Which would be viable, if everyone hadn't given up trying to figure it out already and all the research is from January.  As mentioned below, Reborn is out so all that is irrelevant now.

This free weekend was probably Grav's last real chance.  It just ruined its reputation.  When you can't give a game away, which is of such outstanding quality (really it is, the game play is FANTASTIC), you've really screwed up.

TL;DR: Grav is spectacular, but all that potential is being wasted because the developers have failed to implement even the most basic ease-of-use functionality into the GUI and into the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well, as so as many other Early Acess projects, Grav still needs a lot of work to become perfect game, but it has a lot of potential. I must say that Grav became much better after reborn patch, so i hope the devs will keep working on it and we'll see much more improvements in the future.
Anyway, for an Early Acess project, game is really playable and very addictive. You just have to know that there are no NPC quests, no story line etc, it's more like sandbox experience. So if you are looking for the game where you can save the world by killing rats and collecting their tails, Grav is not the right one :)

You can play Grav offline in single mod, or online on one of many servers. At this moment, it's really hard for new players to start on PvP server (every server is kinda PvP except the ones labeled as PvE), because of high population and actual ruleset which is kinda newbie-unfriendly. If you just want to relax after hard day at work, and you want to explore planets, kill creatures and build your base, i'd really suggest to join one of PvE servers, which are much more friendly to new players.

I really like Grav skill system where you can level up every single job (atm 7 jobs, 60 levels each) you wish and upgraded passive skills remains active, you can even use active uber skills" you have learned from other jobs. You can only craft some items with particular job / level

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game on Thursday, didn't realise it was free weekend so instinctively refunded it to save my money/buy it at a cheaper price.

Incredibly unique take on survival games. Great gameplay, great potential.

A lot of reviews after the free weekend are negative, understandably as the servers weren't totally prepared for such a large influx of players - and some lag issues were present.

People have been complaining about lack of basic features (i.e. brightness, some video options, sensitivity options) etc. That's fine, but please bear in mind this game is in ALPHA right now. Not even beta.

Homeworld is small? Is it really a planet? It's not huge, sure, however it's far bigger than you think because new players physically can't explore all of it without dying. The low-level and above exo-planets however are extremely vast and expansive, and pretty much require a vehicle of some kind to explore the entire thing.

I really highly recommend this game, it's a unique take on the survival genre and while yes you're gonna be gathering a lot - there are a LOT of ways to speed this up once you pass about level...10 or 15, so pretty early on in. They're also extremely cheap ways, and pay for themselves very quickly.

All of the bad reviews of this game that have come out in the past two or so days will be incredibly helpful for the devs, who released a MAJOR update to this game less than three weeks ago. I look forward to experiencing the next few months.

Creativity: 10/10
Implementation for this stage of an alpha: 10/10
Addiction level: 11/10
Skills at showing off a game for a free weekend: 5/10

TL;DR: Great game, free weekend didn't show all of its nuances and longevity.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat survival game with a lot of promise for the future. Already in the early access it offers a lot of content and is fun both in pvp and pve. The game runs flawless on my computer with 60fps+ in most locations. Exploring different planets and dungeons are pretty fun and you get alot of loot as you kill mobs which makes you want to grind more and more to find new recpies and to level up. The games also uses a class system that lets you choose what you want to level as.  For example I am a pilot" which gives me special traits just for my class which is pretty cool. There are pretty many classes to choose from but also there is a crafting system that lets you build bases
hoursPlayed:
weapons and more!You will need to craft different type of gear depending on where you are going to travel because some zones and planets can be very hostile towards you if you dont got the correct gear for the place. For example if you want to travel to the moon you will need to craft a set that lets you breath on the moon or you can craft and consumable item which lets you breath on the moon for around 5min.

I do however recommend you to play this with someone as the world can be harsh if you choose to play on pvp server.

Overall the game is fun and you should try it on free weekend which the game is running on atm and then buy it if you like it which i did!"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nme and my friends had a literal blast playing GRAV and i hope to buy it in the future once i have a better pc (was a little laggy on my pc) its a fun andawesome game ful of epic adventures and deadly encounters. there are a few little bugs like if you log out (or crash as i did) while driving a doom buggy you lose everything you have on you such as everything in your inventory and all weapons and gadgets basically spawning in as a fresh player but i did still have my home and all my spare stuff in a chest so it only took a few hours to get everything but and it was fun doing it, the options are lacking in any type of graphic setting (that actually help framerate for lower end pcs) and the last problem i had was the lack of tutorial info. for a whole day it was telling me to use my player ability ( i found it in the keybindings section pf the options menu but it would have been a lot faster if the tutorial had told me to simply press Q instead of the box taking up 10% of the screen to just tell me to use my ability. apart from those small things GRAV is a damn good game, i enjoyed it more than most other games i played and i am looking forward to purchasing it in the future. 8/10 would play for weeks. :) i hope it comes out on all platforms when it is released. the console gamers deserve to play this game too, its amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game on Thursday, didn't realise it was free weekend so instinctively refunded it to save my money/buy it at a cheaper price.

Incredibly unique take on survival games. Great gameplay, great potential.

A lot of reviews after the free weekend are negative, understandably as the servers weren't totally prepared for such a large influx of players - and some lag issues were present.

People have been complaining about lack of basic features (i.e. brightness, some video options, sensitivity options) etc. That's fine, but please bear in mind this game is in ALPHA right now. Not even beta.

Homeworld is small? Is it really a planet? It's not huge, sure, however it's far bigger than you think because new players physically can't explore all of it without dying. The low-level and above exo-planets however are extremely vast and expansive, and pretty much require a vehicle of some kind to explore the entire thing.

I really highly recommend this game, it's a unique take on the survival genre and while yes you're gonna be gathering a lot - there are a LOT of ways to speed this up once you pass about level...10 or 15, so pretty early on in. They're also extremely cheap ways, and pay for themselves very quickly.

All of the bad reviews of this game that have come out in the past two or so days will be incredibly helpful for the devs, who released a MAJOR update to this game less than three weeks ago. I look forward to experiencing the next few months.

Creativity: 10/10
Implementation for this stage of an alpha: 10/10
Addiction level: 11/10
Skills at showing off a game for a free weekend: 5/10

TL;DR: Great game, free weekend didn't show all of its nuances and longevity.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Seeing the reviews switching to mixed is what is prompting me to post a review myself.

If you join an EA game and are expecting a completed game with great optimization then do yourself a solid and stop playing EA games. Learn something about the process and be patient. I personally have been playing nothing but EA games because they offer something different than what a AAA can. Indy devs who have passion. Some have passion that burn out quickly but I have been lucky to find games that have motivated people at the helm.

The game is a blast but if you join a non-PVE server expect to die and die often in the noob zone. While losing pixels doesn't bother me, bullies do. I have been calling them out every time and it seems the majority of the server are not griefers. I even had someone take me off the street and hook me up.

I bought the game after getting my moneys worth during my first free session of 4ish hours. I can see logging a lot of hours into the game because there is so much to do. The rpg feel with survival sprinkled in is awesome.

The biggest con for me is trying to link up with a friend from work and starting on different planets. Having a join friend through Steam (that actually works) would be great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A NOTE: I'm mostly touching on the negative aspects on the game, and talking about what I'd like to see in relation to them. I'm better at criticizing for what's wrong, than talking about what's right. Just not my thing.
It's a great game, and has some pretty good goals, and ones that are reachable.
As it is, the core gameplay is there, and everything is neat. It all works, even if it's a bit rough, or even just placeholder.

My only complaints are the combat and the lack of a survival aspect, and no real exploring yet. The combat is incredibly simple for an MMO, having absolutely no input aside from hold left click. Hoping that changes though.

The game has no survival whatsoever, which is dissapointing. Hope that gets added.

The planets have some variety right now, but there's quite a lot of re-used models over all the planets, which I assume are placeholder. There's not really much to find or explore, the planets are very simple. I'd like to see more detail and 'alien' features. Things that make planets worth exploring.

I think the game is worth it, although I can see why you might not want to buy it yet at $20.

Wish I could afford it, being Australian, currency conversion is terrible, so the game is expensive :(, plus i'm broke. Enjoyed the time I had it for, though!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here are my impressions on the game. I've only played the game on the free weeked, so I'm a new player coming in, not a veteran.

THIS REVIEW IS BASED OFF A PVP SERVER EXPERIENCE.

- There's lots of things to do in the game. It's just a shame that this is not immediately obvious to everyone coming in. Blueprints drop from monsters, and new players start off with a few crafting recipes. Unfortunately you may not realise this and conclude that the game is very shallow and doesn't have depth. Some players are judging the Early Access game just by playing on the starter planet, and I think they should give it another chance, because I think there's still a lot to this game than the starter planet.

- Graphically awesome, though being an EA game it's still got some issues to kink out (some weird lights at night, graphical artifacts near dawn, etc.)

- I was lucky because when I first joined there were also a lot of people asking questions, so I wasn't as lost as some other people. I know a lot of people were confused about the game's direction (What do I do?")

- There should really be a tutorial as well as some newbie protection zone. I heard some people giving bad reviews because a couple of people were running around the spawn point and killing level 1s.

- Yes
recommended:
but most people who complained probably didn't get past MultiTool Mark 1.

- Don't die.

Overall
hoursPlayed:
I actually liked the game for what it is and have high hopes for the future of this game. I hope it will be one of the more successful sandbox games out there.

EXPLANATIONS AND COMMENTS ON THE GAME'S BAD REVIEWS:
(Note that this game had mostly positive review BEFORE the free weekend)

- New players coming in got immediately killed by some higher levels.
Solution #1: RUN.
Solution #2: Join a PVE server instead if you don't even like the idea of getting killed?

- New players don't like the grinding in the game.
They get faster as you upgrade
voteText:
and as you kill higher level mobs the better loot they'll give you (plus seeing blueprints drop is satisfying)

EDIT: So look what I found on the latest changelog - "The game will now take action against non-newbie players killing newbies. "
They've been listening!

TL;DR - It's a beautiful and graphically stunning game. It's got way more polished content than any Early Access game out there! Give it a try and you'll find a friendly community willing to make you a better player."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start off, the current state of reviews being 'Mixed' is inaccurate. The new Reborn update has completely changed the game and so I wouldn't bother taking those into consideration.The game is in early access still, but that being said, it has immense depth and work put into it. The new update has pretty much completely reworked the game for the better, adding hours of content.The game is similar to your average open-world survival game, so if you liked ARK, Rust, DayZ, or even Arma, I'd suggest checking into it.

You begin your journey by being placed into a region, filled with all kinds of life: creatures, trees, water, travelers, and even mobile vending machines. You'll begin to build your first structures for survival, machines to assist you in crafting, level up, and create new weapons. Night time will hit, you'll see the monsters roam about, and explore the next day. While exploring you found a cave and another player's base, guarded with a forcefield. You can either take the route and try to raid the base for more loot, or venture down into the cave and fight dangerous boss and collect ores!


Pros:
-Easy to run (atleast for me).
-Self-explanatory crafting system.
-There's always something to do.
-Updated frequently.
-Fun with friends.
-Decent combat system.
-Servers are easy to create.
-Tips to keep you from not knowing what to do.
-Multiple planets to keep you entertained.
-Active and helpful developers.
-Easy base-building + difficult raiding.
-Vehicles provide hilarious times with friends and aid the struggle of traveling large terrains!
-'Official Wiki' is a tab in the Menu.
-You can dance, literally.
-Music is enjoyable.

Cons:
-Grinding is tedious, but isn't as much as ARK.
-Bugs occur occasionally, but they're generally fixed soon after discovered.
-More fun with friends than alone.
-People can randomly join servers that are PvE and destroy territory/bases without restriction. (No anti-grief system).
-Spawns of servers are sometimes camped unfortunately.
-You'll be forced to play in 3rd person (some could care less).
-Lack of graphic customization in-game. You may have to configure files to disable some graphics.

Score: 8.5/10
All in all, I really enjoy playing GRAV. Playing with friends is primarily what keeps me having a lot of fun. The scenery is almost dream-like. Plains don't look boring and grassy - there's huge mountains, and those mountains have caves, and behind those have massive trees, which are surrounded by lakes. There's endless things to explore, and instead of focusing on PvP, you can have just as much or even more fun adventuring out into a giant steel tower, a cave, or even a biodome. If you'd like to watch a vending machine get mauled by 8 dinosaurs, and then watch an entire fleet of combustible turtles swarm your house, then you should probably buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only spent time with the single-player side of GRAV thus far, but I've really enjoyed it.

Throughout the game, I've been struck with a constant sense of wanderlust. There's always some cool new biome or alien structure over the next hill that will stab at your curiosity and cause you to stray from your objectives.

The artistic direction is incredibly surreal and creative, reminding me heavily of the sort of zany world design in titles like Spyro the Dragon. The monsters and everything come into all different forms and names, some silly, some epic, but all of them charming.

Combat is a left-click grind, but I quite like it. Then again, I'm very much a fan of games that implement similar combat/leveling systems.

At its core though, GRAV is a game that demands patience. It is designed for the grinder and the explorer. If you're not particularly a fan of slow character progression, then this game probably isn't for you. But if you're the sort of player that enjoys roaming freely, killing time, GRAV does the job well.
