reviewText:
Early Access Review

Grav, the game where among all the other things to do within it, you can also build a campfire and dance around it with friends.

Where should I start? Ok first off, many people who have just purchased this game are complaining about stability or lag, this is due to the most recent update to the game. Whenever the devs release an update, there will be lag until they release a hotfix which comes out a couple of hours after the initial update. The hotfix has since been released for the servers which will hopefully have cut down on the lag.

now onto the game.
This game is a cozy little open world game that you can play by yourself or with your friends. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and so are the graphics. The world is pretty huge and you'll need more than just the average adventuring skills to know where everything is because you aren't gonna get a map! There are tons of other planets to go to and even a second island that you have to jetpack to from the main planet so you're not gonna run out of adventuring any time soon. The Monocycles go pretty fast once you upgrade them to Monocycle+ and none of the vehicles take too much fuel to run. As long as you have about a thousand of every main resource, you should be fine. As long as you're not too unintelligent, you shouldn't need too much of a tutorial and anything that you really need to know about the game can be found in some really helpful community guides, so go look at those.

The game is very stable(I mean people with laptops run this thing)
The replayablitity never ends with all the different classes that you can unlock
the adventuring never ends as long as you don't stop adventuring
super nice community
dedicated Devs
crafting is pretty fun
graphics are stunning(I mean christ, the main planet looks like freaking Pandora from Avatar)
Soundtrack is comfy and amazing
the entire game is comfy and amazing

Anybody would be dumb to not purchase this now because this game is about to get GUUD
completely worth the original price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me preface this by saying after downloading Grav I played for the full 23 hours on my account...straight.  The game play is what I would consider to be a masterpiece in the making.  So why is it a game like this, even on a free weekend, cannot manage to get even a third of their main servers full, of which there are few?  Simple, implementation.

This game is mind-blowingly behind in terms of basic functionality. ANY game I can think of at least has the following:
1) Graphics settings beyond toggle on/offs.
2) Sensitivity options as part of the GUI.  That's right, you need a console command to change your mouse sensitivity, sound levels, etc.
3) Local/LAN/small group play.  You can play solo, but the content differs to an extent.  For the most part you get the same stuff, but the 'backbone' of the game Element X is 10 (hurrr) times (hurrr) worse than on a multiplayer server.  So this might as well not exist beyond the first couple days. Which is why the rest of the points are so damn important.
4) Server Hosting.  While this game has it, it is absolutely horrible.  Most hosting companies won't even touch this game.  They operate each planet on a separate server.  So if you want to host a server, you might end up eating 10GB+ and having seven different commands prompts.  As mentioned, even if you manage to get that far, which my doctorate and 15 years hosting experience barely accomplished, you will spend days figuring out how to tweak the server to your liking.
5) GUI support for passwords.  Yes, if your server is password protected, people cannot click it and type in the password.  They have to go into console and type in a syntaxed command.  Most players won't ever figure this out or bother unless someone copypasta's it for them.
6) This list could go on, but the point is... playing with friends, playing how you want, altering graphics and basic configuration options are such a pain that it makes this a research simulator.  Which would be viable, if everyone hadn't given up trying to figure it out already and all the research is from January.  As mentioned below, Reborn is out so all that is irrelevant now.

This free weekend was probably Grav's last real chance.  It just ruined its reputation.  When you can't give a game away, which is of such outstanding quality (really it is, the game play is FANTASTIC), you've really screwed up.

TL;DR: Grav is spectacular, but all that potential is being wasted because the developers have failed to implement even the most basic ease-of-use functionality into the GUI and into the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7/10

NOTE: I play co-op on PvE servers

GRAV is a bit different than what I expected.  I anticipated a survival/crafting game but what I got was a hack and slash action RPG.  That's not necessarily a bad thing.  I'm not usually a fan of the hack and slash genre, but I took to this game and can easily recommend it to others.  Here's a run down of the pros and cons:

PROS

1) GRAPHICS - Quite frankly, they're amazing, rivaling that of any AAA game out there.  Everything is rendered beautifully.

2) MODELS AND ANIMATION - The models are as detailed as they are various.  There's a huge variety of enemies and each one is unique in appearance.  The way each enemy moves and the way your character is animated are quite impressive, too.  Your character can even perform complicated dance maneuvers, like twitching or gangnam style, something I found silly but clearly demonstrated the amazing skills of the development team's motion animators.

3) CONTENT, CONTENT, CONTENT! - This game has so much content.  There are tons of items, gadgets, vehicles, weapons, and armor.  It will be a very long time before you run out of stuff to make and use.

4) CHARACTER PROGRESSION - This game excels at its sense of progression, allowing you to develop your character through many, many hours of gameplay.

5) EXPLORATION - The world is huge and varies in biomes.  Additionally, there are other planets and moons with diverse landscapes (and hazards) to check out.  It was all very satisfying.

6) VARIETY OF ENEMIES - The sheer number of different types of enemies was jaw dropping.  These developers put a huge amount of effort into modeling and animating tons of different enemies.

7) VEHICLE TYPES - Wingsuit, jet pack, doombuggy, tank, and many more I haven't even unlocked yet (I think there's a plane or two).  Lots of fun!


CONS

1) LACK OF CAVE DIVERSITY - You will spend a lot of time exploring caves, so it's unfortunate that every cave pretty much looks the same.

2) REPETITIVE COMBAT - The combat in this game is pretty much just kiting and mashing the mouse button, regardless of weapon or enemy, thus the hack and slash designation I mentioned earlier.  The combat lacks any nuance that might make it a more enjoyable aspect of the game.

3) LOOT OVERLOAD - There are so many different kinds of crafting materials and loot in this game that your inventory and chests will be overflowing with stacks of stuff you have no idea what to do with.  I quickly got to the point where I didn't even look to see what I was getting from enemies; and not long after that I didn't even bother looting the enemies at all.  That's not a win in my book.


TL:DR

A fun hack and slash RPG with tons of content for many hours of gameplay, but it suffers from repetitive combat and poor cave design.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Enjoying this game a lot.  I can see a lot of potential.
Right now its a little Grindy (heck, what isnt these days?)
Theres no story line but what ever you make up for yourself.
The environments are as Varied a the video suggests, and require specific equipment to survive in them (beware of low grav environments).
Enough weapons to keep you busy.
I have no tried PvP so I cant comment on that.
The progression is well thought out, in that you dont immediatly have access to all recources, but you have to level up in order to get to the environments the recources are found in.
Updates are slow-ish.  Iv seen worse....
Im running this on Windows 10, and I have to say its smooth a butter.  No memory leaks, no sudden client crashes. The Devs seem to be actively watching the community hub and are paying attention to bug reports there.
Im quite impressed with the work they have done so far, and for an EA its very playable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought the game today. The first few minutes of my first game went something like this:-

Spawned  on a lush, vibrant  planet. Took a few moments to soak in the ambience; unseen animals called to each other in the foliage, the wind sighed through the trees. Tall grasses whispered about my legs and in then distance I could see some strange life forms gambolling about in a meadow.

Wow, I though to myself,this looks amazing. Filled with the excitement of adventures to come, of vistas to explore and  hardships to overcome, I took my first step in a new world. And a long neck reached in from behind me and a huge bird thing killed me in two bites.

I respawned in a grassy plain, I could see hills behind me and a forest ahead.  Jumping around madly, and crying with apparent glee, a large turtle type creature flounced through the grass around me. Initially nervous of its intentions, upon realising that it meant me no harm, I relaxed and took a look at what items I was carrying. Noting that I carried a stout club, I took it out and gave it a few practice sweeps around me. At which point I hit the turtle thing that, being level 7, promptly stomped me into the soft, verdant soil.

At this point I had to stop playing as my young son had fallen asleep on my lap and was  exuding an impressive amount of drool onto my knee. I therefore plan to return to this review in the future once I have spent more time with this great looking game.

10/10 would die twice before I literally had taken 3 steps, again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access games are hard to review in general. There is normally a lot of content missing, and a player never knows when additional patches will either render a game unplayable for a time or vastly improved afterwards. GRAV seems to be one of those games that tends to firm up after additional patches, and I am all the more happy about it.

I find that the gameplay is simplistic and authentic. Gather resources, combat the environment and other players, survive raids, discover new blueprints, and dance around a fire to catch your breath. I am sure that these features, plus the allure of building an infinite amount of structures on the surface of every planet, have kept me in rapture for some time now. The graphics are much better than I had initially anticipated. Even thought the details are simple and repeatative, the overall scenery makes me want to take screenshots whenever I can. !@#$ you F12, your easy access will fill my harddrive space with plenty of screenshots and no remorse!

I have not reached the end game content yet, nor do I know if any exists yet, but the thrill of inching closer to the goal of Rank [420] is every bit as exciting as I imagined. I would hope that more people would discover the game to build a more full and vibrant community, but int he meantime it is noce being one of the few on the server that have become a mainstay for some time.

The only downside I see so far is the lack of real content to make the mystery of why the player characters are stranded on the planetary system. I am sure that BitMonster is busy working on fleshing out the lore of the game, but in the meantime we are left to wonder *why*  the character is left on such an inhospitable planet and *where* they may have come from. As far as gameplay show-stoppers are concerned, the devs still need to do a lot of polishing on many of the collision issues such as invisible walls and excessive clipping, creatures disapearing into walls and rocks, physics that glitch out and destroy vehicles and PC's, and tweak the day/night cycle a bit to allow for more planning.

Overall I give GRAV a huge thumbs up. Head on over to Humble Bundle to pick your copy while it remains on sale. Look up the FireBert on the US EAST Universe and join me for a dance by the fire :)

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSolid game for people wanting a more relaxed pace.  It drives me crazy that people can sink hundreds of hours into an Early Access game and still call it a rip off.  It is definitely grindy"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is not a good game. I was hopeful that the whole open-world exploration and crafting on many different planets would expand on the survival genre, but the devs failed pretty miserably. There are like 6 enemy models, with the bosses just being scaled up versions of the normal monsters. There's not much to do besides run around gathering resources or exploring caves. The caves all look the same though, so after 1 or 2 spelunking expeditions you'll be thoroughly bored. The crafting system is nothing special, just upgraded armor and weapons with tiny damage increases. You can make some base items too, but there's not all that many base elements, so your base will look terribly bland. There's no objectives (or point) to this game, and content updates are virtually nonexistent. Instead of trying to make a good game, the devs seem more focused on being the next big thing" in the already crowded multiplayer survival field. Needless to say they won't achieve this. There are many more deserving games out there

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGrav. Now when I first saw this one, I was rather skeptical. I looked into some tutorials and let's plays of it and thought it would be choppy and really bad. I was proven very wrong by the game itself. As weird as it may seem on the surface Grav really isn't at all. Firstly, the combat system, THANK U JESUS ITS AMAZING. They literally ripped the combat system out of an MMORPG and put it into a building game YAAAASS thank u devs. The system itself is very much like TERA's combat system (if any of you play that game). After that, any structures require a TON of harvesting which makes the CO-OP feature of the game crucial to having the most fun out of the experience because they have the reasource requirements set at the perfect limit to where 2 people can get a structure built 3 times as fast as 1 person could. Grav is honestly the first game I've seen to fully say,Sandbox game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My original review I admit was, perhaps, a little misguided. I'm more against the genre than this game so hopefully the developers don't take it too personally.

I don't get why anyone would want to play this, what's the point in surviving when you just respawn and carry on... that should be a T-shirt. There's just no reason to play it. Yes I only played this for an hour (nearly two) so disregard it if you want but let me boil down that hour or so of gameplay: I spent an hour as an astronaut wearing wood for armour, lasering down trees and dinosaur bones while battering big frogs to death with a club and trying to build a house with the most awkward camera controls ever. I was also later infromed that you can dance around fires to heal... because ♥♥♥♥ you that's why. All of that for an hour with no explanation as to why, how or what my end goal was because like in every other survival game there is no reason for anything. You just do because they told you you can.

I don't understand these kinds of games. They're as frustrating and boring as real life but with no real reward except maybe some pretty pixels. I would much rather just rearrange my living room, cook a meal, look at some fancy pictures (I don't mean porn) and then play any other game in the world. I would get the same experience as playing another plotless survival game.

Let me tell you about the game I dream about; I recently played the Tomb Raider reboot for the first time and when I first sat down at a campsite after having hunted a Deer I thought that it was gonna be one the best games I'd ever played (incidentally it was brilliant, just not what I expected). I thought it was gonna be a survival game with an interesting plot, a relatable character that I actually want to help survive and some kind of goal. An endgame. Until there is a survival game that fits that description ♥♥♥♥ 'em all. This would probably make a better Free-To-Play but I still wouldn't play it myself.

If you like those pointless survival games I see no reason you won't enjoy this one.

I don't but maybe I'm just a dreamer.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOk after playing this game with some friends I got to say some of my friends consider it to be fun, maybe I am just different, but although I am no fan of sience fiction games I was the one initiating and animating the purchase of that game for all of us. I played Starwars The old republic too and loved it. Grav is for me kinda boring after short while, although I love to play with my friends. The reason is that you got to go a lot for collecting to build anything and that I really don't have enough stuff I'd like to build because I am kinda focused on the basebuilding and the items for this are very limited and building doesn't work well, after 2 weeks I was completely done with it and I am not a fan of leveling all professions by killing stuff all the time. Killing is just not interesting enough in this game, there are just any tasks missing, no quests at all. It is just going to the next higher planet and killing next higher monsters, collecting next higher stuff all the time. That's pretty much all that game is about. Even the armor you get build for doing this is not amazing enough to motivate me and the most terrible is that you can do it all all over again if you want to level up the next profession to be able to use its abilities, and there are lots of professions that you would need to level up. So I need to end up to give Grav no positiv review, although the graphics are kinda nice. I know it is still Alpha but this review is about should you get it as Alpha already or not and I guess you shouldn't. Sorry for the developers, but it is just how I personally feel about it. You might like to try it out yourself if it is very cheap on sale. Luckily I did that and did only pay 2 Euro and a few Cent. ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The reviews for this game tanked because of free weekend. It's fun, but there's a bit of an imbalance in both PvP and PvE. Although the game says it's impossible to build adjacent to enemy structures, it is DEFINITELY POSSIBLE TO DO THAT. This leads to a lot of griefing. A rank 75 came up to my house, put down some turrets and a shield, and kept me locked in my house until he decided to take them down. It's even worse in PvE because if this happens, you literally can do nothing because you can't kill other players. Spawn killing is also pretty bad, as in any survival PvP game- high levels just hunt noobs for no reason. There needs to be a starter planet or a peace period for new players so they can get properly geared and defend themselves.

It's fun, but these issues are gamebreaking. I'll change my review when the devs do something to fix this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game experiencePure grind. Exploration gets blocked upon start-up by grinding mechanics. You can't leave areas without totaly grinding the crap out of this game. This game can't decide if it wants to be an exploration game or a survival game, but fails at both. This game will literally EAT your precious time through grinding. GRAV has way less to offer than other survival games: some ore nodes to mine, chopp down trees. No variety in wood types or something like that. All the same. The wood cutting animations doesn't play synchronized with the corresponding sounds and feels awkward: It's kinda inspired by Starbound, but in 3D. The laser doesn't create any serious wound decals on the trees while cutting them.

MultiplayerStutter animations, de-synced sounds and lags. I didn't compare the lags to LAN to check if it's a engine/netcode or server lag, but c'mon, who the hell wants to play this sort of game LAN?

Graphics Looks ok, but that's because of adjustments to the default unreal engine shaders and over-saturation. Bright colors seem to influence people more to play this lag-festival of grind.

This game is even after the so called Reborn" update not worth the time. Not even worth 7$. Safe your money and time and be patience about No Man's Sky."

WARNING! The game is a grinder and not rely playable in it´s present state. Before you read the good and bad listing, you will understand that changes will hopefully be made to better balance the game play and graphics later on! Hopefully!


The good bits first:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a really fun game. It has it's weaknesses, but for being an alpha it is really great.  The graphics are vibrant and refreshing, just like how borderlands is to FPS and Action RPG's, GRAV is to action MMO's. I believe once this is a whole complete game it will contend with the best of them. I have been keeping my eye on this game for a while, and happend to get it on sale. I have put more time into Grav than some of the big budget mainstream games I own.
Pros-
Color-pallete  is vibrant and lighting affects blew  my mind.
Music- is relaxing at times, like atmoshperic soundscape, other times dance party Bass.
Controls- accurate enough , are constanlty improving this in each update.
Playability- always something to do, Either build up resources for building up a base or to make a new vehicle/weapon, Grind in the numerosu dungeons for loot and more blue prints. ride or glide or fly around the Huge maps. there are tons of places to see from the worlds to the moons  and hard to reach areas sooo much to look at.

Cons-
just like any PVP /PVE it has its Trolls
Leveling can be tedious, it has a bit of a learning curve
ITs ALPHA... A-L-P-H-A

Conclusion-
That being said it is one of my favorite games and it has a pretty helpful community and  a world that is constantly growing. Its worth the 20 bucks. It has more to offer than a lot of complete games and its only alpha.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tip: Try reading a review before you downvote it. Maybe you don't know this, but disagreeing with a review isn't actually a legitimate reason to downvote.

This is not one of those reviews where the writer doesn't understand Early Access, and then slams the game because they have no concept of the process. This is a review where I take aim at the underlying principles of the game - things that are extraordinarily unlikely to change in development, a conclusion I attempt to justify with what I feel are compelling reasons.

In good faith and fairness, behold the Pro" list:

PROS	Graphics. This game is much prettier than most of its kind
date: and likely to improve as the game develops.\nSound. I like the music. It's not typical
recommended: and it suits the game's aesthetics.\nAdversarial. I love sandbox games where the environment is dangerous and comes after your base
hoursPlayed: giving you reasons to defend it.\nNEUTRAL	Crafting. Crafting and building are OK
voteText: but unpolished. Doesn't weigh against an early access game
helpfulPercent: though.\nLack of UI features. Where the hell am I? No maps. Again
votesHelpful: a feature that could be added
votesTotal: so it doesn't count as a "con".\nPoor Co-op. You can't yet build a proper base together as a group; everything belongs to exactly one person.\nCONSHere it gets complicated. A list won't do
votesFunny: because for an Early Access game
commentsCount: I must justify anything I think will never change.\n\nExremely grindy. If you have MMO experience
column16: this will mean more to you. The resource gathering in this game is incredibly grindy. Think of WoW or FF14

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a mess, barely alpha. For an alpha game, it tries to do too many things at once without doing anything well enough to impress. The gameplay is mediocre; standard third-person shooting action without oomph. As a player, I lack a direction. There are some introductory quests that might count as a bare-bones tutorial, but a couple of hours into the game I'm already just grinding the same boring mobs to get more levels in hopes of unlocking better stuff via leveling. I don't know if that's going to happen, the game doesn't really tell me. Materials are collected simply by beaming nodes with an all-purpose tool. The environment is indestructible, which means no mining. The dungeons" I encountered were simple tunnels that had some non-aggressive mobs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't buy it full price like I did. Wait for a sale. I paid for the 4 pack, which cost me £45 and the next day the game had 66% off, which for 4 would have cost me £15. I was effin ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Why pay full when you can pick it up for cheaper probably next weekend. Who knows when they're gonna drop sales. It seems the devs don't really care too much for the people who buy full price when they offer it for ridiculously cheap and also ingame you can get free codes for others from lootcrates. It reeks of desparation, and I as a full price consumer feel crapped on.

With the sale and free ♥♥♥♥ brings obvious new players but the servers are so laggy when it gets busy that its pretty unplayable when its at its peak. The ingame chat is filled with salty bellends that ♥♥♥♥ and moan about being killed by higher ranked players, and yes there's plenty of high levels that camp spawn points in worlds which is annoying as hell. I am remembering that it is early access and ♥♥♥♥ like this will/might/should be improved. Ranking is tedious atm. Either mobs are too easy or too hard, there isn't a happy medium. Plus it's not actually too obvious what you're supposed to do. Only after playing +24hrs did I kinda start grasping what I can be doing in the game. A lot of the online guides seem to be outdated and need refreshing.

Devs, you need to improve playability and performance sooner than adding extra content as thats whats needed. The actual game however is pretty badass and worth getting. But don't make people who buy into your game full price feel like their moneys been wasted when they see people picking it up for tonnes less the following weekend.

Even though I feel I've been ♥♥♥♥ on, regardless of whether I have a point to be or not this is a POSITIVE REVIEW but I'm labelling it in the negative catagory. I want the devs to see this and hopefully they look through the negetives to see what they can improve on. But I enjoy the game.
voteText: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI played this over a weekend from my friend's shared account. Very aesthetic and flashy, but overall a shallow game, with mechanics that rely on resource and mob grinding. Ability lines are independently leveled which means you need to go through the same level grind several times over. I don't know if this was a shrewd tactic to stretch out the fabric of gameplay material over a smaller actual developed area, or if they sincerely thought this would be a fun idea. Still very much a work in progress. I would wait on this one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First time doing review here but definitely not the first Early access game i played.
I took the free weekend and played alone on Asia PVP server, I bought the 4 pack but is wondering if i should pass to my friends to play. I believe there are some game balance issue as well as some weird game considerations.

Cons:Base-BuildingNo point building bases as they are destroyed relatively easy, to secure your resource do not put in stash put in your inventory and log off. Turrets can be easily avoided. In PVP server i played, there isn't any proper building intact.
Maps are littered with lots of unused base
Building are in form of rooms and they all look the same, no customization
Game DesignWhen you die, you basically drop almost everything and waste whatever effort to accumulate them. There is not cooldown time, so whoever killed you, immediately runs off with your resources.
Monster spawn in caves have no time gap until you cleared the whole waves, so you have to keep spamming your gun
Mining resources take too long even with upgraded tool, you need wood for most of the crafting and it takes a long time to mine them.
Level of your char doesnt mean ♥♥♥♥, you can be killed by a low level who doesnt want to mine and have everything looted. With everyone spaming their guns, whoever has the majority wins.
Grindfest, i need to up my level to 40 just to get a skill that increase damage by 10% and after 10+ hours i barely reach 20
No way to breakdown materials you crafted(guns, bullets and clothes), so you can only discard them.
Item drop sucks, i played for 15 hours and only have the basic assault gun recipe which i used for more than 10 hours of my playtime
Caves are not integrated with the main map, its more of a small area outside of the map.
Monsters glow too brightly in multiple colors which kind of spoil the scenery
I have not found a way to pass the night, like sleeping
Not much attack skills to speak off, the skills are all stat based (No fanciful killer moves). Most of the time i just spam my gun holding thousands of bullets. Close range attack is just normal or hard attack.
There is no map, once your murderer destroys your resurrection station, you will be randomly placed on the area and you will have to try to find your way back through coordinates.
Tip: you can look at logs(lower right) to see on which coordinates you died.
Lack of contentThe monsters i seen only have 2 attack patterns (regardless of home or moon planet), one close one long attack
Lack of explanation for a lot of ingame mechanics
Maps are kinda of plain, monsters have no habitat nor behavior and just roaming around. Lots of open area with nothing on it.
Lighting(UV map) is not implemented, nightime is total darkess and you will need to craft a bot to hover for light and you have no torchlight
The gun firing sound will drive you nuts, combat animation can be improved.
Only 2 NPC types but multiple clones of them in caves and everywhere, you cant interact much with them except to buy bots. Their sole purpose is to be slaughtered or to block your path especially in cave.
There are different home planets like alpha, beta etc but they all look the same, i believe there are some different planets for mid levels but for low levels it doesnt matter which planet you are on.
Low replayability as the maps are not procedural generated.
OthersCrash often
Controller is not implemented properly
Pros:Seems to have potential for something interesting
Lots of different types of resource
Different type of Vehicles  like monocycle? jetpack (Need wood to move though)
You will feel like exploring the map to see what is around
A bit of survival feel (you will feel hungry but not sleepy), monsters hold food packs for you not meat
Graphics is kind of nice
you can eat processed poop
You can find crates akin to treasure chest in caves and makes it rewarding to fight your way in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lets start with my personal experience then get to the pro's and cons.

Playing with friends is a blast, some players can get really angry when you destroy their harvesters that they are trying to hoard all resources with, just tell 'em to bugger off to a PVE server. High levels can kill lower levels but are punished with a beam above them and killed if repeated. I wouldn't recommend this game alone unless playing a PVE server. From my experience so far, higher levelled players are more inclined to offer you things rather than kill you.

I'm giving it a 8/10 for the ~30hrs of gameplay so far.


PROs
Blueprints come often enough to keep you striving for the next level
Travelling by Air, Land or Portal is always fun with a wingsuit/jetpack!
HEAD OVERIDES! These are such an awesome idea, from wearing a santa hat to a horse head.
Caves/Dungeons these are super fun with friends! Killing minibosses and special monsters that spew blueprints is always exciting
PETS! You can get pets that buff you! DMG/DEF/SPD/XP and one that shines light on those REALLY dark nights.
Once you play a class, the passives and active abilities carry over when you switch to another class and are interchangeable.
You can poop....EVERYWHERE.

CONs
The monster level to damage is a bit rough, I'm level 29 killing a level 30-31 and doing low damage.
There's no mouse sense slider, you can fix that by using console commands though
There's no graphical tweaking options at all, can't change audio levels either, you can turn music off atleast
Lack of different mobs is kind of a drag reskinned and recoloured models, but expect more to be added
If you land ontop of someone or enter a instance ontop of another you get stuck and need to relog
Probably the biggest thing of all, due to the lack of playerbase is there's not much to find in wiki pages about where to find certain resources or monster drops what.


Protip! I found starting your first class as a prospector to level 10 to gain the Strip Mine" ability for gathering those clustered resources really quick is super handy and not to be underestimated.


"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played Grav for all of... 70 minutes maybe? But I've noticed two distinct issues with it so far, mind they're nothing too extreme...

Number One: No Single Player mode. Grav is Multiplay-only, whether this is fixed or not isn't a supreme concern of mine, just a personal recommendation. As it is, anyone with a shoddy internet connection is going to be a bit irate when their connection decides to spazz out on them.

Number Two: Build costs seem a bit high for the sheer disparity in material sources and how they're spread around.
This one should be fixed on the side of ASAP. I can see the crafting stations needing Gems, Ores and/or Fossils to build, but the basic structures... not so much. I would recommend the basic rooms and such being Wood, the exception being the support frames, which should include a bit of Ore. (ie: 120 Wood for a Closed Room. 80 Wood, 20 Ore for a Support Framework). As it is, everything else is okay, so far, given this is an Early Access game.

For those of you looking for a new survival/sandbox game, Grav has potential, just expect a few bugs (and bugdogs) in the meantime.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played Grav for all of... 70 minutes maybe? But I've noticed two distinct issues with it so far, mind they're nothing too extreme...

Number One: No Single Player mode. Grav is Multiplay-only, whether this is fixed or not isn't a supreme concern of mine, just a personal recommendation. As it is, anyone with a shoddy internet connection is going to be a bit irate when their connection decides to spazz out on them.

Number Two: Build costs seem a bit high for the sheer disparity in material sources and how they're spread around.
This one should be fixed on the side of ASAP. I can see the crafting stations needing Gems, Ores and/or Fossils to build, but the basic structures... not so much. I would recommend the basic rooms and such being Wood, the exception being the support frames, which should include a bit of Ore. (ie: 120 Wood for a Closed Room. 80 Wood, 20 Ore for a Support Framework). As it is, everything else is okay, so far, given this is an Early Access game.

For those of you looking for a new survival/sandbox game, Grav has potential, just expect a few bugs (and bugdogs) in the meantime.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, people need to stop downing the game for dying at a low level or that there is so much farming and grinding. There is a PvE server if you don't want to be killed and for the farming and grinding that is to be expected in a Survival Sandbox MMORPG. Now on with the review....

The game is amazing there are loads of potential:

The game looks amazing, it takes a lot of ram though so make sure you're at minimum with the 8gb of ram. I play with 5.42gb (not recommended) and  can get a little laggy sometimes with freezes here and there because of my ram not reaching the min requirements, but I am sure as the game proceeds the ram will most likely come down just like Rust. Now for the combat, it's a little meh, it can get pretty repetitive when fighting monsters and boring with the monsters attacks being repetitive aswell but I'm sure they'll add more to combat as the game goes on. As for the PvP it can get INTENSE and is pretty fun until you die, I recommend that you play with a group on PvP or else you'll get killed very easily by big groups. :( For the crafting there are loads of stuff you can create vechiles, armor, weapons. For the building this is probably the most frustrating part for me and the game is very limited on building, such as when I was trying to build a lip on my base it was hard do, the building is not like where you make floors, walls, and foundations seperate and put them together which they should do.

As of now I would recommend this game with a verict of 7.5/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

this game is great! The planets are all beautiful and base building is pretty fun! It's not very 'survival-y' by any means, ie: your non drilling platform / area totem bases are unraidibke if shielded, and you only lose resources upon death, not gear like rust or ark. But I appreciate that aspect,

Constantly being wiped and rinse and repeating is tiresome, they put the focus on exploration and gear progression.

That being said it makes the incredibly cool multi person vehicles a little less important, but whatever!

I don't think I'd recommend this game for solo players, it's grindy as hell and far faster paced and more fun (pvp) if you have a few friends.

All in all I've really come to enjoy it, it's relaxing, beautiful, and has great structure, excited to see what else is coming!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With a computer that runs this game with the reccommended requirements, this game is a treat with a lot to offer at this point in the development phase. People rating it bad with .7 hours of play time played the free weekend recently and couldnt run it. Even if they could, they probably didn't like this genre in the first place.

The first thing you should do if you buy this game is choose a pvp server and go from there. The pvp is fantastic. The guys who are making this game all worked on the Unreal Tournament games. So the shooting feels punchy, the action is fast, and if you're skilled enough you will be able to defend yourself from any griefing. If you don't like pvp then this game probably isn't for you. However, at the time of this review the population on a server at any given time is low. So griefing isn't a major issue in the first place. When I first started playing there was a problem with higher level guys killing new players, but if you enjoy a challenge and can brush off your shoulders you'll have a good time. Another thing to consider is that you only drop a portion of your crafting materials and ammo, never gear you spent time to make.

There is a grind, but it's the same type of grind you would get in other buildy games. The incentive to kill the monsters in the game is to get blueprints so you can build better tiers of armor, weapons, vehicles, and structures. At first the prices are daunting because you are supposed to develop your character and get skills that reduce the cost of things. Once you figure this part out materials are plentiful and are easy to get. You'll probably lose a base or two on the road to the high planets which isn't too bad because once you know how some of the building mechanics work a base can be indestructable to other players as long as there is enough wood in the generator. The only way to break a base currently is if you place certain items inside of one that cause other players to want to destroy it.

This game says it's a space game but there isn't any space travel. You use teleports that take you to another island that has a different environmental survival condition. So if you don't have a prope suit you can't stay for very long before taking damage and eventually dying. Aquiring the blueprints to the differnet suits requires you to kill monsters around your level range so by the time you have a full suit you'll be the level of the area.

I think the job system is unique in that all of the skills gained from any of the seven jobs apply to your character. So instead of having a bunch of different characters you only have one. The max rank in the game is 420, but that is seven level 60 jobs. It seems ridiculous to have a 420 character at first, but in reality once you hit 60 in any one job you can build and fight just about anything.

It's like Unreal Tournament and a MMO had a weird baby that doesn't quite know what it is yet, but is well on the way to being a better game. Make friends, learn from your failures, don't sweat the small stuff, and you'll have a good time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short review: an interesting dose of leveling progression mixed with building bases and improving weapons/armor. I'd highly recommend it while it's on sale. Still partly recommended while full price if you like building style games with a bit of leveling progression tacked on. Imperfect, but enjoyable for what it's worth. Play with friends, if at all possible. The solo experience is sorely lacking.

Long review: This game has given me good moments, great moments, terrible moments, and horrendously boring moments. While I can think of more cons than pros, I still believe that the overall experience of the game, played with other players or friends, makes up for them. I may not play forever, but I enjoyed the time spent, and so I give this a positive review.

Pros:
-Initial progression is fun, as you get new weapons, armor, skills, and building blueprints" from exploring places and killing creatures
-Building bases is fairly intuitive once you get the hang of it
date: and you can construct whatever you wish
recommended: assuming the area is clear and you have the materials. Most areas are easy to build on.\n-Once you figure out the way to build bases
hoursPlayed: you can construct practical bases
voteText: strange mazes
helpfulPercent: or anything you want so long as you protect it with shield generators and plan properly.\n-Playing with friends is fun
votesHelpful: and pvp/pve is fairly straightforward when working in groups\n-Loot is easy to find and abundant to acquire
votesTotal: and ammo is never hard to come by.\n-Devs are responsive
votesFunny:
and many errors/bugs are fixed fairly quickly.

Cons
-Past the initial fun of discovering new blueprints and going to new planets
commentsCount: the progession becomes a grind. Either a grind to level up to get one particular kind of blueprint
column16: skill
column17: or passive effect
column18: or a grind to 5/8 max rank so that you can get the "best" items. The tedium of leveling each and every class is draining
column19: and I have yet to complete the process despite my playtime.\n-Those same high level items are mostly timesinks
column20: as they require absurdly large amounts of resources to acquire or need a max level class to make/use.\n-Beyond what's necessary to build blueprints and acquire passive skills
column21: the classes you can level are non-unique and essentially the same. Once you have a class at level 60
column22: you are "max" level. Level all 7 classes to 60 and you are "max" rank. No further progression is possible or even useful.\n-Building some structures/items requires leveling particular classes or acquiring rare blueprints
column23: which can be boring solo and at best tedious with a group.\n-PVE is a joke. More of a time sink than a real threat. Except for turtles. Those things will murder you unceasingly.\n-PVP is both interesting and unfair. While any level person can kill a higher level player
column24: the difference in armor and weapons is often the decidng factor. Added to this is odd visual and connection lag that can make PVP a nightmare. You need groups/friends to stand a chance
column25: and the most powerful elemental blueprints are from PVP.\n-Only way to reliably protect your base is with a shield generator and power generator. While these can be filled with enough wood to last 12 days
column26: they are limited in range
column27: and any large construction project requires extensive planning to survive the first person to walk by with a desire for destruction.\n-Glitching is still a reality

First experience with the game: start in SOLO mode, takes minutes to load the planet. Playing on a pretty powerful laptop, I need to knock down all graphic options to reach a playable (not by any means good) framerate. I follow the tutorial instructions for a while and sure enough I manage to craft a few things. Pretty straightforward stuff, nothing groundbreaking but enough to bring me back to it.
Second experience with the game: due to wanting to avoid the mind-numbingly long loading times (thought that would be only for the first time but apparently no, it's a constant) I go on a multiplayer server. All sense of survival in a wild world is dissipated by the fact that I land right in the middle of a small village of bases of other players. It's also a level 7 planet for some reason to it takes me forever to manage to kill a single monster as the tutorial suggests. I get killed multiple times because everything is stronger than me and of course I can't even manage to harvest enough resources to make the most basic armour and weapons before I'm slaughtered by some T-Rex thingy and lose a good chunk of my loot. reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game that's been in alpha since Jan 2015 you'd think there'd be a lot of improvements since then.
This is not the case. I can't recommend this in this state at all.

There's seriously no volume sliders, like what? You're telling me the game has been available for over 12 months and they haven't implemented something as simple as volume sliders. I don't really want the option to have 1. my ears bleeding or  2. be deaf. Also why can't I rebind anything to TAB. I think it's pretty common to want to open your inventory with TAB. Can't do it though, no that would be stupid wouldn't it. How about wanting to play the game in a window, sure if you want the game to crash instantly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When you get killed you lose 90 percent of your inventory. I do not like this so I chose a seemingly friendly server, only to get killed with one gunblast from a level 10 player who happened to pass me.
A very friendly player explained me that what I needed was a PvE server. So problem solved.
Nice game with lots of construction options and beautiful views. Will update my review after more gameplay.

Update 18 may 2016

You can now invest in a skill to reduce the amount you lose when you die. Also, when you are further in the game you can build mulitple bases,transporter rooms etc. So there is no need to carry much around.
The game is very addictive, 60 hrs+ in 2 weeks says it all. As it is still in alpha, sometimes accidents happen, I lost a base after an upgrade that prevents building in starting areas. But most of the time you get refunded a good portion of what you lost. I suggest when you start the game to focus mainly on building your character and upgrading your skills. The spawning of the monsters is sometimes a bit over the top, in caves they respawn right behind you and is some places keep respawning. After a while you get used to it and it gets you much XP points and keeps the fights interesting.
Always things to do and new things to build., 10/10 so far

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has problems. The good thing is that they are minor, updates are frequent and support exists.  The grinding is better than most. May seem overwhelming at the begining but, as you aquire levels and ranks the grind becomes more expidited.

Loosing everything you have is not such a let down. It is easy to recover from base raids and pvp battles. Resources are easily aquired. Farming is an enjoyable experince.

Vehicles are sweet. Really enjoy the dog fighting in the jet.

This game is great fun. You make it what you want. Having the freedom to build a thunder dome, a race course or a caputre the flag game, adds to the appeal of this game.  Recomended that you play with friends or make friends.

Dont play single player.

Be a space pirate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game more than anything need to be optimized better. There are people with 8 gb ram having issues to run the game. I have little to none with 32 gb but I still do get random freezes midgame and died more than once or twice due to it. The game have been unbearable at times with Connection Interrupted, on EU PVE server, all the time. People I play with seem to face a 10% chance to either freeze/crash whenever they enter a loading screen, besides the fact that it takes them about 10 min to just actually get into the next zone.
+ Great potential for the game
+ Good class/leveling system/Quests can be annoying but are generally good
+ Blueprint system to learn new stuff
+ Graphics, look good compared to Early Access games in general
+ Music, really lovely music. Some nice space ambient on at times and other Mass Effect like tunes - BIG MINUS;  Memory issues
- BIG MINUS; Option, graphical settings, sound settings
- People being able to destroy and loot your bags even in PVE(Could be FoF locked for friends)
P.S If you crash when you first start playing or having major issues, please refund it instantly .It wont get better for you and itll make you upset once you can't refund it. The game definitely is borderline unplayable for many people due to memory issues, some are champs and still go through it but I don't think you shouldd have to spend that money and be suffering those issues. Buy it when it get fixed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've owned and played this game for a while now plus it just had a major overhaul so it's time for a review.  The game is quite a grind, now this isn't always bad I like some, but in this case it is.  While there are multiple planets to explore and farm, the enemies and npc's are mostly the same on every planet.  While leveling, mob's only take 1-3 hits to kill you even with appropriate gear.  You may very well wear your left click out on your mouse playing this game.  Farming wood/ore/etc. is slow, there are so many items that will only be used once to craft a gun or gear you'll constantly be leaving trash items.  Which comes to the next negative, loot used to float to you and auto pick up after a kill.  Now little boxes are left from each mob for you to look through to try to get only what you want.  During an event this isn't going to happen, you'll die trying to sort loot.

The game does do some things uniquely, but overall the gameplay tends to get old pretty quick.  Building is limited to premade structures to place near/on each other.  Surviving is just keeping a bubble shield up on dangerous planets, if you are low on stamina/health you can dance at a campfire instead of eating to refill.  Crafting you'll have to farm mob's over and over for blueprints, but you'll be doing that to level all the jobs anyway.  You'll make ammo, it drops off mobs, but not as fast as you'll click.

Graphics options are pretty limited, but you can edit your files if you feel comfortable doing that, I had to in order to get better FPS.  This game does not seem to play well with AMD GPU's, many reports of graphics glitches on good cards, I've had quite a few using an AMD A10.  Minor ones such as white outline/shadows and more major where 2/3rd's of the screen is blocked.  This game will eat RAM and CPU like nothing, over 8 gigs of ram in single player.

As for replayability, my hours were put into both the original and Reborn" as well as editing some of the files to play more the way I liked.  Still this was a game I rarely found myself playing
date: most hours played at first purchase and maybe 20-30 after Reborn.  If you like PvP or have a group of people to play with you may like it
recommended: PvE just feels lacking in this game even tweaking the guns/tools/etc. still left something to be desired."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its a great game. Really fun, and I continue to play it. But I have to downvote it.

Why? Because the question is Do you recommend this game?" And with such a toxic community that exists on official servers I honestly cannot.

New players are griefed
date:
players destroy bases without provocation and for no reason whatsoever. The moon is a no go zone under pain of death for any low rank player (despite the fact you need to go here to progress).

All that happens is you hit a player generated wall of difficulty that should not exist. But is created by the usual survival game=mugging simulator mentality. The sort of mentality that exists to overcome probably real life issues that these players no doubt have. Or simply to enlarge their Twitch eDing-a-ling. Players then will most likely quit through boredom of not being able to progress. And before early access is over I am sure the playerbase will eventually kill itself off.

However even if you do progress (and this is an Alpha comment so I do not say this as a main problem) There is not much more to see enemies are merely recolorations or each other. And all that is new is perhaps a different resource to grind at (while other players constantly mug you for it.) And maybe you are doing this in an environment that is as toxic as the players.

In my opinion the method to fix this game is a dualing system rather than a mugging system and/or any player under general rank 20 should be unable to harm other players or be harmed by them. That way newbies can at least have a brief starter respite from getting shot realising the toxicity and refunding their game. The rest is Alpha is Alpha issues which I am sure content will be improved upon over time. But in my opinion wait this one out until Beta or maybe even Full Release."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty nifty as far as open-world sandboxes go. I like the notion of having to go out and gather blueprints to craft new items (though this gets a little tiresome at times when waiting for certain blueprints to drop). There are a few things I would like to see improved, such as cave spawns (it takes forever to even get through the lower-level dungeons due to the rate of monster respawns, especially in small enclosed spaces with little mauverablility), and more efficient armour (the armour items available early on the game barely feel like they help reduce any amount of damage). I'd also like to see the implementation of craftable waypoints, to be able to mark the coordinates of wherever they're dropped (this may or may not be something that's craftable, but I haven't found anything fitting this yet).

Overall though I feel that the game has lots of opportunity to add and expand as it continues along in its development, and I look forward to its future improvements. For the price being asked for the game (especially as it's on sale at the moment), I feel it's worth the purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its probably a little soon to leave a review. But after only 9 hours of gameplay I already feel like I got my Moneys worth. If you are hesitating about buying this game. Dont. This might be early access but I must say it is the most polished and well presented one to date.

Pros:
Price
No Major Bugs. Very Polished for an early access game.
Stunning graphics.
Nice crafting system.
Nice tutorials.
everything is easy to understand (I didnt have to spend hours reading up on how to play the game).
Massive planets to explore which enclude caverns and moons.
Guns, Land Vehicles, Spaceships.
World Bosses.
Nice loot system.
base building is a dream. (again nothing too complicated).
Dungeons.

Cons:
A little bit grindy. Takes a while to get the blueprints you need. But this is a survival game and to be honest with you it wouldnt be as fun if you didnt have to work a little for your gear/upgrades.

I recommend this game for anyone waiting for no mans sky.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good survival game with good RPG elements. Very polished animations, very pretty. Also, unlike Rust/ARK, if you're killed, you do not lose everything! You only lose large amounts of your resources/gear/etc. if you have already been killing players. This means if you're a passive player on a PvP server, you will lose minimal amount of resources upon death - that's it. If you go around killing people, you will get skulls following you, letting other players know that you have been killing people and are basically a walking loot crate. I enjoy this concept.

This is a good EA game but it remains to be an EA game that I hope will come to fruition and do well in the future.

On the subject of the game currently being a Mixed" review - this is due to the free weekend and people moaning about grinding.

Let me tell you about "Grinding"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not a bad game, it sort of has a planetside/world of warcraft mix to it. No real storyline, but you'll be wanting the next toy from the level your gonna get to become addicted and befor you know it, you'll get your money's worth from raw play time. During the free to play time I had 11/15/2015 there was no survival aspect.....shoot stuff, level, be able to build new toys. The world looks a little dated and cartoonish, but its pretty and works.

Thumbs up, I wont be buying it because I don't need another mmo sort of game in my life right now, but after a few updates and me being bored, I'd give this a shot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has the potential for being one of my favorites, but right now these are my impressions.

What I liked:- Art is amazing.
- Made in Unreal Engine 3, it runs fine on a toaster if you know how to edit the settings*.
- Blueprint hunting is fun.
- Exploring is fun.

What I didn't like:- Unbalanced. Killing a mob with a higher level than yours is hell (and you have to in some situations).
- Repetitive. I was gonna say It needs more monsters" but it's not really that. The same monsters are everywhere (with recolors) and it totally kills the feeling of "I'm in a different place than before". Dungeons need unique bosses. Planets need unique monsters and unique dungeons.
- No endgame.
- * Graphic settings are incomplete. To change some stuff you need to edit a config file.
- Devs need to play the game more by themselves to notice its flaws. Some stuff is pretty basic.

tl;dr: Game needs further development. A little more content
date: but some good tunning. Right now it's not good enough."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played during free weekend- even on sale, i wouldnt buy it. but in a bundle- maybe.

Its not that its bad, its fun-sorta. its very open, unending..
no real objectives, just a open world-as advertised.

however...lack of people....and people who are there, have all the resources already because they invested time/money/etc.

takes time..alot...to realize your making a life there, to almost do the same thing you could in real life.

conceptually its fine, it just lacks direction and polish in my opinion. its not high-stress.
but night is annoying as you cant do anything except hide in your house from various creatures who come to kill you at night-mostly.

im saying i dont recommend GRAV,
not because i dont think you shouldnt play it when its free.. i just dont think you should pay for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well what can I say. I am of mixed emotions over this game.
The Idea of the game on the outside is great. Finally an MMO based game that gives you the single player choice and let not go on how big it is because I'm yet to even set foot off the 1st planet. That being said the reason why is because even after they said they fixed the fps rate for single player. I am spawned into a slow, scattered paced world which is very annoying with the glitching soundtrack in the background like someone turning the volum on and off every second and lets not get started with going online and playing because thats just a slaughter house of bad bandwith and overloading. The only good fun times I have in the game so far are in the desert and inside some dungeons ( maybe because it doesn't have so much ♥♥♥♥ going on in the background that you can't adjust in the options like other normal games eg: Load distance ).
Constructing is fun and a great idea too (If you like building something then blowing it up and then building the same thing on top just so you can get the walls right).
Also lets not get started on how damaging it is on my computers RAM even 10 minutes after shutting the game down.

All n all It's a good game for VERY HIGH PERFORMANCE COMPUTERS.
But needs to start focusing on fixing the problems instead of saying that they did.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty nifty as far as open-world sandboxes go. I like the notion of having to go out and gather blueprints to craft new items (though this gets a little tiresome at times when waiting for certain blueprints to drop). There are a few things I would like to see improved, such as cave spawns (it takes forever to even get through the lower-level dungeons due to the rate of monster respawns, especially in small enclosed spaces with little mauverablility), and more efficient armour (the armour items available early on the game barely feel like they help reduce any amount of damage). I'd also like to see the implementation of craftable waypoints, to be able to mark the coordinates of wherever they're dropped (this may or may not be something that's craftable, but I haven't found anything fitting this yet).

Overall though I feel that the game has lots of opportunity to add and expand as it continues along in its development, and I look forward to its future improvements. For the price being asked for the game (especially as it's on sale at the moment), I feel it's worth the purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GRAV is an amazing sandbox/survival game with great potential , let me simplify this review:

good:
*great atmosphere at times
*manages to balance chaos and clam areas well
*wacky yet sometimes serious
*both gun and melee combat are fun and well done
*boss areas are a fun challenge

The not so good:
*very repetetive ((kill/craft/explore) then again it is a survival game..)
*having to run off to get resources aaaaaall the time gets very boring
*loot boxes are level restricted

My own personal gripe
*i know its a survival game...but i want some form of at least basic story! everything is there...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its probably a little soon to leave a review. But after only 9 hours of gameplay I already feel like I got my Moneys worth. If you are hesitating about buying this game. Dont. This might be early access but I must say it is the most polished and well presented one to date.

Pros:
Price
No Major Bugs. Very Polished for an early access game.
Stunning graphics.
Nice crafting system.
Nice tutorials.
everything is easy to understand (I didnt have to spend hours reading up on how to play the game).
Massive planets to explore which enclude caverns and moons.
Guns, Land Vehicles, Spaceships.
World Bosses.
Nice loot system.
base building is a dream. (again nothing too complicated).
Dungeons.

Cons:
A little bit grindy. Takes a while to get the blueprints you need. But this is a survival game and to be honest with you it wouldnt be as fun if you didnt have to work a little for your gear/upgrades.

I recommend this game for anyone waiting for no mans sky.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good survival game with good RPG elements. Very polished animations, very pretty. Also, unlike Rust/ARK, if you're killed, you do not lose everything! You only lose large amounts of your resources/gear/etc. if you have already been killing players. This means if you're a passive player on a PvP server, you will lose minimal amount of resources upon death - that's it. If you go around killing people, you will get skulls following you, letting other players know that you have been killing people and are basically a walking loot crate. I enjoy this concept.

This is a good EA game but it remains to be an EA game that I hope will come to fruition and do well in the future.

On the subject of the game currently being a Mixed" review - this is due to the free weekend and people moaning about grinding.

Let me tell you about "Grinding"

Yes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pretty nifty as far as open-world sandboxes go. I like the notion of having to go out and gather blueprints to craft new items (though this gets a little tiresome at times when waiting for certain blueprints to drop). There are a few things I would like to see improved, such as cave spawns (it takes forever to even get through the lower-level dungeons due to the rate of monster respawns, especially in small enclosed spaces with little mauverablility), and more efficient armour (the armour items available early on the game barely feel like they help reduce any amount of damage). I'd also like to see the implementation of craftable waypoints, to be able to mark the coordinates of wherever they're dropped (this may or may not be something that's craftable, but I haven't found anything fitting this yet).

Overall though I feel that the game has lots of opportunity to add and expand as it continues along in its development, and I look forward to its future improvements. For the price being asked for the game (especially as it's on sale at the moment), I feel it's worth the purchase.
